reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was skeptical at first, but the game is extremely entertaining. I bought the game two nights ago and already have almost 24 hours logged. I've assaulted two ports alongside massive fleets and levelled my profile to level three. Everything in the game feels solid, from the level up speed to the sense of achievement.

The game almost works like Mount and Blade: Warband does in regards to the sailing map. Time is sped up and you can find/initiate battles anywhere in the world. These battles take place in smaller instances" just like M&B.

The combat is nice and firing cannons feels and sounds satisfying. Gameplay is very engaging because you can choose what your cannons shoot; cannon balls
date: chained cannon balls or grapeshot. Each type has a different effect on the target. The ability to play with a clan or friends is very useful for many poeple
recommended: but it is also possible to enjoy the game while playing solo (like me).\n\n8.7/10 in it's current state

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval action is a beautiful game about the age of sail, it gets its charm from the time period it is based off on which no other game currently really does except badly made ones, ones which do not exist or assassins creed, which is mainly a land based game and it doesnt provide the realism that Naval Action does. Naval Action is purely a ship based game, no walking on land or walking around on the ships however this does not mean that boarding is not a thing, whether you are a pirate or you sail for any of the numerous navies you can capture enemy ships and either take her a prize, sell her or even just sink her and keep the possible loot for your self for trading purposes.

The game also features a crafting system which you can use to craft ships, however if crafting is not something for you you can buy ships from the stores or find a crafter which can craft a ship to your specifications, there are plenty of crafters out there.

Upgrades allow you to change the qualities of your ships, most upgrades have some short of downside which means that you have to pick and choose which ones best fit your style, you also have a limited amount of upgrades slots and if your ship looses all its durabilities(lives) you will loose the ship and all its durabilites

Positives:
-many beautiful ships ranging from the tiny lynx(schooner) to the giant first rate 138 gunner that is the santisima

-an open world with ports and plenty of enemies to fight

-Great visuals and amazing looks

-simple UI

-everything isnt done for you, navigation and such is up to you so you can get lost

-Both PVE and PVP servers so if you dont like PVP you can always be on the PVE server and be sure that you are safe from getting attacked by players, however if you like PVP join on in the exciting PVP on the PVP Server!

Negatives:
-UI although simple is not the most easy to use as it is very much work in progress and it does not look pretty

-the game can be very demanding on your system, you need at least a decent cpu and gpu to play the game thus stopping entry level systems from being able to run this game at decent(30 fps and above) frame rates

-No tutorial(there is a good beginners guide by me here though: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DPAlcJFarVY&list=PLXxCN4OQuXYfe8cdzta7S8E0Ku5yNR790&index=1)

Neutral:

-The travel time on the Open World can be a bit excessive however depending on the person, it might be too fast or too slow, I find it personally fine where it is

recommended links:
Naval action wiki: http://navalaction.wikia.com/
Video guides by olav:  https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLXxCN4OQuXYfe8cdzta7S8E0Ku5yNR790

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I loved this game for about a year and a half...until I hated it.  It's a game with a ton of potential, but I'm now confident it'll go unrealised with these devs.
ProsCombat is great - ship combat is very authentic (from what I can imagine) and there's an element of strategy and skill involved
Ship and cannon sounds are done wellConsDevs are stubborn. - Insisting mechanics that the community complains are awful are actually fantastic and the community just doesn't know any better.  Then, months and months later finally changes them.
Devs first Open World game and it shows. - The OW map is really just a lobby you can sail around in (and sail" is used loosely because it's incredibly simplified from the combat instanced version of sailing)
There is often nothing to do in OW - There are some paltry NPC combat missions and it's incredibly boring after doing it once.
Devs are a small team (in the Ukraine) and development takes a long time.
Devs show a lack of maturity and don't take criticism well.
Port battles have no Port in them.....LUL
Ship progression and Overall gameplay mechanics reward arms racing to 1st Rates - therefore battles end up being whichever side has more 1st Rates
Complete lack of content for anything other than aimlessly sailing around picking fights
After being active in the forums over the last year and a half of development
date: I can tell you that the developers have no idea what they are doing when it comes to designing an OW game.  They had a great Arena-style Age of Sail Naval combat game in early closed Alpha.  Then
hoursPlayed: and are really just taking stabs in the dark with regards to gameplay mechanics.  Each time they introduce a new gameplay mechanic it's either incredibly flawed or incredibly boring.\n\nMaybe the game becomes great in another 2 years or so
voteText: but I just don't believe in these developers abilities to make this game interesting.  Sad really

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So heres Naval Action, now you're probably thinking what is this game and how does it play? Well let's cover a few things, first up is open world. Now the Open World is vast, it is the Carribbean and it is geographically accurate to every minute island that is present. Theres multiple ports, for all factions and you can capture ports of other factions. Every port produces goods, uses goods and is either shallow or deep (meaning what ind of ship you can take in). So now lets go into the battles, theyre gorgeous. The sounds, the feel, the waves and sky. Its all gorgeous. The battles take place in instances and whatever happens in the world around your instance also happens there. Theres multiple ship types, gun types, you can get missions from the admiralty (go here and kill this pirate) or you can trade, you can just hunt traders or go after contraband smugglers in your own faction. Now lets go into the bad parts. The forums are a place where nobody can disagree with the fanboys, if you are an American player the admins have something agagainst you, such as suggesting an idea it is usually immediately shot down but when the same admin sees on the Russian forums the same idea they praise it as brilliance. The second one is the grind, it is absolutely asinine in the early stages and just manages to make it worse on the higher levels. You start off with a garbage ship and no money and on average a fight will last you 30-45 mins for 50xp and a bit of gold. Now youre thinking thats not bad, but the amount of XP you need to reach rank 2 is 1000. Thats absolutely ridiculous. The AI is also some kind of super human with everything they do is absolutely perfect such as aiming, sailing, taking NO penalties to loss of crew (usually slows reaction time and steering down a terrible degree). PVP is there and its pretty meh. Unless you plan on doing nothing but dedicating all your time to this game this isn't for you. While the battles, crafting and sounds are fun it is drawn down by terrible AI, awful forums and bad decisions by the forum community who the devs listen to. I would give it a 7/10 however I do recommend it if you arent active in the forums and just want to play.
Edit: Adjusted to 7/10 due to very quick patches and on time updates that are balanced.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First and foremost, this is not a perfect game and if you are looking for a polished game wait before you purchase Naval Action. The developers of Naval Action have been highly influenced in developing their game by Pirates of the Burning Sea which is incredible to me having been a former PotBS player. Naval Action has a modern graphics engine(that looks amazing), but when you play it you get the distinct feel of PotBS minus the avatars. I for one miss what PotBS was and it will always occupy a special place in my gaming experience. So to see a game that is essentially in homage to PotBS is impressive and a must buy in my opinion.

Most importantly and the reason I’m posting here, is the developers of Naval Action have been extremely interactive with the community and open to suggestions. Most of the major game features have been voted on and discussed on the forum extensively with the community. They are not making Naval Action in a vacuum and are using the forum as a sounding board to develop the game that the community wants. Naval Action is clearly being developed as a labor of love by some truly talented people. I’d love to see many people buy Naval Action to add their voices to the community and help make this game everything it should be.

Now while I’m very excited about Naval Action, it does play very slow and is like an age of sail simulator. It  emphasizes developing skills very much like an FPS like aiming individual cannons to hit their targets, adjusting your yardarms manually, and plotting open sea travel. Nonetheless, the potential of Naval Action is enormous and with a little polish it could become an incredible gaming experience.

Lastly, If you think $40 is too expensive for an early access game then I defy you to find another game similar to Naval Action with an active population which is still in development. It is not a cookie cutter game, but a unique experience that is worth every cent of the purchase price.

I’d like to invite you to Naval Action and hope you enjoy the journey as much as I have.

Cheers!

However, I’ve played nothing that is quite like this. Bar, maybe, the sea battles of Sea Dogs. But this categorically leaves Sea Dogs in Davey Jones’s locker along with the rest of the afore mentioned.
I’m not saying those games are bad. That’s not true. I played Cuttroats in the 1990’s for hour upon hour. Hunting for that all but elusive Spanish treasure galleon.
I just loved the fact that you had a PC game and you could do ANYTHING you wanted to do. They are all an open book to be written as you feel fit. Though, some did have a story line that you could follow, if you so desired.
Naval Action is, in my opinion, stunning. The graphics. The ships. You can even build your own ship!! The sea battles. The game play. OK! It may not be for some. I’m sure that some will find it a little tedious to sail from place to place. But I find it tedious that a lot of PC games are just wham

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval action sets a new standard to sailing games. The combination of graphic quality and the determination of the devs is resulting in a incredible Age of Sail experience.  All the images/trailers you see above are ingame footage, the graphics really are incredible. Sail in the Open World and engage in battle instances to see the beauty of this game unfold.

The epicness of the naval combat is beyond words of expression. The thrill of 50-players fighting for their lives, the admirals despirate to hold the formation, the sound of the fire-bell in the distance, the noice of two ships boarding, masts cracking/falling and ships exploding is next level.

You can sail the seas alone or group up with other captains to raid as pirates, or defend the waters of your glorious nation.


~~
Quite some time ago i joined in on the journey of Game Labs to create this game. I have always likes the bond between develloper and player, which has done miracles for this game. Features and systems that are proposed by the community are taken into account by the devs, and vice versa. The result of which is the best of both.

Currently we are at a stage where the game is ready for more players which really increases the livelyness of the Open World. One of the things the 'new player' might be scared by is the placeholder UI (User interface). It saddens me that those players can't look past the current version, therefore miss out on the real beauty of this game.

This game has quite a lot of features, which will take some time to get acuainted with. This, in my eyes, creates a lovely play/learning experience. Once you have mastered the basic sailing, there will nearly always be some tips and tricks that can improve your ability.


Although there is still enough work ahead of us, we are sailing foward at a steady pace, are you willing to join us on the road?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: This review is coming from a former EVE Online player, so my perspective regarding what is and is not a complex game might be somewhat warped. I see another game with a huge amount of potential that could turn into something great -- and in a lot of ways it reminds me of old EVE. I hope Naval Action doesn't squander that potential.

This is not a complex game.

I know, judging from a number of reviews on here, you might assume this is a complicated and convoluted game. It is not. Please do not let these opinions discourage you from trying this game -- It is very close to exceptional.

I can see how some people might be intimidated with how the game appears upon initially starting it up. However, if you stick with it, you'll learn it very quickly. There is also an in-game Help" channel that is quite useful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is like a hardcore version of sid meier's pirates, we have manual sailing available (we can control independently the sails at the front and rear of the ship to take advantage of the wind) , no indicator showing where we are on the map, we have to rely on our compass and landmarks, wind has much effect on the sails, we have to adjust our cannon's angle manually correctly to hit at the right distance, take into consideration how the ship is swaying due to the waves and also waves can stop our shots.
Hitting a ship trying to flee at long range is a bit of a challenge when we are new but it feels very rewarding when we finally manage to place that shot.
Ships can be capsized and the game world is huge.
I also like that we don't have some weird magical abilities like in many games with naval battles.
Trading and crafting are in game at the moment but they need more content and polishing I think.
And finally the ships look gorgeous. I want to experience and hopefully own every one of those beautiful ships.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have had the pleasure and sometimes the pain, yes pain, of playing Naval Action through the original battle sim on to the launch of the open world.

Visually the devs have done amazing work. As you sail around the detail astounds you.  You need a nice graphics card and machine to truly enjoy it.  Last night I noticed that the shallows near islands had become sand beaches and rocky shoals.   Another upgrade to the whole visual aspect of the game.   Watch some of the videos.

There are a few negative reviews regarding the grind and the time it takes to sail from place to place.  Also about nothing being fast and taking too long to complete.

Have you ever sailed in a yacht on a sunny day? You really do not get anywhere fast.

Real life age of sail battle could take all day to resolve if they even were resolved.  In Naval Action you could be in a battle well over an hour  and then sink if you can't escape a losing battle.  It is the age of sail after all.

If you want instant gratification and super powerful ships the moment you buy and join the game then you might as well go elsewhere.   You need to earn your place on the seas and there is a lot of help for you to get where you need to be to have fun in larger ships and sail with skill.

The initial grind can be very frustrating but everyone in the game has to do it. There are legal in game ways to make it a bit faster but as you get better it goes faster and you gain a larger crew which allows you to sail larger ships and gives you more options as to how you want to interact.

Some trade mostly and build ships. Others constantly organize port battles and manage the wars against enemies. Several like to backstab fellow pirates and pay the price.

The world is in flux. Ports change hands, Power bases grow and shrink and ships get lost.

We all have lost our best ships in a battle but live to fight again.

If you want to join a game still being improved (and sometimes in ways we might not all like being tested), still growing  with a good base of skilled people in all of the nations from all over the world, then give it a try.

I have played in free" games and pay games where bots have taken over the game and completely ruined them.  This game depends on your skill and your clan and country's ability to hold important ports for supplies and staging and not on some computer bot working against you.

Join the grind
date: join the community and enjoy the game.   There is nothing more enjoyable than after an hour or more of tough battle with cannons firing
recommended: smoke wafting across the water and hearing your crew cheer when the dreaded enemy loses a mast and then you sink or board the ship and seize it!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the time of this review i had put 100 hours into his game in 1 week after launch on steam. Its's a damn good game and certainly has the potential to be a very good MMO.  Let me start with the positives of this game, Keep in mind this is still in alpha.

1. PvP is great. Battles can go on for 1 hour 30min, however, they dont feel like that at all. machanics are all there and keeps you intrested in the battle all the way to the end. Oh, fleet size pvp can get as big as 25 vs 25.

2. Visuals are also very good, swaying over the waves as you try aiming at other countrys ships to sink it. priceless.

3. Port Battles. Allthough port battles are still in develpment atm its still a joy to join up with other people from your selected nation to go capture ports from your enemys.

4. A good selection of nations to pick from.

5. Arr, matey, thar be ye booty!  (Be a Pirate)

6. Crafting. Its still in its infancy but there is enough there atm to keep you preoccupied, although it still needs alot of work done to it.

7. Board and raid other ships. destroy enemy sails with 'chain shot' then whittle down the enemy crew with 'Grape' board the ship than take the loot and ship as a prize.


Now some stuff that is in the Gray zone, this stuff is a good idea but still needs alot of work in my eyes:

1. The economy. As it stands at the point of writing this review in a alpha build, the economy is broken. There are some people that have got a monopoly on some of the goods and its very hard to get hold of some of the 'goods' to build ships. so the prices of ship building are very high and you will most likely loose any sort of profit. That said i have heard that its ok on other servers but some of the ship crafting needs to be tweeked to balance things.

2. 'Durabilty'. On ships you get something called durabilty. These are effectually your lives. rate 7-5 ships have 5 dura (lifes) then rate 4-1 ships you get one less life per rate.  For me personally i would like to only see 1 life per ship but alot of people will disagree with me.

3. Small ships are pretty useless and are used as a 'stepping stone' to get the next Rate ship. I would like to find a way so small ships are used later on in game.

4. The map/ Open sea, Its well big. it fits in well with the game and how its done. you have to work out what direction to sail from your compuss and it can & will take hours to get to where you want to go. Its how it should be, however, its a bit boring for the eye. I do believe that they are planning to add things like storms and damage to your ships, etc... this will make it alot more dynamic

Now to the bad things in this current Alpha build:

1. UI is crap! its only a few blue boxes with text.

2. Its very hard to just pick up the game and start playing it if your new, There is nothing to help you apart from the ingame chat.

3. Missions are extremely repetitive yet they are one of the best ways to get exp and money.

4. Feel the grind! The first few days i thought that the exp gain was to fast, however, that changed once i got rank 1st Lt. It takes bloody ages to grind exp and it really is quite painful.

5. Current lack of content. There really isnt much in the game atm, howevewr, it is only alpha and i do know some very exciting things are going to be added and alot of rebalancing is going to happen.

6. Trading is still very poor. This will get better over time but as it stands there really is not much point as it takes along time to get to port to port.

This is what i have made of the game so far from me playing it. For an Alpha stage game it really is solid and well done. If you can keep in mind that its Alpha then alot of the bugs/ balancing issues/ lack of content can be forgiven. there are somethings that i personally need to be changed but everyone is differant.
I would suggest you watch a few streams of gameplay and ask lots of questions before buying it, i did, this will give you a better idea if you would like the game or not.

one of the best buys i have done for awhile, My £30 was worth every penny.
For an Alpha i give it a   ---- 9/10 ----

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a perfect example of why Steam needs a 'Neutral' voting option

Tour your ship on foot, go to your quarters to examine maps and charts, go down to cargo hold to look at the cool stuff you've collected. Attend a pirate conclave with other Captains in a secret meeting place. Go to your nation's capital and walk to your Admiral's office for your next orders. Stroll around the marketplace to examine the wares and find something that strikes your fancy as you wait for your next load of cargo. Go to the shipyard and see your next ship under construction as smiths pour the molds for your bigger, better cannons. Take part in a Mount and Blade style boarding action, ,culminating in a one on one duel with the enemy captain.

All these features that would give the game much-needed extra layers of depth will never happen, as confirmed by the devs.

The game, as it stands, is playable but all except the hardest of hardcore will lose interest. The ship models are gorgeous, and the battles themselves are very fun and nerve wracking at times, but the game itself is a grindfest. Fight, level, get a bigger ship, repeat. Over and over and over. Sail for hours and hours in real time, hoping the wind will hold course long enough for you to get into port.

I *want* to love this game,  but I can't.  Not for the price,  and not for the amount of content.  It seems like it's more of a proof-of-concept for what should be one mechanic of a much bigger game, and it really seems from what the devs have been saying that we'll never get that 'bigger game'. If it were $10 I would call it a must own. For now I'm going to give it a few  months and see where the concept has gone. I believe Assassin's Creed has shown that a market exists for Age of Sail games, and a AAA studio could take the core of Naval Action and make the best damn game you've ever played.

Edited to include a point I made under the comments. Thanks for the up votes everyone!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a lot of potential for the gamers that like time sinks. There is no such thing as hoping on and doing a quick mission or pvp battle. To accomplish anything meaniful you need to set aside at least 3-4 hours per session.

The OW sailing combined with the rapid change of wind make it painful to get anywhere. Its a whole lot of hurry up and wait and wait some more. The game isn't difficult and the pvp is fun and does require some skill and situational awareness.

This is not the game for you if:
1) You dont have a lot of time to play
2) You are looking for fast action
3) You are looking for a story line based game


This is a game for you if:
1) You like sandbox games
2)Skill based pvp
3)Slow action
4)Spending lots of time getting from one place to another with absolutely nothing else to do but afk sail and talk in chats

Overall I started out really enjoying the game because it was fresh and something totally different. But after a month of playing I have decided to uninstall this game.

Game is still in Alpha and it is worth your time. money and support for this amazing game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impression! Review will be adapted during the game's EA development process

Someone still remembering the age-old title Age of Sail? I loved that title for it's atmosphere and approach to realistic sailing and shooting mechanics.

In many aspects, Naval Action seems to be a worthy successor.

Ship handling is difficult and demanding, but incredibly rewarding when you finally get the hang on it (I certainly have no arrived at that point. Still missing broadsides at point blank.) It feels very immersive, too.

Now add a pinch of Pirates! to the lot and mix it with classical MMO features:

Naval action circles around PvE and PvP (there is a PvE only server, too) sea battles in an open world sandbox (yes, that time of the year again).
Choose a faction to side with and gain ranks and riches by doing missions, privateering, trading and, well: naval action. Grind your rank from petty midshipman all the way up to rear admiral while sailing the infamous caribbean waters.

Be aware there is only a very, very basic and GODDAMMN ugly, but functional UI and port interface present at the moment (place holder)!

The AI is decent but not stunningly smart. It benefits from cheating and bonuses, too. Still lots of room for improvement here.

As to be expected you can find balancing issues, bugs and glitches but so far I did not discover a game-braking one. Remember: Early Access.

If you were disappointed by gamey ship handling in Empire: Total War but loved it's graphics and atmosphere, Naval Action will interest you. If you're willing to look beyond the Early Access issue and the heavy Elite:Dangerous style rank grind, which still feels dull and pretty unrewarding.

If you ever wanted to be Jack Aubrey, Mr. Hornblower, Arr! Blackbeard or Surcouf, this is your chance. Don't forget to have a looped volley of shanties running on your music player, though.

The Looks and Sounds

Sailing ships roll and pitch in the seas in all their detailed, glorious splendour. Mighty Ship-of-the-Lines exchanging rolling broadsides under a waning moon, their dim stern lanterns lit while the whole sea is enlightened by muzzle flahes just to be swallowed by dense gun powder clouds again.

Listening to the creaking sound of ships rolling in heavy waves and the impressive thunder of firing 32 pounders is impressive.

Ah, the ocean! It's colour sheme and rolling wave's look even more realistic and impressive than in World of Warships, and that ocean already looks stunning.

Spotting a lone sail or traces of a slowly growing landmass on the fog-shaded horizon amidst the sheer endless, foaming sea really succeeded in immersing me right into the game.

I've exclusively playing PvE until now- so I can't give a verdict about the PvP servers or the state of PvP in general.

As of update 9.7 there have been many additions to PvE content like gargantuan AI fleets, AI can sail all ship types, a stronger, very challenging AI opponent (as of update 9.73 made easier for lower skill levels), land-in battles (meaning the battle terrain will reflect the open world terrain).

The only thing that needs to be added for atmosphere are decent music (and by the way, those STUPID COMMENTS ON THE LOADING SCREENS NEED TO GO! They are not even close to be funny.) and more modelled sailors. Right now you've only got one sailor manning a gun each, the helm is unmanned and no one cares to deal with sails. Which looks kinda silly! Albeit the sailors models themselves are well done and the textures detailed.

On Crafting

Building ships can be a pain. It all comes down to the hunt for blue prints enabling you to buildship type when consuming the blue print item.
Blue prints do have a random drop chance while producing a certain ship type:
e.g. building a St. Pavel 2nd Rate Ship-of-the-Line might give you a blue print drop for a 1st rate Victory.

As chance RNG is involved you may have to build several ships of a type to cimb up the blue print ladder. This can be frustrating. But as of patch 9.6 the chances for drops have been altered so there is a very decent drop chance by now. I have all the blueprints by now and don't even have the highest crafting rank- chances are influenced by your level relative to the BP level you are trying to get and the quality of the shiup you were building- the higher the better)

Crafting is also affected by your crafting XP level. You get XP for building ships, modules, components and thus level up until you reach level 50 enabling you to build the mightiest 1st rates in exceptional quality and the best modules (that can be placed as ship components making them better), too.

Crafting also requires ressources (surprise, isn't it? :P), which are consumed by producing ship parts. These parts are then used in the building process. Eg. Oak---> X planks--->X planks needed to build ship Y.

For the very crafting process you also consume labour hours that replenish over time. As they are also used for extracting ressources from production buildings, buildiong modules or components they are the rarest good. You'll have to be careful on what to spend them if you want to climb the XP ladder / built ships most effective. E.g. you'll have to amass the labour hours worth of two real life days to build a single Santissima Trinidad- without all the components needed!


Feel free to ask me questions in-game, my Naval Action char is named Agamemmnon" (sic! don't mind the stupid added "m"
recommended: Admiral Nelson) mostly playing on PvE 1."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I started playing Naval Action about a year ago. When I bought it, you could only play something called Sea Trails, which was only combat and no open world. I got a bit tired of the wipes, so I didn't play that much. That didn’t mean I disliked it, though. Naval Action does in fact beat all the games I've played about warships from the age of sail. I think it beats Assassin's Creed: Black Flag and Pirates of the Caribbean Online by a long shot, even though I played the crap out of them. That was true even a year ago, when the ship vs. ship action wasn't as good as it is now and there was no open world.

The visuals are amazing, too. Stern lights and the day and night cycle gives a really good atmosphere. When in combat, the muzzle flashes of cannons going off as well as the gunpowder smoke looks better than in any other similar game.
I have most graphic options on the lowest, but the game still looks amazing.

Naval Action already have a lot of different vessels ranging from fast 8 cannon sail ships to giant first rate ships of the line with up to 138 cannons and three gun decks (four if you include the weather deck).
If you have played World of Warships, you will recognize certain elements when it comes to shooting. For instance, you can shoot individual shots to make sure the full broadside will hit. It is, however, more difficult and in my opinion better than in WoWs.
Wind is an important aspect in NA, as all ships are using sails. Tacking against the wind can be hard for newcomers, but there are good tutorials out there that cover this.

Open world is something I haven’t really played that much, but I do like it. You can choose between the British, French, Spanish, Swedish, Danish-Norwegian, Dutch, United States navies as well as Pirates. You become a Pirate automatically when attacking ships from your own navy. The whole crafting and trading system may seem a little overwhelming to some, but it is something that should be learnt quite easily. Off course, there are tutorials for that too.
Ships can be crafted, and players can set ships for sale at a price they choose themselves. You can, for example, sell a cutter (The first ship you get) for 100.000 gold, but nobody will buy it as they can get it for free in the store. Also, each ship have 5 durability, which means that if it sinks 5 times it is gone forever. You can buy repair kits, but in combat you can only use one. That means that you will often find yourself running away if you’ve ended up in a bad situation.

Apart from from the placeholder UI, the only thing I dislike about the game is that after you buy it, there’s no way to continue supporting it through the game itself.
The game is not for people who are just looking for a relaxed and forgiving MMO experience, but if you're interested in warship games I can almost guarantee that you'll like it.
There is more to this game than just what I've mentioned, and I might add to this review when I've played some more.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hi,

I've got a ton of hours playing this game for over a year in closed alpha.  I can tell you the graphics are beautiful, the gameplay is really fun, the community is great, and this game really fills the huge empty gap that is currently missing for Open World Age of Sail games.

The OW is huge and It takes probably 20+ hours to sail across the Carribean in this game.  There is trading, crafting, ship building, port battles, storms, varying weather, day night cycle, several factions and free towns, realistic phyics, historical ships, large fleet battles, conquest mechanics...pretty much everything you would want in a realistic Age of Sail game.  For the combat, this game is more on the realism and hardcore, skill based side, easy to pick up hard to master, having to learn things like yard controls with tacking and boxhauling maneuvers.

Please note the devs have been rapidly releasing new features and there is not a lot of what I would call 'polish' to the game yet.  The UI is pretty barebones and some gameplay is not yet fully fleshed out.  The good news is their servers have been rock solid so far, no disconnects or anything.

If you are an avid PvPer you will love this game.  If you love large battles you will love this game.  Hell even if you only want PvE they got that covered too.  Buy this game as their won't see many like it in this genre.

Definitely a PotBS killer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Set in the Age of Sail you will captain your ship through the entire Caribbean in search of either the riches of the land or the blood of the enemy. You are able to rank up to command some of the biggest ships out there, like the 1st Rate HMS Victory, or build up your trading and crafting endeavours and rake in the big money.

There are a whole bunch of nations to choose from (United States, Denmark/Norway, Sweden, British Empire, France, Dutch Republic of the United Provinces, Spain and the outlaw Pirates), ranging in various difficulties depending on how many islands they start out with and their diplomatic capabilities. You can log onto a server (PvP or Player versus Player) where many of the ports can be conquered by other players of other nations and players of the different nations can fight it out in the Caribbean waters with each other as well, or you can choose to take it easy and sail around on the PvE (Player versus Environment) server where those things are disabled. Rank progression is shared among the two, money and assets aren't.

Even at this early stage the tropical world you sail in looks gorgeous and the action when battling looks breathtaking. That being said, it's not a game for the people that are impatient and with a short attention span. If you intend on exploring the Caribbean you can easily spend 30 to 60 minutes sailing without anything in sight but open sea before reaching land again. But it's worth picking up for those who played Empire: Total War for the ships and possibly familiar with Pirates of the Burning Sea.

[21/01/2016 Early Access Launch]
Mind you that this is a very early alpha build. There's no tutorial yet, neither any pointers, hints or tips, and UI is minimal yet functional and not all planned features are in the game yet. For the best experience it is recommended to find like-minded players through chat, on the forums or better yet join them on TeamSpeak. Many of the seasoned players, many who were able to play for more than a year, are more than happy to help answering all of your questions. If you want to play this rather for yourself on the PvE server, expect a steep learning curve.

reviewText:

I've owned this game for nearly a year now, and since then, the game has improved dramatically. When I first started there was no open world, only a battle arena. This was fantastic because it allowed the developers to test combat mechanics. Since then, they've implimented the Open World, basic economy and crafting, a new damage model, and a ton of new ships.

The game is fairly niche, and it does have a steep learning curve when it comes to combat, but don't let that hold you back. The graphics are incredible, the sound effects are stunning, and the ships are majectic. The developers have been fantastic thus far; they have been very open to change and discussion, as well as listening to the opinions and suggestions of members of the community.

Naval Action has been absolutely fantastic, and I have nothing but kind words to say about it. Now remember, it is an Early Access game, so there are bugs, and there are things that aren't as pretty or refined as they could be. There isn't an Official" tutorial

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fantastic sailing sim set in the 1800's. Get lost in both the immersive world and at sea because you don't remember where that mission was!
This game offers a lot despite it's Early Access status. You can:
1. Sail around the Southern US, Carribbean, parts of South America, and more.
2. Join the world renowned navies of the 1800's, such as the British, French, Spanish, Pirates and more.
3. Join PvP or PvE servers depending on your preferences.
4. Get lost at sea for half a month and hope that you'll find some sort of land.
5. Trade between many different cities and ports, and be chased mercilessly by pirates.

Overall, it's a fantastic game with great mechanics and physics. It's very easy to sink some time into.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval Action has supprised me. Although still early in it's development, the game provides an immersive experiance that replicates the neccessity of quick thinking and adaptation to circumstance that pervades naval combat. The ocean is a 'living' being adding chaos to even the most well thought out and well timed turn to broadside the enemy. This chaos complements the commitment combat entails. This is not another simple a random number generator, HP driven fight with boats. This is more a physical recreation of a universe with accurately modelled physics. Combat is not resolved in seconds, nor even minutes. My first duel in the game lasted roughly 15 minutes, on the edge of my seat, hoping for some turn of advantage that would yield me the weather gage (naval advantage) and allow me to force victory.

If you want a deeper naval warfare simulation then get this. If you want another arcade game that yields you easily exploited mechanics and detracts from the naval history of the Age of sail, look elsewhere.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I come from playing tons of the old Pirates of the Carribean community mod and tons of hours in Pirates of the Burning Sea. Naval action really brings back memories of the hay day of POTBS.

The game currently is not complete but the core gameplay is solid. Ship to ship combat is amazing, not too hard to get into but very hard to master. The feel in this game is great, really lets you get immersed into it.

There is currently a progression system implemented that as you do PVE missions you gain ranks within your chosen navy. You can however sail any ship you like, what limits you however is the higher rank you are the more sailors you can hire. I really love the way this inserts progression in an unobtrusive way whilst keeping the theme.

The graphics are pretty solid right now with improvements on performance coming with updates all the time. It currently runs pretty well on medium and up spec systems.

The only real criticism currently is that there is no tutorial currently you are just dropped into the open world. If you buy this game head over to YouTube and look up some guides otherwise you will be kinda lost.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval Action is a gorgeous game with a lot of potential, some of it front and center and already realised.

The game is an interesting mix of gameplay styles. The ship to ship combat is streamlined but deep. Requiring you to not only use the wind to your advantage, but also the waves of the ocean itself. You must navigate successfully, and command your crew to prioritize tasks onboard. All of this culiminating in an epic and tense battle, with the thunder of cannons and smoke filling the air.

The gameplay itself harkens back to Pirates! as well as elements that remind me of EVE (massive map, crafting and trading).

Players choose a nation to start with, which will determine your starting location (U.S, U.K, Dutch, Sweden, Spain, Denmark & Pirates). Each nation has unique challenges based upon number of ports and geographical location. Interestingly enough I jumped on the French side, and lo-and-behold, most of the players were speaking French!

Once you start in your home port you can grab missions from the admiralty and head out to the open sea (which is an absolutely massive map of the Caribbean). Once in open sea you can engage battles that are under way, other players (if you're on a PvP server) or head towards your mission objectives.

Eventually you gain gold, experience and promotions. Allowing you to build, buy, or capture better ships.

PRO:
- Fantastic looking
- Authentic Historical ships
- Immersive weather and large map
- Crafting (seems decent so far)
- Tactically deep
- Map does not show where you are, requiring you to use visual markers and a compass (I think this could be a PRO or CON)

CON:
- UI is a bit rough at the moment but is fairly functional
- No tutorial on gunnery, crafting or trading
- Somewhat steep learning curve
- Map does not show where you are, requiring you to use visual markers and a compass (I think this could be a PRO or CON)

All in all, the UI is rough but the gameplay is solid. I was extremely skeptical of this title heading in, but after logging a few hours today I can safely say this game is already very fun and once it gets polished and more ships added in, it will be very very good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reviewing an early release is notoriously hard, the game is still in development and who knows where it is going to go. But Naval Action, while still an Alpha, is shockingly playable for a game so early in its development.

Game play is rather unique, and by unique I mean SLOW. Combat is slow, travel in the overworld is slow, crafting is slow, and that slowness is probably one of the greatest points of this game. If you are a fan of most modern games MMO or otherwise this slowness can be a schock. This is not Call Of Duty, or War Thunder. Naval Action is more a game of chess than a game of whack a mole. You plan your attack, you turn a few points off the wind and you wait for the enemy to roll into your broadside. A single ship to ship combat can take up to half an hour, a multi ship battle can take over an hour. Travel in the overworld takes planning and time, a trade route may take you hours of real time to travel. Nothing happens fast and in this quick twitch game heavy world the stately if slow action in Naval Action is a welcome change.

Factions are a fact of life in Naval Action, there are no independent ships. You will have to join a faction in character creation but that does not mean Kill On Sight for every other faction; French Privateers will peacefully cruise past Spanish ships of the line in neutral waters, but you do need to watch your back. Just because you don’t attack does not mean you will not be attacked.

Overall this is a pleasing game, but you do have to set some time aside to play a good session. I for one look forward to the further development of Naval Action, it has a lot of great potential.

Beautiful Age of Sail Game, rich with historical flavor. I have enjoyed my time with game and have become quite addicted...this game will appeal to a more mature audience who have an appreciation for the period...folks with gamer ADHD should avoid this title...it will not hold your interest....

Pros:
Realistic Combat Model
Beautiful Graphics
Runs well on mediocre machines
Mature Player Base
Well Done Crafting System
Easy to learn but hard to master
Both PvE and PvP content
Large variety of ships to choose from'
Lots of customization features (not graphical though, more mechanical (ie, upgrades))
Rewarding sense of acievement
Addicting to the right kind of player

Cons:

Game requires patience

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Believe the hype.

Naval Action offers a borderline simulator experience with its age-of-sail combat gameplay. Take command of anything from a simple schooner to powerful Ships-of-the-Line. Travers a massive map of the Caribbean and experience beutiful sights and sounds of the Age-of-Sail.

In-depth naval combat mechanics means you control your yards and aim your cannons all while attempting to manuever and dodge gunfire yourself. Mistime or aim incorrectly and watch your broadside fly over the enemy's deck or hit the sides of a wave insted of the enemy's hull. Misuse your sails and you'll find yourself face-first to the wind and unable to move, am easy sitting target for your enemies.

This is NOT a pirate game. This is an Age-of-Sail game. While pirates are a playabe option, they are by no means easy to master. The game offres a challenge while still being fun. As is expected with Early Access, there are still a bit of impurities and imbalance, but even so, the combat system alone is very well honed and can offer some interesting yet not altogether lopsided battles.

This is a must for anyone who is interested in the Age of Sail.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My review - From my experience in the early alpha
First of all i wish to state that the community of the game has been amazing and the developers have been listening very well to us. I have been following this game ever since early 2014 and it's grown to a very enjoyable game.

PLEASE NOTE: This game is not made for the impatient
The game requires atleast a decent interest in ship combat and sailing, you need to navigate yourself, the combat is made realistically. It is not an arcade, note that if you just want to kill, kill, kill this game won't be a good game for you.

First of all, the graphics look fantastic. Probably the best looking game I've ever seen in the Unity engine. The Open world currently does look a little worse than the battles, but this is understandable for performance reasons. The game runs decently, haven't had any issues to achieve a solid 60FPS. Yet the dev's stated they would improve performance in the future so no worries about that.

The ships are beautiful and detailed, just look up the trincomalee in the game, and irl. It looks identical. Honestly amazing how detailed the ships have become. I hope to see more crew on deck in the future. More activites there would be nice.

The sound design is AMAZING, it sounds like you are actually in an 18th century sea battle, the smoke really adds to the battles aswell. Couldn't be more perfect.

Overall the battles feel very complete already, it is the open world which does require a bit of work. Of course, the UI can be confusing at first, and it does not look the greatest. It is not the priority, and we understand this. The UI is something to improve on definitely. Another negative thing about the game is that there is currently no tutorial. So finding out what to do can be a bit tricky at first. So please use the help chat in game, someone almost instantly helps you on there.

The open world is a WIP and that is clearly visible, and this is most likely where the developers will focus on in Early Acces, so you will mostly see that progress.

Overall, I bought the game on a Thursday and within a week I had played over 100 hours. A recommendation for sure, dedicated dev's, good communication with the community. Best Naval game out there right now!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have bought the game back in November/December 2014. I liked the period, but was a bit sceptical, especially when combined with a paypal payment method and was just willing to try it.

How much was I mistaken. It is my most played game on steam right now. I did hunt AI ships alone. I did chase player ships off the perceived turf with a group. For a time I was the one of lucky few, who were able to build HMS Surprise. I did successfully trade iron, when there was almost none left in the whole carribean. I went to the edge of the world. I met people that were nice and crude, honorable and dishonorable, dauntless captains as well as cowards. Does this appeal to you? If yes, this game might be just for you.

HOWEVER, you have to be willing to overlook some substantial flaws, at least for a time. Terrible UI. No help, if you don't search for it/ask. You have to be willing to accept behavioural standards of the community (courteous, gentlemenly). You have to be willing to learn. You have to be able to think of the battles as battles, not as the grind.

2nd HOWEVER, you get an opportunity to participate in the development of the game you have been waiting for for the last 10-15 years, due to the great devs, who really listen. (I can pinpoint some features that are in the game to originate with specific players and specific posts on the forums).

I will not tell you if the game is right for you. For me, best 40 EUR I spend on a game. For an early access title 9/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While the game is the only show in town if you want a realistic Age of Sail game I have sadly withdrawn my recommendation. After many, MANY hours of testing since the early days of closed testing, much of the potential never went anywhere. Good combat mechanics will only tide me over for so long. The rest of the game is nowhere near up to snuff.

The PvP port battles are a repetitive time consuming chore and there is no meaningful PvE.
Worst of all, the balance is out the window, allowing bigger nations to utterly crush smallernations without any hinderance.
This is a flaw exacerbated by the clear favouritism towards the pirates who get several mechanics that clearly favour them, including that every other player can easily switch to pirates but not to another nation. As a result the pirates are merrily steamrolling everyone as many in other nations give up in frustration while pirates grow ever stronger.

The result is that there is barely any age of sail experience to be had here. It is gank or be ganked. Which gets old.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf there was ever a game with so much potential, it'd be Naval Action.  By far and away the best sailing experience you will get out of a computer game. The finer parts of what the Devs have accomplished thus far would certainly be the optimization and multiplayer integration. Both of these two key features make the game a pleasure to play both alone and with others. The ship combat is amazing, firing a broadside into an enemy ship's hull is one of the most satisfying things in the game. The sound of the cannons is perfect and you can hear them roll out across the water like they should. The ships themselves are marvelous to look at and the scenery around them is wonderful. The only gripes I have with the game are the boarding experience is a bit lacking at the moment and the UI is underwhelming however the Devs have stated that it is only temporary. The game overall is wonderful to play and I would highly recommend the game if you are into the age of sail.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing Naval action for a bit now. I'd like to say that I could endorse this pretty looking game but I can't.

There are quite a few unsavory elements to the game. And here's a few.

1. Unrealistic and overpowered AI.

The NPC ships in the game routinely break nearly EVERY sailing rule of physics in the book, maneuvering like hydrofoils even in a headwind. And if THAT isn't bad enough, their gunnery puts even present day warships with their guided missiles to shame with a near 90% hit rate even at extreme range with maybe 2 out of every 3 hits landing criticals. Also they seem to have a higher rate of fire than most players.

The devs DID recently reduce the AI accuracy on small ships such as cutters and brigs hoping that less experienced players won't notice that all frigates and SoTLs still have the sniper elite" level AI and dance around like fairies.

2. Toxic and hostile player community.

The game is supposed in alpha stage
date: which means that people playing the game are supposed to be providing feedback and making suggestions. However the player community will usually try to shout down player suggestions
hoursPlayed: and attempt to derail the suggestion thread by leading it off topic into wild and immature tangents. They also seem to celebrate on the forums when frustrated players announce their intention to leave <like good riddance or don't let the door hit you in the *** on the way out
voteText:
etc>.

3. Devs alienate PvE and Independent players.

With only a single PvE server and no access to alt characters if you want to experience something new
helpfulPercent: for example playing another nation or just plain want to play a new character they give you only 2 options either completely delete your old character and make an entirely new one sacrificing all your gold
votesHelpful: ships
votesTotal:
crafting resources and all that even though you still retain both your rank and crafting xp or be forced onto a PvP server where only 3 of their 7 or 8 playable nations are even viable and where ganking and griefing runs rampant.

They claim that this is designed to prevent economic exploitation but that kind of exploitation already exists in the game in the form of the current guild activity.

4. They are setting the stage for total disaster for the game economy and solo playability with their future economic goals.

In their most recent patch they did away with player ability to sail captured warships. Instead players now have to auto turn in warships they have captured in boarding combat over to their respective nation's admiralties for a tiny sum of gold and only allowing players to commandeer merchant ships. They also have future plans to completely do away with NPC resource vendors and allowing players to have the complete run of the economy. This action coupled with the canned ability to sail captured warships will inevitably open the door to massive overpricing of ships
votesFunny:
and other items and make it impossible for any independent player to survive and be competitive.

It's like Pirates of the Burning Sea all over again.....Perhaps even worse.

At least portalus games has since begun to offer means of solo player survivability (if only to line their own pockets with real-world cash).

With this all said I can not in good conscience recommend this game to anyone."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good! But Slow.

I'm not opposed to a 'grind' in a MMO.  I like when games make you work for it, and you have something  to strive for.  This game does that well when it comes to ships, and levels.

What I mean by slow, is the combat itself.  Sure you can destroy a small ship with a large ship with ease, but when it takes 20 minutes for a group of players to kill one large ship, it's just silly, and feels like a big waste of time.  The biggest pain point is that when you destroy a side of a ship, it WILL sink.  There is nothing they, or you can do about it.  You can slow the death by going into survival mode, but death is inevitable.  So my question is. WHY NOT JUST SINK ALREADY!
You cannot accelerate the sinking any faster.  If the armor is down on the ship, and you keep hitting the ship, it doesn't matter at all.  Just pound away for 3 minutes and the inevitable happens, or just turn sail and ride away and wait for it to sink.  JUST SINK, EXPLODE, DIE!

The combat is good.  High skill based shooting, and strategy.  I've been playing solo, so it's not been nearly as fun as it would be with friends, like most games.  I do see a lack of end game in the current state of the game.  You pretty much progress in ships and xp for it's own sake.  The only end game I see is either just disrupting other countries with groups of players killing them, or taking ports, which is difficult, but relatively boring.

Players of POTBS or BBO will see a lot of resemblence in this game, although this game seems more shallow, with less to do.  The boarding function is clicking what you want to do, not actually doing it.  No 'adventure' type thing.  No land based gameplay at all. (granted that was pretty lame in POTBS but it did add depth. Land combat which was boarding combat, farming, gathering ect.)

Community is solid enough.  Lots of questions get answered pretty quickly, and you will have LOTS of questions your first week.  I'd definitely reccommend it if you are playing with friends, and hopefully the devs will come out with some more engaging things in the future, rather than running boring/slow missions, and fighting fleets for the sake of fighting fleets.  PvP is good, and fun, but also rather meaningless unless you go out and hunt players which will not be worth any kind of reward for the most part.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is still in early development as of 1/19/2016. I've played this game before it was on Steam, for many hundreds of hours.

The game itself, is an open world game based in the Gulf of Mexico/Bahama's. East coast of America, Mexico, all the islands of the bahama's, and Jamaica, and East coast of South America.

Travel:

The travel in this game does take awhile. It's a HUGE map, however you don't NEED to travel great distances if you don't want too either.

Immersion and Combat:

The immersion in this game is very real, and realistic. Distance of the shot, the size of the cannon, the thickness and even type of wood the opponents ship is, the angle your ball hits, the velocity, all of this takes into account whether your ball penetrates, and even how it interacts INSIDE the opponents ship. That's right, a cannon ball can continue to bounce around a few times inside the ship, or blast out the opposite end.

Waves and wind will affect your shot quite considerably in smaller vessels, and if you're fighting in a storm, your ship will bob left, right, up and down affecting your shot as well. Your cannon can only aim up, down, left and right to only a certain degree.

You can board and capture enemy vessels, sink them, break them down for component parts to make your own ship, or sell captured ships.

Port Battles:

Port Battles is also a thing, attacking enemy ports or defending your own, complete with defensive towers and the works. If the attacker is the victor, they take permenant control of that port, or at least until you capture it back.

Your Choice:
How you play is entirely up to you, and what you do. You also do not have to grind through the tiers". Small

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, this is an early access game. I realize the price is steep for an early access game, but this is quite simply one of the most fun games I've probably ever played, both in the open world MMO genre and in general. I've easily gotten more enjoyment out of it than the last $30-$40 full release titles I've purchased, and the hours speak for themselves.

The Awesome:
1. Combat is absolutely amazing. It plays somewhat like a chess match, in both large fleet actions and single ship actions. Each side makes a move, to which the other side attempts to counter. In a large battle, this mainly comes down to your side's shot caller attempting to give as many of his ships as possible a shot on the opposing fleet. In single ship fights, much of  the skill comes down to maneuvering to rake your opponent's stern to kill crew and dismount cannon until he can no longer fight, while preventing him from doing the same.  The combat is definitely the most polished part of the game, and it shows.

2. Development: I say this mainly because the game already is in development, but I've seen very few games capable of treading the thin line between giving the players what they want, and doing what's best for the players and the game as a whole. These devs have done an amazing job on this, and many player suggestions throughout closed alpha and even early Steam release have found their way into the game. In addition, the development cycle is very regular, with a major content patch around the middle of each month, along with usually 2 ships added to the game. In addition, the devs have added multiple player-made ships to the game.

3. The Open World map: This is probably the most important part of the game. The open world map is a scale representation of the Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico, based off of maps from the time period of the game (early 1800s-late 1700s). This is how you get from port to port and find other players to sail or fight with. When engaging other players, your position relative to them and both of your positions in relation to the wind translates directly into the battle instance, making positioning in the OW almost as important as actual combat skill. A recent update now translates any land you may be nearby into the battle as well, meaning cunning captains can pin smaller and nimbler ships against land when they would otherwise be able to sail away unscathed. In addition to that, major fleet AI battles can be found quite easily in the open world as well (but make sure you bring friends).

The Not So Awesome (outdated, see EDIT):
1. Finding a fight: One of the biggest complaints is the difficulty of finding a fight in the open world. This can be a challenge, but it does depend primarily on where you are trying to find fights. Generally, the closer to Cuba/Jamaica you are, the better the change of finding a fight (this primarily concerns the PVP1 server). Free Ports (uncapturable by any faction) allow you to base ships closer to these areas to get into the action quicker. In addition, duels can be set up in the port screen (just ask around in national or local chat for a dueling partner, and remember your ships must be the same battle rating to duel), which gives a loss-free way to practice handling your ship before jumping into real danger in the open world.

2. Game Economy/Crafting: This is probably the least polished portion of the game, meaning everything I say here is subject to change. The economy is inbetween a full player driven economy and an AI driven economy. Money can be made quite easily by your production buildings, and those resources in turn supply the shipbuilders. Ships require resources to build if you want an above average one, otherwise basic versions with a minor flaw or minor improvement (to speed, crew space, rigging, etc.) can be bought for very affordable prices from the AI. AI only sells up to 4th rate 60 gun ships however, anything larger must be built by a crafter or captured from another player. If your objective in buying the game is to become a major crafter/trader and nothing else, you may want to wait for this feature to mature before purchasing.

3. The Grind": You'll find many reviews that complain about the game's grind. At the end of the day
date: the game is only a grind if you make it one. Unlike War Thunder
hoursPlayed: or other arena games where you are forced to play a vehicle  to unlock the next
voteText: the only limiting factor in Naval Action is the crew you can command. You start with 40
helpfulPercent: and this increases as you go through the ranks. You can still purchase any ship on the market if you have the money to do it
votesHelpful: and some ships can be used without much downside with less than maximum crew due to crew management mechanics added to the battles shortly after steam release. In addition
votesTotal: the thresholds for how much experience (earned by damaging and sinking/capturing enemy ships in battle) is required for each rank was recently reduced by a large margin. All that being said
votesFunny: don't fall into the trap of thinking "bigger ship = better ship." The captain's skill ultimately decides the battle. Even a cutter (starter ship) can make the difference in an open world battle

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have never written a proper review for a game on Steam before, but I feel as if I have to for this game.

In short, it's beautiful.
The Open world is gorgeous and seemingly full of activity that ranges from lone/grouped pirates on the hunt, AI fleets or trade ships are full of cargo and are ready to be plundered. The map is stacked full of visitable ports/cities (as long as your nation has a hold of it).

The combat is in-depth and can be complex. That being said it can also be forgiving against the AI and the game developers allow you to have unlimited free repairs for the beginning ship which gives you the freedom to test your skills without punishing you.

Everything from the winds direction, the waves & the caliber/type of your guns can affect the course of a battle significantly, which adds an unexpected element to the battles. Does your enemy have long range cannons or Carronandes? Are you Up wind or Down wind? Is there a storm at the moment, or is the ocean calm? This all adds a unique experience to each and every battle which personally, keeps me drawn in.

PVP is awesomly fun, with both open world PVP or Small/Large battles you que up to and play in. They are generally 10v10 for small battles and 25v25 for large battles, which can get hectic but are always fun. Teamwork plays a major factor, shepherding ships across friendly broadsides, keeping the ship distracted while a friendly rakes their stern or even assisting in boarding by grape shotting the enemy ship (careful not to hit your friendlies).

The ship designs are wonderful, even though I would prefer to be able to see my crew during the open world sailing. Each ship has different characteristics, some being hulks with more guns or corvettes built for speed which allows the player to explore with their prefered traits.

The crafting system also allows players to construct and modify ships to add special abilities. For example, a Snow- typically a slower ship- can have upgraded rigging and be built out of a lighter wood, which will increase it's speed for a lack of armor.

I would prefer if they added some in-game music from the era, but I usually just remedy that with some youtube of either the Assassins Creed Black Flag sea shanties or some classical music from Mount and Blade: Napoleonic Wars.

The community is wonderful and always ready to help, which is quite rare in my mind. It may be because the game has a bit of a learning curve that it deters people who would rather troll" then play properly. Some people have been around for a long time
date: and some since the steam release and they integrated quite easily to form a very solid community that I am happy to be apart of.\n\nOverall I honestly suggest this game even though it's in early access. It is not one to miss if you are in love with the era or if you are naval fanatic like I am. If not and are hoping to dabble into the genre
recommended: this is a great start - the game is forgiving to new players & the community is willing to help teach you the basics."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

IMPORTANT: If you're someone who likes to get into a game and play it just fine, this isn't for you. Maybe because it's early access, but to understand everything, you'll need to look up stuff on the game official forum or ask on the steam forum ( who has a very low population compared to the real forum tho ).

The game is very well made for an early access, I've owned this game since it's very very early access where you purchased it on their website and they sent keys by wave. There's a lot going on and the game mechanics are very good. But it's really ''realistic'', it's not an arcade kind of game like how you fight with ships in black flag, so if you're into that instead of something more up to par with real life standards, I'd recommend you skip this game.

The graphics are very good & I never had any lag ( playing this game on a 560M than on a 960 ), obviously there are some bugs, but it's pretty good looking so far.

The only thing that is a downer ( for me at least ), is the price tag, 55$ CAD is fairly expensive for an early access game, and I feel it may pose problems for future sales.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although being in Early Access, Naval Action has a very good foundation upon which the game is being built upon. They started with the very basics by first developing, fleshing out and testing the combat module years ago. It is clear that this is where Naval Action shines.

It's not a true simulator by any means, however, it takes whatever realism it can and molds it into a fantastic gameplay experience. Sailing mechanics such as manually controlling the yards is extremely fun and rewarding as your maneuvering the battlefield trying to line up a perfect broadside. Constantly keeping an eye on the direction of the wind, the angle of your yards, the angle and direction of your targets yards and ship. Outmaneuvering your opponent can be a truly rewarding experience and most definitely will help you in coming out on top and surviving a battle.

The 'overworld', or 'open world' part of Naval Action is very much so a work-in-progress. However, it shows us the potential of Naval Action as a large-scale war between multiple nations trying to outsmart eachother through stategical prowess and manipulating the political landscape. Naval Action has a long way to go but it has shown us that the concept works, beautifully so, and they plan to make it so much better.

Albeit a tad bit pricey for being an Early Access game, I personally believe it to be one of the best we've seen thus far. So if you like the Age of Sail in general, perhaps the masterpiece film 'Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World', the great series 'Black Flag', you might want to check out this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, a friend has been going about this for some time, and being a fan of wooden ships myself finally got to try it.

WOW. This, this is a really great find for fans of the era, or just looking for something different.

Some things you must have a basic understanding of before you play.. or you will be really frustrated... You will / can learn but better to admit to yourself what level you are before rage quiting.. take that frustration and learn how.. its not so hard.

1. Real compass to map navigation. There are no giant quest guides. No mini map route to use. You have a map. You have a compass. Terms like S by SE begin to come clear.  If your in the deep water, landmarks dont exist.  You have your compass, the sun and you have to think about how long you have been sailing and speed.

2. Sails / tacking etc.. The physics are pretty good in what I have seen. Fortunately you do have wind direction available on your compass.. a little knowledge of sails goes a looooong way.  Also remember.. these vessels dont stop, accelerate or turn on a dime. It takes the crew a moment to make sail changes also.

Combat is really well done. Cannons, various ammo types of the time, shipboard musket fire.. boarding..

The tide is with us, the wind fair, cast off!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTICE:  This is a Early Access Review.

By the time of this writing I have played 894 hours in this game, and one of the leading commanders of the Dutch Antilies Squadron.  I've enjoyed this game a lot through it's development and progress, however, you need to know about this game before you get into it.  Spend a week or two reading the fourms, watching videos on YouTube and such, and you should be well aware what this game is about before you perchase it.  Naval Action is a beautiful and entertaining game with a mostly decent community, therefore, you should want to know what you are getting into before getting it.

This game is not fully fleshed out yet, and many features are still yet to be developed, such as a port UI, official in-game diplomacy, proper economy, and provisions.  Development with the game is slow, and requries patience.

This review is not about the individual features of the game, but how this game is largerly operated by most of the community.

Naval Action is an Open World Naval Combat game.  The game's era is between 1750 and 1820, therefore, this is not a galleon, sea-dogs and pirate game.  Instead, it is more of a game of national sepremacy from the Seven Years War to the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic era.  Right now, the map is the Carribean, Gulf of Mexico and lower seaboard of the American coastline,  but don't be dismayed, it's plenty big enough right now, as it will take hours to sail from one side of the map to the other.

This game is not a game where you can log in an expect a quick and decent battle however.  Battles themselves can take 30 minutes easily, and not to mention the amount of time looking for a target to attack.  If you want to play this game properly, you need to set aside an entire afternoon.

Most of the real fun in this game are the large national fleets fighting for conquest.  These are largely operated by organizations, for example The Decatur Armada and Tattered Flags for the Americans, the Sea Lords Royal Navy for the British, Enfants du Roy for the French, and the Dutch Antillies Squadron for the Dutch (as well as many other groups, more information for them are on the Naval Action fourms).  Most of these organizations opperate off of a TeamSpeak 3 server to allow for communications.  Some are more strict than others, and is up to your prefernce.  These organizations however will try their best to help you through the ranks and teach you all the qualities of seamanship you need for Naval Action. The real excitement are the large ship battles that will occur as rival nations clash with each other on their borders in large battles for sepremacy in the Caribbean.

But yet again, people need to be aware that war is not fair.  If you sail away from areas protected by your nation, you are a free target for any other nation or player to attack you, fairly or not.

The fact is, the most important decision that you will ever have in this game is which faction you are going to pick at the very start.

Some factions are easy due to the sheer number of players, like the British and the Pirates due to their sheer numbers, while others are thrown in the middle of the most contested waters in the game, such as the Danes, Swedes and the French.  Spain will forever be a target for the more expanively minded nations until they get a population, while the Americans and Dutch will be cursed in the early game due their lack of ports and resources.  Currently, there is not official diplomacy implemented between the nations and all are theoretically at war.  Diplomacy is largely crated by the player organizations.  For example, the Dutch and the Danish organizations are allied with each other, even though theoretically they are at war with each other in the game.  Therefore, it is wize to learn about which organizations are allied with which, and which ones are at war.

In conclusion, at the current state of the game, and particularly on the PvP server, the best way to treat this game is a battle for National Sepremacy.  Each nation has its own story: the Swedes, a story of survival; the Spanish, a story of prevervation; the Americans, a story of expansion; the British, a story of sepremacy; the Danes, a story of progress; the French, a story of unity; the Dutch, a story of achievement; and the Pirates, a story about too much rum and watching the world burn.  These nations may or may not achieve the stories the way that they wish, but they are the vital core of the game right now.  It is these nations and the people that follow them that make this game what it is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To be read with British accent…….

Cannons & wooden ships, what could possible go wrong? Down to Davy Jones’ locker you go!
Well not most of the time……

Based on the age of sail, wait, for those dimwits who can’t understand “age of sail”, that means your boat does not have a motor (NO ♥♥♥♥) it uses the wind for power. Boats at this time were made out of wood, so don’t expect to be driving the Bismarck around the Caribbean.
Enough of the intro lets move on shall we?

Open World:

Real life locations, beautiful sea, pirates, ports where you upgrade your ship or buy a new vessel, create a fleet (if you have the gold and experience), start battles, join your allies’ battle, attack merchant ships for expensive goods (my fav). Choose from a loads of nations: The British Empire (my fav XD), the French Empire (boooooo), the US (“damn colonial rebels” says in British accent), the Spanish Empire (filthy Spanish! I hate them…idk why but I do XD), the pirates (cowards and scum. I always go for theses ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s first). Plus a few more nations that I forget….sorry XD.

Naval Combat:

Use your brain and you will survive (hopefully). Don’t expect to start off with a first rate ship of the line with 108 guns (most powerful type of ship in the game). You, yes, you young captain you start off with a small 12 gun cutter. Sad and pitiful, you will work you way up to get better and bigger ships.
Combat is fun and realistic. Cannons sounds like cannons do. Smoke textures aren’t bad would like to see something of a high resolution. Boats look beautiful. You can fire one cannon at a time or all of them (what we call a broadside). You can destroy the enemy’s sails, kill their crew members, or just batter the ships hull until she sinks (what I do most of the time). And there is also the option to flee……cowards use that tactic often. You’re not one of them are you? If you wanted to……you could always capture the ship! Sinking them is much more fun.

OVERALL:
It’s a blast. Community isn’t fill with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Listen to pirates of the Caribbean theme with this game….will thank me later. Fought a brig in a cutter, lasted 5 mins 10/10 would get reckt again. Don’t do that plz. The devs still have lots to work on. Game needs better animation, cannons need to recoil, easier way to get to better ships. In the end the question you have to ask yourself is….would you to rule the Caribbean and slaughter the enemies of your empire through naval combat? Yes, Yes you would.
If you see me in game say hello and I hope, we conquer the Caribbean together! I always play as the British Empire, just letting all of you know. Good luck young captains! May God go with you.
