reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit after some time: this is the first MMORPG ive put this many hours into in years and years. Truly something different.

On the fence about getting this one seeing the high number of hours for many of the positive reviews. Took the plunge knowing I had 2 hours to decide before refund became unavailable. Glad I did. For the moment its like the old Pirates combined with World of Warships. Battles are just great, the detail level is a big step up from WOW, the battles are long and tense and swing back and forth as you land shots in the damaged areas and start to cause leaks below the waterline.

UI - placeholder, does the job
Tutorial - non existant but plenty around in the community, and honestly its not that hard. WSAD to control your ship, your cannons shoot where the mouse aims give or take, you have to wait for the moments when you have a good line due to waves not being in the way. Community helpful so far in PvE server
Grind - yes and no. Yes you have to fight a lot of fights to level up, XP rewards are proportional to the damage you do, and you need lots of slow earned XP - so you would be right in thinking that sounds like grind. Thing is that the battles are so good that I really don't get a sense of grind - this isnt right click on enemy, watch large hit point pool go down, use abilities etc etc, the battles are far better and give me a sense of both pleasure and achievement when I win through against the odds - more like Dark Souls, really skill based.

So I really like this. Its absolutely an alpha in early access with a long long way to go to be polished, but you play it to do the ship combat and that is simply the best I've seen. Really interested to see just how good this can get, its clear that it has taken big steps in the direction of being one of the great ship games, comparisons to EVE online frequent and deserved, and could easily go all the way.

Certainly worth the price of admission if you liked Pirates! or similar and want something with a really detailed damage engine, and excellent core game mechanics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Right then, first of all I just want to say something about the negative comments: Alot of the bad review seem to be from people who know nothing about the game nor seem interested to learn, I.E saying there is 0 guides.. Try checking the game forum (And now it is on steam people are creating guides for quicker access). Waiting times to login. well yea thats going to happen as the game just hit early access via steam..

And that all too important message of It is Early Access!

Right then, I was lucky enough to be apart of the early stages of pre alpha testing 2 years ago, the advancement that has been made in that time has just been great, the damage model is fantastic and altho basic to most people the graphics are beautiful. Back when we first got to play on the open world, ports had barely any textures, islands were blurred but it still looks great (A semi comparison would be like legacy rust to current rust.)

There is so much more in the pipeline for this game and the devs have been fantastic. They listen and communicate with the tester and player base (Just go to the actual forums)

This is a more hardcore realism age of sail game rather than an arcade style boat shooter.
The learning curve can be quite steep for some but stick at it and there is the help chanel in chat for newbies to go nuts in.

Once you experience a propper fleet battle with teamwork, the sounds n the imagary is just fantastic. You will love this game. If your not that into ships or the timeline then I doubt this game will be for you.

It's nice to play a game where the devs put their love into it.

10/10 and still much more to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really wouldnt listin to the negitive reviews of people whom have 30 hours or less into the game. people spouting off how bad the game is yet have 0.1 hours played. dont listin to them at all.

The game is relaxing at sea. if you enjoy the sound of the ocean, the booms of cannons anda good paced game. this is it for you.

You have PVP and PVE servers. you have a mini map. most of how you travel is by figuring out in real time where to go, and getting lost can be done with much ease.

Pros would include
Ship Vs Ship Battles
Port conqest ( you can take over some other nations port)
Ship boarding, (you can board another ship and take it as you're own)
Trading (not very fast paced but great if you want to earn some extra money)
Ship crafting (yea, you can build ships here and sell them off)
Graphics, (very nice graphics in the ships, the sea and the world)i miss the pig cloud though
Damage control. (You can disable a ships rudder, rip his sails down. or shoot the maste off to disable his speed)


Cons
Getting lost (its easy to get lost if you dont know what you are doing. never go afk in open world sailing.)
Losing you're ship (this is a pro and con here) If you lose a life on you're ship to zero, you lose the ship altogather, at the same time so does you're enemy)
long traveling between distances.(Hey its a massive map, dont think something fun will come quick and easy kids, go play call of duty)


All in all i say its a very fun and addicting game. i would kinda say it woul dbe like taking a crap in a handicapped bathroom. you have you're space, and have the little handle bars for power squatin

This game would be best most enjoyed if you like 2 of 3 things.
Do you like ships old or new?
Do you enjoy the ocean and sailing around?
Do you love intense battles with bots or players?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It has potential and the ship combat is pretty excellent unfortunatly the MMO mechanics of the game are something awful. By far the fastest and most effecient way to get into larger ships are to run missions" which as of now consist entirely of go to X kill Y. PvP and open lobby style battles are great but bot and mission grinders are already showing up in these with much more capable ships and dominating.

The "Open World" map is extremely boring there is really not much going on. There is weather but it does not have any impact in the open world map. You basically stare at water for 15min-hours+ depending on how far you need to go aand with no map marker
date:
you cant really even alt-tab. You may see some other faction and attempt to PvP them but the rewards for the missions are usually much higher and involve less risk.

The main problem is the by far best way to progress to competitive ships is the dullest part of the game. It involved sailing to a marker on the map which does not have a marker representing you so you have to navigate by feel. Then you fight one of 2/3 npc ships that spawn for that mission type. The AI does not present a real challenge but the battles still take between 10-40 minutes.

PvE gameplay is not bad some people like that but it is really unpolished in this game. Grouping with friends significantly hurts progression. The AI is not the worst but not capable of presenting much of a challenge either. Its always the same battle this one ship easily but slowly win type gameplay.

The free Cutter/Yacht causes more problems as the ship is unlimited and free so the fastest way to progress if you cant stand grinding boring missions is joining the lobby battles and then charging in and just yolo doing the most damage you can
recommended: even ramming etc is a non issue since your ship is free and the faster you sink the faster you can get in a new battle. Using any ship that is not a significant upgrade from the cutter is a huge waste as they can be lost most people recommend using that the entire time untill you unlock the end-game ships of the line.\n\nIF they are able to change the focus of this sandbox ships game to PvP at least on the PvP server this could be a great game. They need to at least triple the exp gained in PvP small and large battle lobbies. They need to find a way to diversify the ships used beyond free ship/brig-snow/SoL
hoursPlayed: again by offering increased xp/gold for people not using a free ship.\n\nThis game does a bunch of things right but then puts the focus and highest rewards on the least polished and most dull part of the game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game that I really want to like. I love sailing ships, I love naval combat. And this game is maybe 75% of the way there.

But here's the thing. There's literally no explanation of any mechanics in the game. I mean not a single one, there's no help page. No tooltips. No explanation of what things on the Worlds Worst UI do. No explanation about settings and things you can toggle on your ship. If you want to find any of this out, you have to go dig around the game forums, and read explanations of things that are out of date or don't help at all.

The players in game don't really answer questions either. I've seen several lost new players asking questions, and being ignored by the veterans in the chat channels. The playerbase obviously isn't putting any effort into helping the new people get a grip on a complex game.

The progression is absolutely glacial. I've played for 8 hours now, and haven't even gotten halfway through the first captain level. Even the gameplay gets glacial, once your ship takes enough damage and your crew takes enough casualties (about 5 maybe, it's insane) everything takes longer to do. Guns reload so slow you could watch a youtube video in between shots. Don't get me wrong, I'm a fan of slower-paced games, and wouldn't like to see this game turn arcadey. But as it stands, the pacing is just painful.

When it's on, it's on. It's great sailing into battle, broadsiding other ships. Until everything slows down. It looks like there's a lot of fun metagame in the faction conflict, but you're gonna spend ages grinding before you get out of your baby ship.

Wait until the developers get a clue before buying this. As it stands it's maybe worth $20, not the asking price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:

+Great graphics
+beautiful scenery
+engaging ship combat
+a friendly and helpful community (take advantage of the online forums! GREAT resource for newbies!)

Cons:

-Early Access: still a work-in-progress
-Limited gameplay depth: combat is supreme, and crafting/trading is still not fully fleshed out
-Limited RPG depth: not much in the way of character creation, customization, roleplaying, etc.

Final Evaluation:

If you love the Age of Sail, then you should manifest your inner Jack Aubrey and try this game.

I understand that the $40 price point may be too much for some to gamble on an Early Access title, so if that describes you, at least put it on your Wishlist and keep an eye on it. The devs have shown themselves thus far to be reliable in meeting their stated goals, as well as responsive to player feedback. Odds are good that the game will only improve as time goes on.

Early Access Review

Nothing in the industry compares to this.

The underlying skill curve together with the most spectacular visuals depicting naval warfare in the age of sail makes of this game a must get for any age of sail aficionado. On top of that if you like combat games that can be played at any brain level - from simple automated sails with button smashing to the more intricate manual rigging taking advantage of winds and turn - then you must get this as well.

The entire caribbean sea is massive. And multiplayer. Link those two together and ... you get the point. Massive multiplayer.

From simple beginnings up to a commodore standing atop your own ship of the line of battle, sail the world, battle rival nations, trade, join events with dozens of ships in battles that make Trafalgar look like a nice place to be when the shards of timber start flying.

Albeit the game is somewhat demanding on the hardware side any modern gaming rig can run it top options, so no worries there. On top of that the lowest graphics" scum cannot exploit it as smoke

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best Naval Simulator out there.

Even though I have over 25 hours in the game I have explored less than 5% of the map and tested only 2 ships yet. You have to come to terms with the fact that this game is a marathon, not a sprint. If you are ok with investing time and effort into learning the machanics of sailing, gunnery, tacking and so on then there is nothing better out there currently. It's a realistic simulation and won't give you things like map markers, you have to navigate with your compass.

Killing enemy ships takes a lot of skill and time but once you get good at you get this awesome feeling which only comes from knowing that you worked towards it and not just clicked your mouse at a reticule.

You will spend about 20 hours just learning the basics (preferably against the AI) and then buying a real ship which will be your gateway to the caribbean. Don't be intimidated by the learning curve though, there are a lot of helpful videos and many helpful people in-game as well.

Even if you want to just relax after a long day at work, you can just hop into your little pile of oakwood, pick a heading and sail the high seas!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I must say that I have been called a “Fan boy” many times.  However, I seek to give an honest review that contains the good and the bad, so that people know what they are getting into, and whether the price tag is right for them.

Features
Authentic Age of sail naval combat game that blends realism and gameplay for an enjoyable and unique experience.  Era of game:  mid 1700s to the 1820s.  It is not a sim.  It is not an arcade.  It is not fully realistic nor fully historical, but a blend of all these.

Authentic and Addicting Combat System
Naval Action features one of the most beautiful and authentic Age of Sail combat systems to date.  Every cannonball, every wave, and many parts of the ships are all tracked to see where the ball hits.  Accuracy is not based upon rng or a magical skill number but actual gunnery, which is your own ability to judge the following three things:  the distance between you and the target, the characteristics of your smoothbore cannons, and the pitching and rolling of your ship through the waves.  I don’t know if this is well known or not, but I have hit the wheel of enemy ships and seen their ship go into “rudder shock,” which means they cannot turn.

No artifical skills
There are no skills to artificially train.  Instead of training skills at level up, you yourself have to get better at the game.  Whether it is knowing when, how and where to maneuver in battle, your ability to process the tactical situation, your own personal skill at gunnery, the way you position your ship while under cannon fire, or your ability to navigate the world, this game is all about how good you, your friends, and your enemies are. Your hand is not held by the game, but you will find the community is typically helpful if you have questions on how to do something.

Open World (OW)
Explore a massive world that would take weeks to fully explore.  It is time compressed because otherwise it would take days of real time sailing just to go between ports, let alone the weeks needed to cross the Caribbean.  How it is right now, it takes 4-12+ hours of real time sailing to cross the map.  Travel can be long.  Local knowledge of the area, the channels, shallows, and hiding spots are all vital. However, at the moment, the islands can seem a little boring beyond the majestic views.  There is dynamic weather and you can get lost, especially in storms and heavy fog.  Venturing out of sight of land for the first time can be a little intimidating.

Map
There is a very rough ingame map that shows the ports.  The devs plan to beautify the map once UI is decided upon.  There is no “You are Here” marker.  You will have to keep track of that yourself.  Navigation is a skill you will want to learn if you want to venture outside the Arena.  It is extremely daunting at first but easy to pick up.  Soon you will be pretty good at it.  The map lacks navigation tools.

Battle Instances
Because every shot, every wave, and detailed parts of the ships are all tracked by the server, battles have to be instanced. Instances can have up to 50 ships, whether they are small cutters or ships of the line.  Shallows and land do not appear in battle yet but is planned.

Realistic Sailing Model
Sailing in the battle instances is fairly realistic and authentic. To tack properly (turn through the wind), you have to learn manual sailing. Easy to pick up, fairly easy to master. It becomes second nature, like learning manual shift in vehicle.

UI
Battle Instance UI is pretty good in my opinion. I am a minimalist when it comes to UI. I don’t want all the extra crap blocking my view of the beautiful ships and environment. The Open World and Port UI are horrible (tech demo). I wish Game Labs would have spent a week polishing it a little before Early Access. The UI will be finished later. They don’t want to spend a lot of time working on something that will have to be redone in the future.

Economy and Crafting
The economy and crafting is basic, but every time I turn around, something new has been added and fleshed out. Don’t fall into the pitfall of buying crafting resources from NPC ports and selling them to NPCs. Sell to players or build your own stuff to sell. That is where the money is. Crafting and trading takes time, experience, and a lot of gold, but the payout is good.

Boarding Combat
There are no avatars.  You cannot walk about your ship.  When you board the enemy, a tactical mini game appears.  Some people compare it to Rock Paper Scissors.  Some like it, some hate it, I think it is fine.  If this is a deal breaker, watch YouTube first before you buy.

PVE
There is Player Vs Environment (AI).  The AI can be difficult at first, even very difficult.  But they soon become easy and boring once you get to know them.  There is a pve only server if you don't want to play against players.

PVP
This is where the heart of the game is. Expect Ganks. Expect great 1v1 fights. Expect on-the-edge-of-your-seat group fights, where teamwork and skill is needed to clutch victory from defeat. This is the addicting part of the game.

Port Battles:
Right now port battles only consist of a few towers that you have to destroy along with any player defenders that show up. There is no land yet or proper forts, but these are being worked on.  A successful port assault will change the current owner to your nation.  Do not open player outposts in national ports except the capital city. All other national ports can be captured and you will lose access to anything in the port until it is recaptured. Port captures are way too frequent (negative).

Arena
There is an arena option available.Technically you never have to access the open world if you don't want to. Battle seems daunting at first, but in the Arena you can practice in a low stress environment with the free basic ships. Combat is easy to get the hang, very difficult to master.

Progression
You start with a small cutter.You can progress to a ship of the line.The progression can be long.  Just pvp and have fun; no need to grind. You will get into the larger ships in due time and you will want to learn the game first. This game is all about the process.Forget the end game. If you get to the end game without learning the game you will cry when your extremely expensive ship ends up on the bottom of the ocean or in someone else’s dock. If you grind, it isnt any worse than WoWS.

Price
The price is expensive for an early access game. But in my opinion, it is very worth it. At almost 2000 hours, I have paid about 2 cents an hour to play Naval Action.

Stability
Even though the game is Early Access, I haven't had any crashes in almost a year. It is very stable on my machine. There are annoying bugs from time to time and very rarely something is wrong with the server. Other people report crashes but those are usually people who don't meet the minimum requirements. People do report fps problems. People say the game is poorly optimized, but with a 980 ti, I get 70-100fps on Open World and typically 100+ fps in battle.  I play on 1920x1080 and ultra.

You only get 1 character per server

Negatives/needs work/I dream of:
No crew management
OW and Port UI
Port Battles are a new feature and are still very rough
No land in battles
No navigation tools where your skill as a navigator matters
Only Basic clan features.
Port Captures are way too frequent
OW needs some little details to make it varied and interesting
No built in tutorials or manual
No reputation system yet

Positives
Battles are amazing
Addicting pvp
Realistic sailing model
Well developed damage model
Beautiful ships
Learning curve means you are always learning new things.  After almost 2000 hours, I am still learning new things.
Immense and impressive Open World
Era is set in the Napoleonic period and golden age of sail instead of the overdone golden age of piracy
The best Age of Sail game I have ever played

reviewText:
Early Access Review

***STEAM Early-Access REVIEW***

The game is a lot of fun, especially in a small group.

But.... There is much work to be done on the game, so those who are easily annoyed should wait to purchase at the least. I have NOT had many crashes, but a few disabling bugs that are usually ratified by a restart/ log (can't enter port, Can't sell goods, etc). I have played just over 160hrs and feel I developed a good grasp on the game. And it definitely does not take long to get a bearing on your place in the world. Especially since they added a map. Before you had to look at a google map and figure out an approximate heading. Which wasn't always easy since many places have been renamed from what they once were.

There are many interesting aspects to the game that age of sail or naval fans will find enjoyable. While others might find it a pain.

For example, planning your route of travel is more than just saying you want to go from X to Y. You need to account for wind direction and how it will alter as you progress along your designated course. Traveling in this game is a LONG and grueling process. You will either love or hate it. A good captain will take advantage of favorable winds and timing of the change in wind direction to make the most out of their course. That said TACKING is extremely important, and the sooner you understand that the better. Going straight to your target location is not always the best or fastest choice. Depending on your sail configuration and wind conditions will determine if tracking is necessary or in many cases a necessity.

Another featureful aspect to the game, naval and age of sail fans alike will enjoy, is the angle of LIST or LISTING which ships employ in the game. You ship doesn't sit flat on the water, (at least in most every case), rather it will tilt to either port or starboard depending on the ship itself, water conditions, and wind. This really adds to the combat aspect of the game, making it challenging to place shots on the enemy. Captains need to learn how their individual ships preform and act accordingly to perform in battle. Using different sail positions or going to battle-sails are great aids. But it will come down to the ship (and upgrades in some cases) and how well the captain knows his ship.

Ultimately the game is still in its early stages and has a lot of work to be done, but don't let that shy you away. If you are a fan of naval era games or age of sail in particular you are doing yourself a great disservice not trying this game out.
Oh yeah, and if you set an enemy ship on fire……. Put as much distance between you and them. And thank me later ;).

TL;DR: Fan of Age of Sail and not easily scared by semi-hardcore mechanics this game is for you. If not wait or simply do not purchase as this is not a game for the faint of heart or pew pew-sters.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, its always hard to objectively and honestly review Early Acces games. This is due to the fact that theyre not a finished product.

Naval Action is one of those games that has the potential to be a true gem in the making:
- The map is huge, and i really mean huge which gives that awesome feeling of truly sailing in the caribbean.
- Lots of player factions, not just the classic 3-4, no 8 is the way to go.
- combat is awesome, it is slow-paced but feels genuine in how the ships move and behave.

Sure, alot of things are still unfinished and placeholder, for instance the interface and the menus when in a harbor are just raw and unpolished, clunky and lacking. But im pretty sure those are items that are on the development agenda and bound to get the necessary attention in due time.
For now i feel that the developers are focusing on expanding the overall game, implementing a trading system (which i havent dabbled in and do not yet understand) and a crafting system (this looks pretty easy and straightforward and works well). Offering the playerbase more to do than just float around, do missions and attack other players.
This is a good choice, imo. Polishing can come later, give us a game first.

And the game is there, free liberty to roam around with your teammates and hunt down lone traders or sailors that had the bad idea of going out on their own or without enough support.

I have joined the United Provinces (Netherlands) on the EU1 server (which is the most populated one) and from what ive come to understand is that there are clans of 200+ members that already wage large-scale wars against other faction. Matter of fact, as im writing now, the French are making a move on the United Provinces along the eastern Venezuelan coast to go and capture some of the towns. Its all-out war!

Its a true PvP-game which i think can only be compared a little to EvE in how large it is and how large battles can be. Im not 100% sure but i think a large battle can include up to 50 ships.
This might increase later, it might not.

I think its an awesome game but it really is a WiP, one that even in its current state i highly enjoy and recommend!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're looking for a game about 17th-18th century sailing and warfare in the caribbean, I'd say this is the game you'd want. It has some similarities to Pirates of the Burning Sea, but it is more complex, has way better graphics, and is way more realistic, at least in my opinion.
Still, the game is in Early Access, so there's alot left to be done, as the UI for one, and I suspect there will be some sort of avatar part of the game as well.

A few things bother me though, first of all there's no real difference between nationals and pirates, wich goes pretty much straight against what this game otherwise have in terms of realism, the second major thing is that it is very hard core, and is endorsed to be so by the vocal part of the community that are active on the forums.

Overall I can say that the developers seem to listen very closely to what those active on the forums say, and not only ask for but also act on alot of the feedback they get. This however seem to further propel the hard core setup of the game, and I fear this can lead to a high degree of drop-outs among those trying this game out.
This doesn't seem to be viewed as a problem for most of the players, since there seem to be an opinion that it will create a good and healthy playerbase if weak" players are weeded out.
A good and healthy playerbase need enough players though

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A beautiful gigantic playground filled with stunning sunsets,huge storms,fog and changing wind  and sea conditions.

Craft simple ropes to exceptionally crafted ships.Open up outposts,build warehouses.Trade for income or for your manufacturing needs.You can sell goods to ports but also create contracts for desired goods from other players or sell your own manufactered goods via contracts to other players.

Board ships and take ownership and keep the cargo.
Battles filled with smoke,waves and flying wood splinters.

There are PVE servers for the single player minded  as well as pvp though the same character can enter the pvp server and keep rank and xp then reenter PVE server again keeping rank and experience.Money,ships are not transferable between servers.

In PVP ports can also be taken by 1 of 8 factions in game.

All this is in the  Early Access launch.
Dev's say there is still lots more to come.

For us old seadogs like myself EA used to stand for Electronic Arts and their advert that ended with It's in the game". Nowadays EA stands for Early Access but somehow there are those that expect an EA game to be feature complete(!?). For those that have been here since the devs first starting selling access keys and watched it grow from one PvE instance until now with Open World being just so incredibly huge this game has enough to justify the price for those who don't demand a $100mill game for their $40.

Upsides;
Slower paced game that simulates the forethought which went into sailing and fighting in Age of Sail ship. A much better "thinking man's shooter" than others in the store.
No crashes (using the x64 build) and only a couple of graphical glitches and minor
date: non-gameplay breaking bugs.\nVery good graphics. No
recommended: you can't disembark and walk around the port but that is a small nitpick that takes nothing away from the core game.\nDownsides;\nA slower game time-scale wise than many will be wanting to put up with - As one commented in chat the other day if you want to sail from one side of the map to the other plan on doing something other while your ship is sailing (studying

helpfulPercent:
right now" crowd.
Simple UI - This is one point that needs addressing soon. Something a bit more immersive such as the old "Pirates!" game would be nice but admittedly we still have many months to go before we can expect something of that scale to be implemented.
A slow grind and even slower for those explorer and social gamers types. The first couple of ranks could be made a bit faster to rank up in. Me being an explorer type played 8+ hours yesterday and am still an Ensign. Those that learn how to make the most efficient use of their time will rank up faster tho' don't expect to rank up like you're playing WoW while wearing full heirloom gear.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you only play this game for a few hours you will not witness the true glory. At first you'll sail around wondering why you spent $40 and what the hell there is to do... Do not be worried - NPC ships are everywhere. Ports are constantly being contested by opposing factions (again this will grow on new servers as the game sells). The game has an internal network of events - PLENTY to do - tons of ships to fight!

Lack of tutorials means deadicated learning through the community - join a clan if you can to be faster. Find the public teamspeak servers - read forums, look for help and you will find it.

The interplay of wind-based controls and line of sight cannon gunplay is an amazing mix for combat. It's realistic and very very strategic. Don't feel bad if you can't hit some ships with your cannons at first - moving speeds and shooting timing comes with practice. Once a bit more seasoned you can really hit hard in some of the bigger battles with a reletivly low level ship.

Leveling seems intimidating but in actuallity it's very much like other MMOs, just multiplied down. 10 levels instead of 100, getting to level 2" will seem like forever - but in terms of time it's like going from level 1 to 10 or 20 in another MMO."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game really worth trying, even in alpha.

This is a must have for every age of sail fan, it is really promising and full of detail and even if you are not a big fan of sails and cannons i think you could easily become one with this game.
The developers know what they're doing and listen to the players in their forums.

In game, you start by choosing your player name and nation, then you are brought to the Capital of your faction in the port screen (User Interface is a bit clunky right now, but they are obviously planning to improve it) where you can see your ship, buy equipment, trade, craft items, upgrade your ship and accept missions or simply jump in a random battle room and fight.
But if you press Sail you get to the open world, which is really huge, ranging from the northern coast of South America to Florida with the Caribbean Islands in between, of course, and the gulf of mexico, with lots of settlements and places to explore, fight or trade.
The various factions in game can conquer settlements belonging to each other, by assembling invasion fleets.

Sailing and fighting might seem hard at the beginning. but you will quickly get used to the various keys and maneuvers.
And fighting is where this game really shines, with a great level of immersion, nice graphics and awesome sounds (though the game could use a bit of soundtrack and a bit more variety of sounds), learning to maneuver a ship in a battle with many ships, with cannonballs flying over your head is really satisfying and when you manage to sink or capture your first ship it gets even more, the only negative thing about combat i can find personally is the text based" boarding actions

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been in this game since it was in private alpha, more than 500 hours with a long break in the middle. There are pieces of it that are simply magical. There are others that are pretty rough.

Hard to judge a game in early alpha, but as of now, I can only give it a very tentative thumbs up.

The good:
- As other have noted, the combat is incredible. If you have even the remotest interest in the Age of Sail, this is the combat sim for you. It is amazing. Combat is by far the best bit of this game, and may be worth the purchase price right there -- IF you are willing to stick with it. You really only begin to see the potential once you get out of the earliest levels and out of your default cutter.

- The open world is beautiful to look at, and the ship models are gorgeous. They look and feel like I imagine frigates and ships of the line would have looked and felt at sea. Cannons roar, smoke billows. It’s jaw-droppingly realistic.

- The PVP aspects are great, even for those who don’t like PVP generally (like me). This is a very slow game. It’s all about tactics, about limiting damage against and taking advantage of your enemy’s mistake. Fast twitch does nothing for you in this game, which is, frankly, awesome.

- The new damage system is fantastic. It is physics-based, and takes into account range, size of cannon, the angle of your shot, the type of armor your enemy has, where on the hull or masts/sails it hits, etc. You can honestly snipe someone’s rudder, which is a very big deal. People are complaining about it now, but I think once it is tuned a little bit, people will come to love it.


The bad:
- So far, 90 percent of the effort has been on combat and new ships. If you aren’t into combat, and PVP in particular, there isn’t much else going on here right now. Careerwise, it’s pretty much all about fighting. Trading is dull. Crafting is tedious. And this is coming from someone who has done a lot of both, a level 48 crafter.

- The devs have done a lot to limit ganking, and I don’t think it’s anywhere near the problem others do. I’ve never minded an unfair fight if it’s fun. This is a game, after all. But others seem to get more worked up about it than I do.

- The worst part I think is the lack of newbie zones, and instead the game relies on players for the most part to defend those areas. I stopped playing MMOs seriously a while back, so maybe this is a new trend -- that somehow players will balance the world out. It hasn't worked out that way, at least on PVP1. And I'm not sure that’s realistic in a game world. But as a new player you’ll be thrown right into the thick of it.

- In fact, I can’t imagine what this game would be like to come to new. There isn’t, as others have noted, much in the way of instruction. No in-game tutorial (yet). No really safe place to practice and learn. And as noted already, if combat isn’t your thing, you’ll tire of this game quickly. There is a pure PVE server, but the AI combat isn’t anywhere near as fun as PVP.

- The port battle system sucks, and needs a massive overhaul (which, allegedly, is coming). Currently, it leads to incredibly boring dynamics where a nearly indestructible fleet arrives because they had time to prepare, and defenders didn’t, and it’s over really before it starts.

- Pirates are silly as currently implemented. The devs are trying to maintain some connection to historical accuracy, but as of now the game system, oddly, allows pirates to be the most powerful nation in the game -- on PVP1 that is. Pirates should operate solo or in small groups. They should have completely different reward dynamics such as disrupting trade, running contraband, etc. And privateers should be a career option. Pirates should be flat-out banned from owning anything bigger than a frigate -- nor should they want to. Seeing a fleet of 25 pirate Santisimas is just -- wrong.

All-in-all, this game is worth buying if you are a fan of Age of Sail. Even now, it’s well worth it. If you are not, or if you want to pursue a career other than one that is combat-oriented, I’d wait.

Ok, I will give you a little back ground. I loved POTBS. Thought it was a great game right up till they sold off.
I was kind of excited to see this game. A friend was playing it and verry excited about it. I himed and hawed about getting into another navy game. So I decided to take the plunge, and now sorry I did. To be honest I cant say all things are bad. The sea graphics are exelent. The cannon fire and aiming great. The crafting system seams good too, I like the labour hour storage.
Now over to the dislikes.
1.  I am sure that in the 1700's they where using sextant. So why do I not know where I am in the game.
2. Ship speed, Why am I going so slow in a small boat and turning like a barge. I do understand that a large ship going with the wind and all of it sale can over take a small ship. I do understand tacting the wind in a small boat. But when I get in a battle with a small boat against a big ship, skills in knowing this are of no use when my speed in manurving are nerfed. One like thought out of this they do have the dead spot, They should also have with it the ability to take the other ships wind that is running form you.
3. Nice spread sheat for a port. Am I back in dos? I undrstand this is alpha and It will probally change. But with so much detail to the ships and the beautiful ocean., they could have sat down and done something better.
4. Attacking ships as a team, I dont understand why I have to go out side the circle to enter the battle that I am trying to join with a team mate. If you are in a group you should be pulled in together.

Right now I wouild give this game a 5/10, I will be watching and trying it after patches to look for improvements.  I am not going to recommend at this point just because of the price point.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only had the privilege of playing Naval Action alpha for the month prior to early access but I've found it to be fun and it's got great potential. It's a slower paced game with moments of high drama. Players that enjoy games like Eve online, POTBS or Elite Dangerous would probably enjoy this.

Sailing the ships is a joy, the devs have really nailed that part of the game. It does take some practice to get any good at it especially the gunnery and manual sail control. You actually have to aim your shots here, there’s no tab target and use ability type stuff.

The graphics are really well done they can be taxing on some systems though and at this point the port UI still is unfinished.

The game world is large and as a result getting from A to B takes time. This gives you plenty of opportunity to chat with other players, plan you next crafting project or plot your next attacks. This may annoy players that expect things to be fast paced, others like me really enjoy a relaxing sail from island to island.

The game supports both PvE and PvP players with both types of servers available, the difference being you can’t attack other players in the open world on the PvE server.  PvP options include fighting on the open world, arena type battles and port battles for territory control.

For the less violent types there is crafting, trade and hunting NPC’s on the open world map. There’s also a rudimentary mission system, currently only simple kill NPC missions but they’re pretty challenging none the less.

One thing I must say is the game is very stable I've not had a single crash in 100 hours of play and the only bugs I've reported have been typos in the test. There’s still a lot of ideas and improvements to be added though so the next few months are going to be exciting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was a huge fan of Sid Meier's Pirates! back in the day. More recently I enjoyed the MMO Pirates of the Burning Sea. If you liked both of those games, you'll love this one. It is a bit more technical than PotBS and a lot more than Pirates! but it is easy to get the hang of. The graphics are amazing.

One thing you do need to realize though, this game isn't done yet. A lot of the menus look like crap. There are bugs. A lot of stuff is left to be refined. If you can get past that, this game is an amazing sailing game. If you can't get past that, this game has a lot of potential, so follow it.

There are NO official tutorials yet. I recommend you read and watch the videos members of the community have created before you start playing or you will be a little lost. There is a thread on the official forums that contains them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

FIRST: It's an alpha. Many systems are missing, many are unrefined. It's fun but don't expect a full game yet!

This said, as a fan of C.S.Forester novels, I love this game. I have bought it on an impulse after playing Windward just to relax and boy, was it the right decision.

Currently what has received major focus is the naval combat (surprise!) - it feels good! While a bit overwhelming at the beginning and the interface not being in any way final, after spending a couple of hours and reading around (no manual, no tutorial yet but plenty of guides on the forum and youtube) I started enjoying myself immensely. I really believe the combat captures the right spirit of the era and to any sailing ship fun this will be a delight. After overcoming the initial part I realised I was craving for even more complex mechanics to tackle (and which are on the way).

The open world part certainly still needs work but the beginnings are all there. It is very rough on the edges but with time and feedback it can only improve, especially because the dev team actively listens to the players and tries to fix issues and rework system to make it the most fun possible.

So if you like naval combat and are not afraid of PVP (let's be honest, that's where the fun is)  then grab your portion of rum, hoist your sail and sail on towards adventures and glory!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I purchased Naval Action via their website just before the Steam Early Access release. In general I have been pleasantly surprised at the current quality of the game. I have logged 30 hours on this and game has never crashed on me or become unplayable. I have experienced the odd bug but the devs seem to work quickly to resolve them.

The game itself in its current state has plenty to do. The joy of sailing around an Open World Caribbean is there. You join a nation and are essentially at war with all other nations (attacking your own nation’s ships, unless they are carrying contraband, makes you a pirate for life). So whether it’s hunting down a trade ship or a frigate, there are enemies to fight, both PC and NPC. There are also Port Battles which can decide whether a port will change hands to another nation. These often become big organized PvP affairs.

The game was already populated by an active community before it came to Steam. There are active player groups with each nation. The website forum has  many threads on the full range of subjects that a new player will want to know. This is a good thing because the game currently lacks tutorials.

Right now there are two sides to the game, combat (sailing around, accomplishing missions or fighting) and crafting/trade. You can craft basic goods and ship upgrades all the way up to crafting ships, which can then be used by you or put on sale in a specific port. You can also buy/sell goods in different ports.

Please note that in Naval Action, your XP rank limits how many sailors you can command but there is no limit on the ships you can buy. So you start off at 40 sailors (and a Cutter that needs 40 sailors to man it). Thus, even if you have the gold to buy it, you won't be able to man a frigate that require a crew of 200 or more, let alone a Ship-of-the-Line. An undermanned ship often performs poorly in every way. So resist that “buy” button, even when you have the gold to pick up a big warship. Make sure you can crew it (and outfit it with cannons/carronades, with you must buy separately).

The other thing that should be noted is time. It can take a while to sail around in the Open World, especially if the wind is not in your favor. Hitting the seas for a full 30 minutes or an hour is not unheard of if your destination is several ports away. The Open World also has no real navigation tools. From your starting point you really have to look at the map (M), decide on a bearing and sail in the direction you want to go. Once land disappears you don’t know where you are, its pure guesswork and planning. Just sailing off without paying attention to the compass can get you lost. Note that behind the chat window in the upper left hand corner of the screen in Open World Sailing there is another panel that gives you some options, including allowing you to teleport back to the nation’s capital port.

For faster play, there are missions that typically allow you to jump into combat fairly quickly, from a load screen for a simple PvP match, or a mission that sends you to a spot in the Open Worlds near your current port to do battle. These two mechanisms are often the best way to grind up gold/XP but are also the most convenient for players with limited gamer time.

Expect a slight learning curve because of the lack of tutorials and a sometimes not-so-intuitive UI in a few places. I spent a lot of time combing through the forums on Naval Action’s website for the answers to various questions the first week I started playing. I highly recommend spending a lot of time in the starting Cutter (it's free and replacing it is free) to get acclimated to the game.

In general, if you enjoy Age-of-Sail, you'll enjoy this game, even in its current Early Access incarnation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally Naval Action will hit the EA.
To get some Informations for new players I am going to write this review.

I've been playing the game since May 2015 (Alpha State).

About:
Naval Action is a mmo open-world sandbox ship fight game. The ships are from the age of sail. At the moment this review was written there are no other games like this.
You play as a captain, sailing a ship along one of several nations including GB, Swedish, US, French, Spain, Danish and even pirates. As a nation you need to stick together, to gain more exp and defeat your ports against the hostile nations.
Yea thats right, you need to defend your ports. As the game is pvp based all the ports of a nation can be obtained by hostile nations, what leads to huge port battles that gain you extra exp aswell.
The fight-system is instance based. So you sail along the openworld map located in america and join battles with your friends or start a battle against an enemy ship you see on the water. The huge maps and hundreds of ports make it even very interesting for players just wanting to explore everything and look at the beautiful graphics. As you fight enemy ships (PVP or PVE) and do quests you will rise in rank. This allows you to hire more crew members needed to control large ships. The ships itself can be upgraded and sticked with different cannon types, for example short range carronades that give u a lot of damage but won't work if another player just destroyes you from range with his long cannons. This gives the game a nice tactical touch, especially when participating in big PVP battles (like 40 players for example).

Features:
- Nation based gameplay to garanty PVP (PVE Server is availible aswell if you dont like PVP)
- Port battles (obtain the enemy port and use it as your new headquarter!)
- Crafting System (for ships, upgrades and cannons. To get the best stuff, you need to craft it)
- Trading System (ports produce ressources needed for crafting, but not every port produces the stuff you need)
- Open-World
- Instance based battles
- Boarding-Feature (You can capture enemy ships and its holding)
- Different ammunition types for tactical use (demasting, kill crew, destroy ships)
- Different Upgrades and Cannontypes (make your ship suit your playstyle!)


I totally recommend this game and are looking forward for new players joining our current playerbase. At the end of the alpha testing we are around 500-1000 players already.
Please be aware that the game is still in early access. Thats why there is no nice" User-Interface in the ports implemented yet. But the fightsystem and graphics on water are absolutly fantastic.
See you on the map

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Three things that distinguish the game:

-It's the best naval combat simulator out there. It beats such giants as Age of Sail, Pirates of the Burning Seas or Sea Dogs. You control every individual gun if you want to, you can control individual masts to turn faster or decide at what angle/distance the guns will converge. Ships react realistically to wind or gunfire damage, they can even be set on fire. This game offers slowpaced but hugely realistic and fun fights where a small cutter can outmaneuvre anyone, a swift frigate is the jack of all trades and a huge, slowturning ship of the line should better stick to a strict line of friends to survive.

-It's a true MMO sandbox. The downside: there is no tutorial, you have to rely for forums and youtube for (good) explanations, there is nothing resembling a story" and leveling up takes a lot of time. The upside however: It's an enormous open world where you can sail anywhere and it will take you more than 5 hours to cross from east to west and you will have to use only your compass without relying on an automap. It's a world of thousands of players
date: if you play on a PvP server you can be part of high politics made by the mighty guilds/fleets
hoursPlayed: try to starve your enemy out or make your nation the ultimate underdog
voteText: biting the large empire in sensitive spots. While the main part of progression is nearly exclusively combat at the moment (it will change in the future)
helpfulPercent: traders and especially crafters play a huge role in supplying this war effort
votesHelpful: where large crafting chains of coordinated players are usually coming together to build huge ships of the line.\n\nImportant Disclaimer: You can play this game as a casual pretty well
votesTotal: however a game session of 15-20mins will not bring you anywhere since travel times are longs and fights might lasts for some time. However if you can spend an hour a day on this game and are an avid age of sails fan it will not disappoint you.\n"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBeen playing this for three days now and I cant stop! reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game about age of sail. It's multiplayer focused but Naval Action is closer to open world experience of Eve Online (port conquest battles, huge player lead guilds) than World of Warships tech tree grind. Battles are tactical and realistic but still simply fun, and thats a huge achievement for an alpha state title.
If you would ask me about biggest drawback of Naval Action at this time, I would point at W.I.P UI and lack of tutorials. Also   don't expect AC: Black Flag level of graphical fidelity, since game has to handle 50 player controlled ships in battle instance.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this game back in Sea Trials and I have logged in over 600 hours of game play, I can tell you that this is the best Age of sail game i have played. Even during Sea Trials where all there was is combat I found the game fun, and now with open world there is a lot more to do with crafting and port battles and there will be a whole lot more to do in the future once the devs add more content.

Graphics:  The best graphics in a age of sail game each ship is detailed to its real life cosmetics and physics from fore and aft rigged ships to the famous HMS Victory and more ships will be added!   Along with the detail of the ships the open world is also very detail including day and night cycles and dynamic weather.

I give this game a big thumbs up because I can only see this game getting better  as time goes on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game so far and one of my favorites in the last years.

Contentwise it is rather heavy on the action side right now. It is not a bad thing and the game is very enjoyable, but if you expect a great story or trading simulator will be dissapointed at the current stage. The main part right now are battles, basically standart open world battles against whatever you encounter on your journey and different forms of large PvP battles. While many other features, like trading and crafting, are still in development with only a basic version in the current implemented into the game so far. These will be extendet inn future updates.

I am playing this game since the Sea Trials and still really like. This is still just the Early Acces  version and with the development progress of last year in mind I expect this game to turn out very well.

There is no in-game introduction yet so search youtube for an intruduction to get the basics. It is not too hard and defenitely worth giving it a try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Es un juego sin acabar. Por esto tiene aún muchos fallos. Personalmente creo que será divertido, aunque requiere muchas horas para aprender y ver todo su potencial, y para disfrutar con las batallas. Esto es de lo mejor: las batallas grandes que realizarás con otros jugadores, conectado a un Clan por un sistema de chat. Al juego todavía le falta la interfaz y muchos detalles que le darían más realismo, algunas animaciones, graficos, detalles de ambiente, etc. Pero creo que todo esto lo lograran con el tiempo. Lo peor, y creo que no podrán arreglar, es la falta de secuencia historica. No hay Campaña, ni hechos historicos, ni barcos españoles, ni nada que se le parezca, ni tan siquiera sabes el año en que juegas...y el mapa no refleja el Caribe Español en el siglo 18. Es una pena pero la Historia se la han saltado y, pisoteado diría yo, pues NO hay indicios de que lo vayan arreglar, y si parece estar hecho para agradar a los Americanos. Por esto actualmente lo que hay es un agravio y una falta de respeto por la historia. Ni los piratas eran así, ni las ciudades del caribe, ni la historia inexistente en el juego.Una lástima. desde luego no es un juego educativo desde el punto de vista historico. Grave error.

______________________________________________________________________

It is a game unfinished. So it has many lacks. Personally I think it will be fun, but requires many hours to learn navigation and to enjoy the battles. Those battles are the best: you will play with other players, all connected into the Clan with a chat system. The game still lacks the interface and many enviroment details that would give more realism,( some animations, graphics, details, crew etc.) But I think that all will come on release time. The worst, and I think we can not fix it, is the lack of historical sequence. There is Not Campaign mode, neither historical facts, nor Spanish ships, or anything like that, not even know the year in which you are playing ... and the map does not reflect the Spanish Caribbean in the 18th century. It is a pity but they will have jumped the history, and there is no indication that it will fix. This game seems to be made to please the Americans. Currently there is a lack of respect for history. Neither the pirates were so stronger, nor the cities of the Caribbean, were like we saw in the game.Certainly it is not an educational game from the historical point of view. Big Mistake.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game everyone who was ever a fan of Jack Aubrey or Horatio Hornblower was waiting for. Take to the seas in a variety of sailing ships, from litte 12-gun cutters to the magnificent Santisima Trinidad with 140 guns. Sail with friends in a fleet, go off on your own and play old harry with enemy trade or hunt pirates. Or become a filthy pirate yourself.
It is very easy to lose time in this game. After I got it in closed alpha in the first 48 hours after installing it I had 27 hours played. Its so good.
It is alpha, so game mechanics will change, appear and dissapear. The devs themselves promise new and exciting bugs with every patch. Keep this in mind.
Apart from that, its great. Good god its great.
Currently there is no official tutorial or manual, the game changes too much to make one now. But, you can find plenty of help in the aptly named help" chat in game. There is plenty of guides on the forums and several youtube videos.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love parts of this game but just cannot reccomend it as it stands. The devs have a fantastic setup for the future of this game and will surely make a game that will go down in history. But as of right now, there is just too many flaws that make me rage quit this game every time I try and get into it. I'll list some of my complaints below. Keep in mind that I have been playing this game quite a bit to try and see if maybe I am doing something wrong, but I am convinced that this game has too many issues for me personally.

1. There is no tutorial at all.
This game has a very very steep learning curve, almost like hopping into IL-2 1946 on max realism for your first time. You are dropped into the game and are on your own immediately. They don't even tell you how to open your sails to move. You are forced to get in touch with a clan who can train you and provide you with some basic knowledge about how to even use the port menus. Joining a clan isn't too bad of an idea since almost all of the larger clans are happy to help but if you like to be a lone wolf it can be very frustrating.

2. The AI is extremely overpowered if you try to battle by yourself.
This is perhaps my biggest pet peeve about this game. If you are by yourself trying to do a mission on your level it is nearly impossible to sink the AI. I did a battle in which I was in a Navy Brig, the AI was in a regular Brig. I had 37 leaks on his ship and he was at near zero armor. He was still floating like nothing happened. He could even sail into the wind at 8 - 10 knots while the second I turned into the wind, I came to a dead stop. I was at around quarter armor all around and had 0 leaks and I was taking on water at crazy rates after one broadside. I have never been able to take on an AI in battle unless I had a fleet with me or took on a low level mission while using a large ship. The AI seems to be way too accurate, way too maneuverable, and have armor that seems like it's made out of cast iron.

3. The optimization is absolutely terrible.
Not much really to be said on this subject. The game has pretty bad optimization.

4. The game is extremely grindy for XP
If you want to level up within a day you have to get used to doing back to back missions. It's not bad at first but once you reach level 4 or 5, it takes forever to level up. If you want to get this to play for only a couple hours a day, you might want to get used to the cutter because it will take you weeks to level up. While this can be a con, it is also understandable since you don't want everyone rolling around in the best ship.

I have many more complaints, but I am really not trying to go on a b*tch fest here. I'm just trying to say what I don't like about this game. I will probably continue to try and like this game but as I said before, unless you are constantly with a couple of people to help you in battle, it is near impossible to win fights unless you go against a small ship. For $40 I would personally say wait until this goes on sale for at the most $25 and pick it up then if you really want it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very impressed with this game so far, in early access. The combat similation is absolutely top notch for an Age of Sail game, and certainly many players who have been looking for a similar title to Pirates of the Burning Sea will find a new home here.

As I write this the game is pretty barebones apart from the combat areas, but entirely functional, and stunningly beautiful. Combat is simply sublime. The developers are active on their forums and take their heading from the community as to what the focus of the upcoming patches should be. New ships to be included are submitted and voted on by the community and are then pushed through to development.

I really, honestly, don't have any major complaints to make about the game in its present state, I think the only thing major that needs to be addressed is the inclusion of some form of tutorial, as you do see in the in-game help channel a lot of new players a little confused about the same topics over and over again. Thankfully however the community is both welcoming and helpful, and seem entirely happy to patiently help you as you take your first steps (and mis-steps!) in the in-game world. The Basic Cutter starter ship is free anyway, and losses are to be expected as you learn the ropes! Its a fun process anyway, and rewarding when you get to grips with it.

I find the the game has a certain feeling of satisfaction to it when you win a fight that you should otherwise, by rights have lost, only to prevail due to your skill at handling your ship. In that regard, it is definately a rewarding game.

Literally cannot tear myself away from it right now, its very good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game, even though it is in early acces at the moment of this review, has everything you could want in a game.

Pros:
+ Nice graphics
+Tons of action
+Tactics and strategy
+A complex yet simple to understand crafting system
+An awesome community
+The lower tiers ships can have as big an impact in battle as the higher tiers depending on the situation

Cons:
- No in-game music, you'll have to make your own music set-list. Sea chanties ahoy!
- No tutorial. People will definately help you in the Help chat though.
- Faction misbalance. With the current mechanics, the faction with the most players is too much at an advantage.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo Naval Action?What is it?Simple,its combat in the Age of Sail.PLay area so far is around 12 million Sq Nautical Mile encompassing the Southeastern seabord of the USA,Gulf of Mexico,Yucatan Peninsular,and the North eastern coast of South america and the Carribean Islands.You start off as a Midshipman(other Nations have equivalent Ranks)and in posession of a basic Cutter that has 6 Cannon per side.You Ra k up by gaining XP by Attacking and sinking other Ships(AI or Player)as you Rank up your allocation of Crew increases,thus allowing you to Crew lager ships.Then there is Crafting and Trading.Both selfexplanitory.Crafting allows you to build bigger and better ships along with Upgrades.The Open World is a sumptous place with both Fine and Stormy Weather patterns.You can expand yor Nations Empire by having Port Battles to take possesion of the Enemy's Ports.Sailing and Gunnery mechanics are simple but not easy to master!If you are after a run n Gun" game or cant be bothered to sail in open water for 45 mins then maybe NA isnt for you.If you are a History  Buff or an ex matelot you WILL love this game!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval Action Early Access Review, Grade : Captain, written at around 350 hours of game-time.

Pros

- An unique open sea battle simulation. The (few) naval battles games that exist can't get close to the gameplay, realism and beauty of this game.
- Combat is really well done. Every tactical option is here : 3 different ammunitions, crew management, advanced sails management with wind direction, different kind of canons, different kind of ships and possible strategies...
- Very enjoyable with a group of friends, large or small. As it is a PVP designed game, you'll enjoy the thrill of naval action together. If you don't have a group though.... you'll get ganked !
- A very large map. It easily takes half a day of sailing to get through one point to another !
- Devs are very engaged on this game, and close to the community. They often reply on the official forums. Tired of AAA game devs ? Here they're really awesome.
- Port battles are going to be awesome once they'll release... forts. But from the previews it'll be epic !
- No subscription, no cash shop ! It's basically a MMO like the first guild wars, Buy to Play. Price is OK for the content.


Negatives

- Open sea mechanics are still new, and not very well designed. Trouble to find enemies that don't run, trouble to find missions... ports are conquered way too easily etc... That will change but the actual state of the open world is bad.
- Grind is real. I didn't grind much, as I like to experience quite a lot of different things in the game, and after 350 hours I'd have thought to have end-game ships. Not really ! I am yet to unlock constitution and 3rd rates. So brace yourselve if you're a casual player that don't like grinding, you might never experience the end game anytime soon.
- The game is a sandbox, and is definitely unbalanced on small servers. Choose your faction wisely if you don't like to fight with unfair (impossible) odds.
- Crafting system is terrible as it is purely based on RNG, but hopefully it will change next patch.
- UI is awful, as it is a placeorder. This will change before release.
- Customisation is missing : no character or portrait, no ship cosmetic customisation. But that will likely change before release.
- You keep combat XP forever, but devs will maybe/probably reset everything else before release. You've been warned. Nothing is final yet.

Overall : 7/10 if you have a group of friends or meet nice players in game. If you are also a fan about ships of the golden age of sail it gets to  9/10, THIS GAME IS FOR YOU. If you're a casual solo player : 4/10. Unless you want to play in group on a regular basis, this game has not much to offer to you.


Final verdict : Recommended

The game is unique in its genre and should definitely be in your library if you like simulation of early 19th century sea battles. I repeat, this is not an arcade games and it is realistic to a certain extent, while not being a full simulation. The pace is slow, but needs skills.  If you like or don't mind simulation-paced games, then consider the followings :

The open sea mechanics are bad, but the excellent combat mechanics more than make up for it. Open world is still recent though, and the game will only get better until release. Devs seem to be very engaged at keeping work on this game, and don't really care about money.
Also, this is a PVP game before everything, and to enjoy it you need to group and grind at least a little. If you don't mind both of these requirements, then it is definitely a good game. It is still far from being perfect, but worth it even right now. Then, if you're a fan about naval battles don't hesitate. You'll probably love the game.

If the devs fix the open world mechanics and keep putting more content, I'd recommend it even for casual players.

Great game. Well, it´s in EA obviously but the devs are pretty active and also very communicative, have frequent polls for new features/ development steps and so on going, so i´m not worried the game will grow to maturity...

That being said, for me as a PvE player there is not (yet) very much to do, going on missions or hunting ships on the open sea are the activities that i can do so far, but tbh, that´s exactly what i bought the game for. More PvE stuff is to come,like more mission types and other activities. Right now the production focus lied (and probably still lies) on the combat (pve and pvp) mechanics as well as economy/ trading and crafting, the latter being really complex already. So if you are a designated crafter, you´ll feel at home here as well...

the combat and sailing mechanics are what the game shines at. It takes a rather realistic approach. It features a manual aim system, where each gun type and also each ship has a certain way to aim...combined with the need to take your ships stability and the conditions of the sea into account, aiming takes a bit of practice. reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I am somewhat biased because I EFFING LOVE SHIPS. If I could go back in time and join the Royal Navy I would. I know the life was rough but the ships are so freaking awesome.

Anyway, this game is like a wet dream for me (no pun intended). I think there is still a lot of room for improvement but so far this game has really satisfied the need for a game centered around these type of old world naval combat.

The grind is REAL. XP does not come quickly or in large batches but you quickly become lost in the immersive details of the game. You literally have to run your ship and pay attention to everything that is going on. This game is almost like the DARK SOULS of boat games. It takes time, a lot of work and patience, but when you see those 3rd rates riding around decimating people left and right you know it is all worth it.

My notes to the devs:

-  More XP per PVE battle would be nice. it is 1000xp to the first rank after you start and ~50xp per battle is brutally slow especially when the battles can go on for over an hour (especially when the AI jerkoff bot keeps riding into the wind)

- Add collisions while roaming the open world. Force people to pay attention at all time. this would of course you to stop loading ships on top of each other as well.

- If you are in Sailing mode during battle I don't see why your ship wouldn't maintain the same speeds it does in the open world. Everything should be consistent. I would understand a penalty while being in another mode during battle.

- Please add the spyscope/telescope view to open world!

- When zoomed all the way in on the starting cutter the mast is directly in the middle of the view

- Better tutorial in the beginning. I had no idea how to earn XP or what to do other than drive the ship. Took a lot of outside research to figure out main objectives. I don't mind a challenge and figuring stuff out but i spent the better part of my first couple hours just riding around in the open sea aimlessly not knowing what to do.

- YOU ARE DOING A GOOD JOB KEEP IT UP YOU ARE MAKING MY CHILDHOOD FANTASIES COME TRUE

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Interesting game that takes place in the Age of Sail period between 1700-1800 ish. With very interesting open world features in and more content being added quite often. Expect a large patch soon that will change fundamental game mechanics for conquering other nations ports and added diplomacy between nations.

Its still in early development and it lacks a lot of finished and polished details but still very fun to play if you enjoy this period.

Start with a lowly cutter and fight your way up the ranks until you have earned the crew that allows you to outfit a 1st Rate Ship of the line Nelsons Victory, if you can find one.

You can also advance your crafting talents and become a ship builder that help your nation by supplying your fellow captains with ships for trading or cannon thunder, for a fee to be negotiated.

Or a shrewd trader that buys low and sells high, Transport needed goods from a port with a surplus to a port that lacks your commodity and is willing to pay a premium price.

The choices are yours, But remember The open sea can be a dangerous place. There be captains of other nations with whom you are at war, The smuggler who is trying to bring contraband to you or your enemies, or even the Pirates who wish to plunder your ship and cargo for a night in Tortuga with his ladies and rum bottles.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You've seen the trailers, right?

Few games really live up to its trailers and all its marketing nowadays. This one surpasses it. The realism is there, to a much higher degree than any even remotely similar game I have ever seen. You have your physics, the sea and the wind and the structure of your ship, to take into account in every move you make. You have your graphics, as beautiful as you could wish. And the immersion is there - every battle you fight counts, for good or for bad.

The ships range from the smallest cutters and schooners to the heavy first rate ships-of-the-line, and the variety in gameplay is enormous as you raise in the ranks. Furtheremore, the game offers other aspects of the naval Caribbean life than combat between nations - trading, crafting, plundering and politics.

This game already has ten times more to offer than the average AAA game, and so far the game has been growing furiously in both size and quality, from the match-based combat game it once was, during the Sea Trails, to the masterpiece it already is, despite a few bugs and a very rudimentary GUI. And this despite its still being considered an alpha version. It offers no tutorial as such, but instead it gives you a cutter to do with as you please, and which you can replace for free once you manage to sink it or blow it up. In my personal opinion, this is the best tutorial you could wish for.

And lastly, I know the price is by some people considered rather high for an early-access game, but I assure you: if you would be willing to buy any of those AAA games for 150% of this price, then you should not doubt going for this one too. And contrary to so many of those games, there has been no talk about any DLCs, suscription fees or any other of that crap yet. And that detail alone is very encouraging.

See you on the high seas, captain.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a 'pre-release Alpha' stage game it already has plenty of great content to justify 40+ hours of play.

But the current rough UI and less than stellar economic system is NOT the end vision, please check out the forums at http://forum.game-labs.net/ for some nibbles of the long term goals of player-driven economy and large scale conquest.

You will see alot of comparisons of this game to Eve online, these are not entirely unjustified as there are similarities of goal.  However this game is NOT EVE: Age of Sail, there are some sharp differences on all levels but the MOST IMPORTANT: Aiming matters.  This game is less excel 2.0 simulator and more sailing+broadside management.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you played POTBS I can easily recommend Naval Action.

If you did not, the first thing you should know is that everything in Naval Action takes very very long. So if you are the impatient type, you've been warned.. xD

The game revolves around PvP and a player driven economy like in POTBS. So if you like to play economy games where you make money by crafting and/ or selling stuff and are thrilled by the idea of competing with REAL people over the caribbean market instead of only predictable AI I can again easily recommend Naval Action.

PvP is the other reason why you would wanna buy Naval Action. PvP in this game is won by team play and teamspeak. It is strongly recommended to join a clan since working together will not only just bring victory but will also make getting ships and experience points easier. While 1v1 PvP and single gameplay is possible like preying on lonely players on the open sea the biggest parts are definitely big group battles and port battles. Port battles are fights for the ownerships of harbors of the caribbean. It is a bit like siege battles in total war but with players and on the sea instead of land.

PvE questing is as bare- bones as it can get. The only reason why PvE missions are in the game is to make money and gain XP. There are, however, PvE servers in Naval Action but I do wonder what the frek they're doing over there?? xD

I criticize, however, Naval Action for its use of ranks or player levels. You have to grind a long long time before you can sail bigger and more important ships while I leave it open to debate if bigger always means better?.. There sure are some roles for smaller ships to catch and stop hostile players from running away, for example. I like that there are shallow and deep water ports what makes smaller ships more important and gives players of a lower lvl a chance to partake in the more meaningful stuff of whast is going on on the conquest map. Same goes to crafting, you have to craft a whole lot of stuff you do not even want just to gain XP and advance in level. Furthermore, there's some stupid korean RnG mechanic which makes it very hard to get blueprints for certain ships sometimes.. (http://www.navalactioncraft.com/blueprints)

Basically, as a new player you will most likely run into a period of severe boredom but that only lasts for a while. There are so called 'fleeting groups' which are run either by PUGs or clans to gain money and XP faster. I suggest to look out for those if you get bored with the game!

Finally, always remember that this game is still in alpha! Since this is a full-blown PvP game players tend to forget the fact that this game isn't even in beta yet..

Some useful links:
http://forum.game-labs.net/
http://navalaction.wikia.com/wiki/Ships

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is pretty much EvE online meets Mount&Blade Warband meets Silent Hunter in 18th Century Carribean. This concept is something I have been dreaming of for years, and Naval Action is everything I could have hoped for. Vast and  disorienting at first, challenging, but also very rewarding. The devs have managed to strike a great balance between realism and accessibility, with controls that are relatively easy to grasp, though challenging to master. Graphics are beautiful, though I would like to see improvements in wake and bow wave effetcs. The inteface is still a bit clumsy, but it is functional. Even in its current Alpha stage, it is thoroughly playable and enjoyable, with great depth, challenge and immersion. If you liked any of its afforementioned illustrious inspirations, I could not recommend you try Naval Action warmly enough.  10/10.
