reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only been playing for about a week and have become hooked. This review share what IMO are the greatest pros and cons.

Pros
Great Open World. Some find this a con because it's easy to get lost in, but I enjoy sailing around trying to figure out where I am by visiting ports and determining which direction I need to go.
Epic port battles. Join a nation and protect your ports from being captured by other nations or pirates.

Cons
Underdeveloped port UI.  This game should not have been released before working on the UI. Apparently there are future plans to improve this but IMO this should have been top of the todo list.
No guide. You only have the forums, YouTube videos, and friends to learn from.  There are no in game tutorials or guides.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval Action is a unique and beautifully made game that gives you complete freedom over your destiny, you take your role as a captain in the west indies during the age of sail, you may simply want to trade or like me take enemy ships your prize.

The community is greatly helpful and i spent my first few hours talking to more experienced captains who were talking me through what I could take in my starter Yatch. After a few more hours I got to grips with navigation and once I worked out where I was I had to rely on map and compass, no player location marker in this game im afraid, you are forced to learn and adapt in this wonderful world.

After basing my now upgraded yatch at kingston I operate in 5 day tours in which I will go into enemy waters, take a prize and bring it back into kingston for my own gain. I am under the flag of the UK which means I mainly attack French and Spanish ships, attacking an English ship would make me a pirate!

I would recommend this game if you are intrested in the Naval history of this time and have an appetite for the learning curve, however you will not enjoy your experience if you are not willing to listen to more experienced players.

Thankyou for Reading!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have never had as much fun with an Alpha game, I have put in a lot of hours on this game, it is challenging, fantastic to look at and sometimes frustrating but always fun fun fun, The graphics are amazing, the sound of the ships and guns is fantastic, the stability of the client has been fantastic, PVP, PVE and port battles are truely awesome, the other players are fantastically helpful and supporting, one of the best communities I have ever played with.

This is a purely ship based game, you take command of your own vessel which you then use to either attack NPC's or other players to gain experience and gold, you can also board other ships and engage in option turn based combat, however you play this game you will enjoy it, there is a learning curve but the community will help you understand and learn the ropes quite literally.

The UI is currently pretty basic but the game graphics and gameplay more than make up for it, the best money I have spent on steam in a very long time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This may be the greatest PvP game I have ever played. And to be clear, I have played literally almost every MMORPG ever made, all on PvP servers, and all were pretty inadequate. My entire gaming career has been PvP, since the days of text based online MUDs. I'm old. Whatever.

Question 1: Do you like sailing ships? If no, then don't get this game.
Question 2: Do you enjoy war simulation" pacing? If you need constant action
date: then don't get this game.\nQuestion 3: Do you like PvP? If yes
recommended:
and if also yes to questions 1 & 2 then get this game.

I cannot speak as to whether PvE players will like this game. I feel the PvE content is not rich enough by itself. There is 1 PvE server (and 3 PvP servers) as of right now and I have no idea why anyone plays the PvE server.

Grind warning: there is some 'grind'. Your starter ship is limited fun and it may take you a dozen hours or more to really get out of it. That said
hoursPlayed: it is actually an effective PvP ship (no
voteText: seriously
helpfulPercent: try it in a group of like 5 of them and just go wolfpack hunting. You'll be surprised. To a big ship it's like being attacked by a swarm of killer bees) and you can participate in "Small Battles" off the Missions screen
votesHelpful: that are basically PvP arena/cage matches. These "Small Battles" aren't a focus of the game but for a new player they can be a way to hop into quick fights for gold and XP until you're ready to try the open sea.\n\nWhen you're ready for the real game
votesTotal: it's there
votesFunny:
and it's a pretty epic wargame. Imagine EVE if the combat didn't suck. Imagine Planetside with a world map strategy and resource control component. Imagine Pirates of the Burning Sea without the draconian "fair fight" mechanics that broke up your groups and guilds.

This IS early access.
Expect map wipes.
Expect gold and asset wipes.
Expect some crude interfaces for areas of the game that have not been fleshed out yet.
The devs have said they will never reset our XP but anything else is on the table.

If you can accept that then just get it. It really is the best GROUP FRIENDLY PvP experience I have ever had."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval Action is a hard core, age of sail naval warfare pseudo-simulator, emphasis on the Hard Core.

Firstly, it nails the whole alone on the ocean feel (when you get away from busy ports). Part of the gameplay is learning to navigate using only a map and compass. If you're looking for a real Age of Sail feeling type of game, this is it.

What Naval Action is not: easy. Naval Action isn't a Pirates of the Caribbean game and takes basically no cues from the movie franchise. Naval Action is more like Master & Commander than Pirates of the Caribbean. You could hunt a single enemy player for hours before engaging in an hour-long gunnery duel and boarding action.

Speaking of fighting, the combat is challenging, but fair, and the game doesn't try and hold your hand when you start. It takes a while to learn how to fight with the wind dictating your movement and with guns that have poor accuracy and slow moving projectiles, but nothing is as satisfying as landing a complete broadside and watching your enemy's armor become Swiss Cheese.

Notice that I said Pseudo-Simulator. It's hard to be an actual simulator and be fun, so there are some player gimmes, like teleporting between cities, but more complicated sailing manuevers such as controlling your yards individually and the accurate sailing model give a sense of complexity missing from other naval themed games.

However, there are two major caveats that Game-Labs gave up: The first is that you never have to sail at true speed throughout the Caribbean. There's an Open World overmap which you'll probably spend most of your time. In the Open World, the entire map is available for you to journey to but you can't fight in it and can't interact fully with your ship, and time goes faster, which in turn makes it seem like you aren't travelling at a snail's pace across the absolutely massive Open World map. When you reach a battle (either by attacking or being attacked), you'll transfer to a tactical Battle map where you move a true speed at true time and most of the simulator elements become available. If you've ever played Star Trek Online, think Sector Space vs. System Space.

The other caveat is that it is always windy. You'll never get stuck in doldrums or without a breeze, either in the strategic Open World overmap or in an instanced Battles. But that doesn't mean you can go in any direction you please, you still can't travel directly upwind, though fore-and-aft rigged ships will travel faster close-hauled than square-riggers. Yeah, you'll get to (or really, *have* to) learn some nautical sailing terms in this game, too.

The game is hard, and relatively unforgiving if you just think you can walk in and trounce the first enemy you see. Tactical planning is much more important that twitchy skill or APM. That being said, there are a ton of guides on the Game-Labs forums that will help you out on avoiding the major mistakes many players make. For good measure, I'll give you a first bit of advice: Don't go British.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval Action is a very addictive, slow-paced, deep game with plenty to do that all comes together to make for a very enjoyable experience that is best enjoyed in a group.

As it stands now, only about a week out of Early Acess, Naval Action is a healthy, promising game with a friendly and invested playerbase. The game focuses a lot on basing its mechanics on players' actions in the game world, and as such you can expect to see a vibrant world form as a result. The game's features are still being fleshed out so there is certainly still room to give players more control over the world they play in, but you see from developer's responses on the forums that they plan to give players the tools we need to make this world ours.

So what can you do exactly in Naval Action's giant sandbox? First off, you can fight basic battles with AI. These battles usually come in the form of 'missions', or Naval Action's equivalent to a quest. Missions simply order you to defeat the enemy at a given random location in the sea in exchange for bonus XP and gold. These rather mundane missions are the mainstay of the grinding experience for most players as it is a straightforward way to progress and gain the experience and gold needed to get the next best ship. Battles with the AI can also come in the form of hunting down AI trader ships or patrol fleets by yourself or with a group. Engaging with traders is a good way to try and make some money by “commandeering” valuable goods or ships, and engaging with patrols is a good way to get yourself killed; unless you bring friends.

You can also of course fight with other players. You can do organized PvP in the form of Small or Large battle queues that you sign up for every few minutes in any port, or you can hunt down players in the open world. You can also participate in large port battles with other players against other players to wrest control over cities and the resources they provide.

And of course, you can trade and craft in order to make lots of money. These latter options require a lot of knowledge and time to do right, but can pay in dividends. It is also important to note here that any decent ships you might wish to command must be player-made, and crafting ships is no small task. The economy of this game is one of great potential for the budding capitalist.

Combat as a whole is very well done in Naval Action. It is deep and too complex to go into detail here, but know that this is no arcade style ship game. It is slow paced, but can be incredibly intense, especially in PvP and in large battles. Ships are detailed and well designed, the open world is a delight to sail in, and there are plenty of friends and enemies to be made playing this game. I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone interested in games like EvE that maybe are looking for something more than context menus in their combat scenarios.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have had a lot of fun playing this game, there are still some little issues due to the fact its Early Access, you occasionally find bugs and strange things happening, graphics are also not optimised yet. The game itself has 3 core elements right now, trading, crafting and battles, each of these features have their own fun and challenge to them. The game can be played PVE or PVP, with most people playing PVP, I prefer PVE. Currently You can play one of 8 nations; Britain, France, USA, Denmark-Norway, Sweden, The Dutch, Pirates and Neutral, although Neutral is a bit lacklustre right now and Britain is vastly overpopulated.

The mechanics are similar to that of Assasins Creed: Black Flag and Empire/Napoleon Total war naval battles, feeling more like the naval battles from the two total war games, going beyond their level of realism. You can control sails individually or have it automatically done for you.

As a warning the game does not handhold, currently there are no tutorials and the UI hasn't been properly implemented yet, but the community is very welcoming and people are happy to answer questions to anyone on the in game chat, people are also often happy to show you the ropes of battle against an NPC to help you get started too.

The Future of the game includes a monthly update, adding new features and with a very active and engaging development team who do their best to take in suggestions and answer questions both on their own forums and the steam discussions page.

Personally I thoroughly enjoy the game, and will be keeping a close eye on it into the future, playing along with each period, checking out new features and being involved with the develpment as much as I can. If it continues on the trend it is on then I expect it to be one of my all time favorite games, I am glad to support it and praise it highly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:

Awesome ship combat, clearly the focus of the game.
Has big map with lots of cities, including not so common Carribean powers such as Denmark/Norway, Sweden, and the US.
Has missions, a trading system, and crafting.
I named my character Sir Francis Dank

Cons:
Cities don't have any textures yet so when you first load into the game you're just staring at some menus wondering if the game installed properly
The map is somewhat confusing, and needs work (but I mean it's early access)
I had to pay $40 (but I mean, how could I not?  Look at this game)
Isn't perfect yet.

Overall rating ignoring early access: 7/10
Overall rating acknowledging early access: 12/10 would spend another $40.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is really terrific.  It captures the essence of naval combat in the Age of Sail.  Tactics are complex and nuanced, and fighting does not become repetitious.

The open world is beautifully rendered, and the ships are also gorgeous.

There is a nice balance of PVP and PVE action, and the game caters to those who like PVP but doesn't really lend itself to griefers.

I have played quite a bit of EVE Online.  So far, I really prefer Naval Action, if for no other reason than the combat is a lot more engaging.

Can't recommned this game highly enough, especially for anyone who loves the Age of Sail.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval Action is a very addictive, slow-paced, deep game with plenty to do that all comes together to make for a very enjoyable experience that is best enjoyed in a group.

As it stands now, only about a week out of Early Acess, Naval Action is a healthy, promising game with a friendly and invested playerbase. The game focuses a lot on basing its mechanics on players' actions in the game world, and as such you can expect to see a vibrant world form as a result. The game's features are still being fleshed out so there is certainly still room to give players more control over the world they play in, but you see from developer's responses on the forums that they plan to give players the tools we need to make this world ours.

So what can you do exactly in Naval Action's giant sandbox? First off, you can fight basic battles with AI. These battles usually come in the form of 'missions', or Naval Action's equivalent to a quest. Missions simply order you to defeat the enemy at a given random location in the sea in exchange for bonus XP and gold. These rather mundane missions are the mainstay of the grinding experience for most players as it is a straightforward way to progress and gain the experience and gold needed to get the next best ship. Battles with the AI can also come in the form of hunting down AI trader ships or patrol fleets by yourself or with a group. Engaging with traders is a good way to try and make some money by “commandeering” valuable goods or ships, and engaging with patrols is a good way to get yourself killed; unless you bring friends.

You can also of course fight with other players. You can do organized PvP in the form of Small or Large battle queues that you sign up for every few minutes in any port, or you can hunt down players in the open world. You can also participate in large port battles with other players against other players to wrest control over cities and the resources they provide.

And of course, you can trade and craft in order to make lots of money. These latter options require a lot of knowledge and time to do right, but can pay in dividends. It is also important to note here that any decent ships you might wish to command must be player-made, and crafting ships is no small task. The economy of this game is one of great potential for the budding capitalist.

Combat as a whole is very well done in Naval Action. It is deep and too complex to go into detail here, but know that this is no arcade style ship game. It is slow paced, but can be incredibly intense, especially in PvP and in large battles. Ships are detailed and well designed, the open world is a delight to sail in, and there are plenty of friends and enemies to be made playing this game. I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone interested in games like EvE that maybe are looking for something more than context menus in their combat scenarios.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You would be hard pressed to find a more accurate age-of-sail game, and this is coming from the perspective of someone who has real life experience with square riggers.  The game mechanics in Naval Action are sufficiently realistic that you will find yourself using tried-and-true historical maneuvers.

That being said, the developers have managed to execute this rich realism in such a way that it is intuitive and easy to learn.  You can jump right in and start sinking ships, without first reading a treatise on sail theory.

The ship combat is absolutely stellar. It's complex, nuanced and involved. But it's not a fast game (I mean, it's Age of Sail naval combat). If you need Quake levels of intensity, this may not be for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impressions:
Good graphics and they seem fairly optimized.
Audio is good.
The UI is in need of an update, but thats one of things that were expected.

The sea fights are actually not much different from AC: Black flag in a number of ways, so it was fairly easy to get the hang of movement, shooting enemy ships, the boarding feature is like a turn based minigame, you get options to attack and you need to make sure you got enough crew to get the job done or it could easily go wrong.

did my first trip from one large island to another large nearby island without assistance, mostly about how much angle you put into it that could decide if you reach the other island or forever be lost in open waters.

anyway, this is what i have encountered in the 3 hours playing this game. lost two fights but i have already sunk a ship and almost succeeded in boarding another.

edit: After playing some more, the Boarding action is fairly simple, chain shot sails, grape shot crew and then take the ship, the weather system is easy to get the hang of, wind goes around in circles slowly, meaning it is predictable, there are several types of weather conditions including heavy rain, and fog both of which can seriously hinder your sense of direction if you just far enough away from land not to see it.

So far its been a positive experience after a fuirther 6 hours of play.

edit: continuing the rolling review, having dedicated some hours to the game, there is a grinding aspect to it, can get very repetitive.
what i do to lighten the load is find some ships to capsize, mostly a balancing act to tip the other ship over without yours going with it. so stil going well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impressions:
Good graphics and they seem fairly optimized.
Audio is good.
The UI is in need of an update, but thats one of things that were expected.

The sea fights are actually not much different from AC: Black flag in a number of ways, so it was fairly easy to get the hang of movement, shooting enemy ships, the boarding feature is like a turn based minigame, you get options to attack and you need to make sure you got enough crew to get the job done or it could easily go wrong.

did my first trip from one large island to another large nearby island without assistance, mostly about how much angle you put into it that could decide if you reach the other island or forever be lost in open waters.

anyway, this is what i have encountered in the 3 hours playing this game. lost two fights but i have already sunk a ship and almost succeeded in boarding another.

edit: After playing some more, the Boarding action is fairly simple, chain shot sails, grape shot crew and then take the ship, the weather system is easy to get the hang of, wind goes around in circles slowly, meaning it is predictable, there are several types of weather conditions including heavy rain, and fog both of which can seriously hinder your sense of direction if you just far enough away from land not to see it.

So far its been a positive experience after a fuirther 6 hours of play.

edit: continuing the rolling review, having dedicated some hours to the game, there is a grinding aspect to it, can get very repetitive.
what i do to lighten the load is find some ships to capsize, mostly a balancing act to tip the other ship over without yours going with it. so stil going well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played many games to a very high skill cap and this game in my opinion is amazing.  Its very in debth age of sail game that got the little things right.  You can be what you want trader, builder, exploreer, and open sea hunter as well.  I played Pirates of the Burning Sea back around 2009 and loved that game, much of the princples of that game are being implemented here.  The open world pvp is epic and the portbattle system as well.  Its not a instant gratification game like most people of my generation like, some battles can take over a hour, you have to earn your damage and kill.  If your at all into a open world pvp enviroment with high stakes and high skill pvp this is the game for you.  And its only in ALPHA AND ITS THIS GOOD.  Can't wait to see what it becomes.

Happy sailing.

www.twitch.tv/heskox1 if you want to see some game play

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval Action is not a perfect game.  It's still unpolished, with a rough UI, grindy and clunky level progression, repetative missions.  They just throw new players in, with no explanations or direction.  Obtaining even a moderate size ship is the result of many long hours of combat.  Battles are slow, with small ones taking 30 minutes and larger battles nearer to 90.  Sailing a ship to a distant port can take literal hours of tacking against the wind, with no navigational hints or visible land at where you are in the vast carribean, left guessing your position.

Yet still, this is the best game I have played in a very long time.  Just a few months ago, before I knew of this game, and in the middle of the Aubrey Maturin series, I found myself wondering Why isn't there a good

Early Access Review

hmm i will say i recomend this game for those who liked Sid Miers Pirates but always wanted to play it with others.

this is very simliar but also very diffrent.

here are some pro's and con's i put the cons first as i feel get past this and i think the pros will be worth it.


Cons:
has no easy way to find out how to do stuff like sail or use manual sails.

Has no location on Map thus making it hard for people who dont know how navigate.

Takes for ever to get most places (7hrs of game play from the French starting Zone to the NW French lands in US)

game is still in production so things like UI are not stellar

you can easly lose all your cargo if you forget to put it into your cargo hold in a port you dont have a outpost.

Starting Ship combat is very hard due to waves casueing shots to miss. (gets better in bigger ships)

Zerg nations like US/Brits make smaller nations harder to play

Can be as adictive as cocain.....

Pro's:
IS HIGHLY ADICTIVE played 141 hrs in last 2 weeks alone...

is not just a Sailing game it is also a factional Strategy game as well with nations declaring war and taking ports from others

the PVP is both exciting and fun.

allows for diffrent styles of play you could be a mercant or you can be a pirate or you can form your own clan into a Notional Navy reserve to protect your nation. you can do crafting of ships to make your money or you can lead your nation in war aganst another.  you can sail around hunting NPC fleets.

lots of diffrent ships to choose from that have there own Benfits or defects and allow for a player to find a ship that seeks his style of play better.




this game is not completed but it is damm good and playable even now. it can have a hard learning curve but i suggest spending a few hrs looking up Utube vid guides and you will learn all you need to know from this game.

for best enjoyment Join a non Zerg nation like the French/Sweeds/Danes/Dutch/Spain somtimes being a underdog just means u got more people you can kill :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good game.  There's crafting components & ships; there's trading up and down coastlines; and there's combat, both individial and group based.  The real fun is finding the balance between these three competing dictates.  The initial grind is hard and boring but is as needs must for you to become a competent captain.  Find a clan, learn the secrets and amass the cash & experience necessary to become a captain of a first rate ship of the line.
Plenty of forum and youtube available to learn the basics and gain proficiency.  In port (non ship) based UI is drab and boring, but is obviously only a placeholder.  Only negative is the 1hr server restart every day at 0700 hrs UTC.  Why they need this leftover from late '90's gaming is a mystery, but there it is.
One of the more expensive Early Access games out there, but certainly has it's addictive side.  You can easily find yourself 100 hours in barely a 3rd of the way to MOAR CANNONS.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

1. Best Age of Sail combat simulation there is.

2. The game is open world and has own server like an MMO where there are hundreds of players.

3. Play as Pirates, USA, Great Britain, French, Spanish etc.

4. The map is huge centering around the Gulf of Mexico, Bahamas and the Caribbean Sea and travelling across the map would take hours. Each of the 100+ port is conquerable.

5. Graphics are great. Sea and weather looks realistic and ships look detailed and authentic.

6. Wind condition plays important part in sailing, so are ship sailing profiles.

7. A large selection of ships, ranging from tiny cutters, to small brigs, to midsize frigates, and to large ships of the line, including the HMS Surprise, HMS Victory, and USS Constitution.

8. Trading & ship-crafting is also important in this game.

9. Some ships are only craftable by players, such as the trader ship Indiaman and other high grade ships.

10. A large selection of armaments, ranging from tiny 4 pd cannons to 308 pd mortars.

11. Combat, albeit slow paced, is very realistic and deliberate, down to the very details of boarding.

12. The game is early access but very playable, though the UI is a bit rough.

13. The game community is very helpful and active, and does regular port battles in large 10+ ship fleets.

14. The game is constantly improving and even if a bit expensive is worth the price for something so special.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: I've had Naval Action since very shorty after the closed beta started. I've played off and on since then, but I'm not an expert by any stretch of the imagination.

Naval Action is a game about the 'Age of Sail' that lasted from the 17th-18th centuries. You take command of any one of a number of sailing vessels, starting from cutters and yachts, to the largest Man-O-War. Most ship classes are named for ships that actually existed (you can't rename them as of now, and I don't know if that's planned), and a few from more realistic fiction also fill the roster. they can hold different numbers and sizes of gun, larger crews, reinforced planking, and all manner of other upgrades to set them up for your tastes. Nothing exists at the moment to change them astecticly, however.

As these are sailing ships, the weather  (naimly the wind) can be your best freind, or worst nightmare. if you have to head northwest, and the wind is coming out fo the northwest, it's going to be a long and slow slog up to your destination. Learning how to use the wind to your advantage will be the hardest challenge you face in Naval Action. You ship can take damage, and if shots hit below the water line, you're liable to start leaking. Masts can be shot off, rudders damaged, and crew can be killed with grapeshot from the ship's guns, Sails can be shredded to ribbons with chain-shot.

The game itself has a map that encompases the whole of the Carribiean, and parts of North and South America. There are ports for a number of nations, all of them currently at war, as well as ports where any ship may enter. There's Pirate ports (I've yet to find Nassau, though D:)  and Pirates coming out of them. You'll start off by sinking (or if you can manage it, capturing) these pirates, before venturing out to wage war with the other nations, or trading valuble (and sometimes illegal) commodities thoughout the world.

It's a game best left for the patient, it takes me a good half hour to get to Cuba from Charleston, and another ten mintues to get to Hati or Jamaica. The overworld map is pretty large, to say the least.

the graphics in this game are top-notch when in combat-mode, though are a bit simpler when in the overworld. The menus are far from complete (though even they have come quite a ways). The sound is suprisingly good for a yet-to-be-finished title. Get yourself a good set of headphones, and you'll be sucked in, with the sounds oc water and creaking wood in between the smoky roar of your deck guns.

Pros:
-The game is quite realistic - Wind makes a difference, and you can use it to your advantage.
-Looks georgious while in combat.
-Sounds georgious while in combat.
-You can sail the Suprise.
-Bigger ships do not always trump smaller ships (get on the stern of a frigate, and have the wind on him, and you can happily rake him in the backside all day long).
-PvE options for people to learn on, but while XP transfers to PvP Gold doesn't seem to (a nice tradeoff IMHO)
-Gives me a reason for having a whole playlist of Sea Shanites (Which I liked before I even knew about the game).
-You can get large numbers of players together for large naval battles, when everyone knows what they're doing, ti's a sight to behold.
-The Developers are really active in the community, and seem to enjoy us enjoying the game, which is nice.
-A large number of nations to choose from, depending on how you want to start out, and what you want your ship's flad to look like.

Cons:
-Realisim means that you can't go directly into the wind like AC4, you'll have to learn how to tack (this isn't as much of an issue for those who have sailed before like myself, but newcomers might want to watch a few tutorials Which I might even make a few myself)
-Larger ships with square-sails are complex to operate for the newcomer.
-No ship insurance built into the game as of yet.
-Not every command can be re-bound. The functions of the number keys come to mind, how I'd LOVE to set up a custom joystick to handle that instead, but it's a bit less conveiniant then I'd like for that.
-the overworld doesn't look quite as pretty as combat, and you will be spending time in the overworld a lot.
-no spyglass in the overworld, where you'd realllllly like to have it
-not optimized, which is to be expected, but those of you who cannot stand anything less then 60 FPS, turn back now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Age of Sail game that serious PC gamers have been waiting for.
It isn´t for casual gamers, the scale of the map is huge and navigation takes a significant amount of time.
The combat is excellent, and with each update every aspect of ship warfare is simulated with increasing fidelity.

There are a lot of people reviewing the game prematurely, or at least without any real understanding of the concept of early access, or certain decisions made with regard to the business model. 99% of these reviews are uninformed drivel. It becomes apparent very quickly that Naval Action is a labour of love, each ship is beautifully crafted in a way that honours the real world originals, the combat is intense, lumbering, yet somehow despite that slower pace is always edge-of-your-seat split-second decision making. Quite the feat really.

Most of the negative comments here come from the fact that the developers have decided to sell ´premium ships´ in order to pay for the very high capacity servers. Seems perfectly reasonable once you look at the details and reality, as opposed to simply get all hot under the collar because you want everything in life for free. The game world is huge, and to support that many players on one or two servers requires income other than the initial sales. The game is very reasonably priced, and there is no subscription fee. These ships aren´t pay-to-win. Stat-wise, they will be more or less the same as the normal ships, and unlike premium vehicles in other games it is possible to lose them (they can be sunk four times before they are permenantly lost). Seems reasonable enough to me.

Another reason some of the uninformed masses have complained here, seems to be the fact that there are no ingame tutorials or anything. It´s early access! All efforts are currently being directed towards creating and improving game mechanics. The UI, filler and content like more ship types will follow. Currently they are releasing minimum one new ship design per month.

If you understand this, then this game might be worth looking at in its current state. For all others, stay away from our baby.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been following the development of Naval Action since early alpha.

If the idea of open world realistically simulated 18th century sailing ships is your thing this game is definitely the one to check out. Quick Disclaimer: For people expecting arcadey Assasin's Creed IV - Black Flag gameplay - look elsewhere, this is not a game for you.

However if you don't mind the steep learning curve, and being sunk multiple times while learning how to fight an accurately modeled, painfully detailed sailing ship, how to tack into the wind, and sail using compass and stars, this is definitely a game for you.

Community is excellent, gameplay is fun, open world is beautiful and massive. If you would like to see more, check out some of the videos i made of the game (although taken at alpha - sea trials stage)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xZ7idHAxiqI&list=PLU2HTdReBtvIID03BqhZaWb0DZp_Om2Le

That being said, this is the Early accces game in the full sense of the word. Towns business, main gui, crafting, trading and anything apart from sailing, and battles is extremely basic. Most of the UIs are placeholders. Those that expect port business like in Sid Meier's Pirates will be disappointed for some time.

However the feeling of sailing the beautifully crafted open world and engaging in hectic sea battles either vs players or the AI, and mastering the sails is bar to none yet seen in this genre.

This game is one of the very few in early access that i wholeheartedly recommend to all sailing ship enthusiasts.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most certainly the first title to truly live up to its ambitions as an accurate and realistic naval combat simulator, this game is well-worth its price tag in its incredible high quality, immersive and historically deep gameplay and beautiful recreation of the age of sai and the ships of the era.

I have had the pleasure to be a tester for the game for a year, and even though she may not be a complete game thus far, Naval Action is one of my all-time favorites in my queue.

Naval Action takes historical ships from history and puts them at your feet with a wide array of countless different vessels that fit any playstyle any seaman may take. These ships include the HMS Surprise, a frigate whose replica may be found in San Diego, the super" frigate USS Constitution/"Old Ironsides"
date: the 1st rate HMS Victory which can be found in Portsmouth
hoursPlayed: whose replica presently sails around the US. The ships of Naval Action are beautifully rendered with mind-blowing graphics and incredible detail
voteText: bringing a new attractiveness to the era's fighting ships.\n\nA notable feature alongside ships in the game is crafting. Through a complex and realistic set of steps
helpfulPercent: players can craft their own ships as to tweak their construction to increase quality or fit their play styles. This makes the game incredibly fun as over time
votesHelpful: you can specially craft high quality ships that qualify as "dream ships". For example
votesTotal: my "dream ship" is a "speed-tweaked" HMS Trincomalee
votesFunny: a historical (and still around!) 52-gun Leda Frigate. She's very fast and manuaverable
commentsCount: and through efforts in crafting I produced my own "golden" version shaving down some of her armor in exchange for much greater manuaverability.\n\nNaval Action also does a very good job of accuratley and realistically simulating naval combat. Every single cannonball's trajectory is calculated- hits do not merely lower a ship's "health"
column16: but they bounce around
column17: knock over a gun carriage
column18: send splinters into crewmen and sometimes even bounce off the hull and hit other ships! To add
column19: the use of sail manuavers such as tacking
column20: heaivng to ect makes manuavering your vessel much more than using WASD. Historical strategies and manuavers can be easily recreated in the game- raking sterns as to try to disable rudders and to slaughter your opponent's crew with double shot
column21: reefing lower and upper topsails to avoid sail damage (otherwise known as "battle sails")
column22: using a heeling ship to get extra range
column23: firing lower in the water to do more hull damage and much much more.\n\nThe only notable flaws or tediums found in Naval Action thus far are few
column24: and not exactly game-breaking. The UI
column25: at the time this was written is still fairly bland. To add
column26: the game's economy can be punishing for those attempting to craft their own ships
column27: as parts are numerous and can be difficult to find. The overall pace of the game is fairly medium-slow
column28: which may make less patient players find themselves dissented with the game.\n\nHowever
column29: the pros so overwhelmingly outweight the cons. This game is a brilliant masterpiece
column30: and is well worth forty dollars as a true class A title.\n\nThanks for reading this long review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: I've had Naval Action since very shorty after the closed beta started. I've played off and on since then, but I'm not an expert by any stretch of the imagination.

Naval Action is a game about the 'Age of Sail' that lasted from the 17th-18th centuries. You take command of any one of a number of sailing vessels, starting from cutters and yachts, to the largest Man-O-War. Most ship classes are named for ships that actually existed (you can't rename them as of now, and I don't know if that's planned), and a few from more realistic fiction also fill the roster. they can hold different numbers and sizes of gun, larger crews, reinforced planking, and all manner of other upgrades to set them up for your tastes. Nothing exists at the moment to change them astecticly, however.

As these are sailing ships, the weather  (naimly the wind) can be your best freind, or worst nightmare. if you have to head northwest, and the wind is coming out fo the northwest, it's going to be a long and slow slog up to your destination. Learning how to use the wind to your advantage will be the hardest challenge you face in Naval Action. You ship can take damage, and if shots hit below the water line, you're liable to start leaking. Masts can be shot off, rudders damaged, and crew can be killed with grapeshot from the ship's guns, Sails can be shredded to ribbons with chain-shot.

The game itself has a map that encompases the whole of the Carribiean, and parts of North and South America. There are ports for a number of nations, all of them currently at war, as well as ports where any ship may enter. There's Pirate ports (I've yet to find Nassau, though D:)  and Pirates coming out of them. You'll start off by sinking (or if you can manage it, capturing) these pirates, before venturing out to wage war with the other nations, or trading valuble (and sometimes illegal) commodities thoughout the world.

It's a game best left for the patient, it takes me a good half hour to get to Cuba from Charleston, and another ten mintues to get to Hati or Jamaica. The overworld map is pretty large, to say the least.

the graphics in this game are top-notch when in combat-mode, though are a bit simpler when in the overworld. The menus are far from complete (though even they have come quite a ways). The sound is suprisingly good for a yet-to-be-finished title. Get yourself a good set of headphones, and you'll be sucked in, with the sounds oc water and creaking wood in between the smoky roar of your deck guns.

Pros:
-The game is quite realistic - Wind makes a difference, and you can use it to your advantage.
-Looks georgious while in combat.
-Sounds georgious while in combat.
-You can sail the Suprise.
-Bigger ships do not always trump smaller ships (get on the stern of a frigate, and have the wind on him, and you can happily rake him in the backside all day long).
-PvE options for people to learn on, but while XP transfers to PvP Gold doesn't seem to (a nice tradeoff IMHO)
-Gives me a reason for having a whole playlist of Sea Shanites (Which I liked before I even knew about the game).
-You can get large numbers of players together for large naval battles, when everyone knows what they're doing, ti's a sight to behold.
-The Developers are really active in the community, and seem to enjoy us enjoying the game, which is nice.
-A large number of nations to choose from, depending on how you want to start out, and what you want your ship's flad to look like.

Cons:
-Realisim means that you can't go directly into the wind like AC4, you'll have to learn how to tack (this isn't as much of an issue for those who have sailed before like myself, but newcomers might want to watch a few tutorials Which I might even make a few myself)
-Larger ships with square-sails are complex to operate for the newcomer.
-No ship insurance built into the game as of yet.
-Not every command can be re-bound. The functions of the number keys come to mind, how I'd LOVE to set up a custom joystick to handle that instead, but it's a bit less conveiniant then I'd like for that.
-the overworld doesn't look quite as pretty as combat, and you will be spending time in the overworld a lot.
-no spyglass in the overworld, where you'd realllllly like to have it
-not optimized, which is to be expected, but those of you who cannot stand anything less then 60 FPS, turn back now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval Action is the best you're going to get if you're going for a historic naval game.
Many people complain about the grind that is Naval Action, but this is for the best, It's a simulator and sailing will take long, battles will take long, because that's just the way it was back then.

This game does not take the casual approach many game developers take these days, It's not made for you just to shoot some ships and quit after a week. Sailing around the caribbean is not danger free, you will get attacked if you do not pay attention, and you will lose your ship. Other way around, you can take ships.
(On the other side of the grind, If you own a decent ship, getting money is as easy as taking candy from a baby.)

Many people complain about the developers because they don't listen" to the community

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was apprehensive about buying this game in early access because I've been burned by EA games before. But I'm glad I finally bought it.

-The combat in this game is solid naval combat. Except for the poor looking boarding menus. Boarding works but it isn't fun and they'll have to change it for it to be fun.

-It is open world and kind of reminds me of POTBS MMO if any of you played that.  There is a map but it doesn't ping your location so you have to rely on terrain and your compass right now. Also the missions are indicated by crossed white swords which can be hard to see during the day ( I suggested they change the color of those).

-The port screen is ugly but fully functional. It does have a little messege saying Test UI please ignore so it will change. Making it pretty is something probably low on their priority list and that is ok.

-The ships are beautiful but I'd like to see more customization of colors on the wood/designs, possibly sail color (but not a big deal), and a maybe a custom captain avatar sailing the ship. Right now every ship is the same color in its class, the deck's cannons do change style depending on what you have equipped,  and there is a very generic crew representation (which is ok enough for me, but some might want more here).

-Sound effects and smoking cannons are great but the game doesn't have a music track yet, so I use my own in the background.

-there is crafting, trading, and gathering resources to build ship which is nice. There is even a chance at making better ships such as exceptional.

-there is clans, PvP, PvE, and co-op play so it has it all there. Not only can you craft, sell/buy ships, but you can also capture them in combat which is always nice(again boarding isn't fun right now though).

Overall I enjoy  the game because I like naval combat and love playing it with friends over voice chat. However I also like customization and role playing which is lacks, but I can see them building on. I can see this game going a long way and recommend in its alpha state if you want a good naval combat game with the understanding the RPG element of it is growing and not complete yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY ACCESS  ( things will change )

...at this moment in time...

Basically you sail around the Caribbean fighting, trading, crafting, in packs or solo for your chosen nation


Combat

When you attack someone in the open world you are drawn into an 'instance' pretty much like Elite Dangerous.
There are a few Rules of engagement that are constantly being adjusted to try to help the lesser combatants so not much point commenting on those here as they're likely to change from one week to the next.

Exeptional combat model that has only got better with time from the devs' and input from the community.
Easy to get into if you are able to tie your own shoe laces but also complex enough to take time to master.

Beautiful models sounds and sea textures.

The combat model is pretty much the only thing that is near 100% finished and unlikely to change much and it shows, when comparing it to the rest of the 'game'...  it's simply stunning and even more so when you start to appreciate the subtleties.

9/10

Trading

Trading all revolves around resources and materials for building ships.
To be honest it's very, very simple but it's still being fleshed out.
I would like to see a massive economy driven trading system not just about materials for ships, but based around real items that were traded in the set time period.

2/10

Crafting
Very strange crafting model that is very dull and a little RNG
I'm not even sure it should be in at all but as with most things this will change and hopefully improve vastly.

1/10

Naval Action has the potential to be an absolutely stunning title that gives you a hint of what it was like to be in combat at sea in the set time period.

I do recommend the game but... only to those people that are intelligent enough to understand it's not a casual game and requires considerable time investment all in a half finished title. It's probably why the price is hefty in an effort to weed out the less passionate gamers given everyone has an input in the developement.

Footnote
Player numbers peak after major updates and fall before them as they wait for content injection or character wipes, it's not uncommon and can happen from time to time...currently we are waiting for an update which is why the numbers are dropping.
The experienced players aren't playing, not much point if you've played/tested everything so far and it will get wiped next week so don't take much notice of reviewers claiming the end of the world and the game is dying it's just the usual ebb and flow of early access


I shall return to this review in the future...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval action is a early access public alpha that takes place in there sailing era of between 1600-1800 in the Caribbean.

The main premise of the game is to bring the age of sail to people who love naval combat.

Pros: a massive MASSIVE map to explore, raid, trade or sink you way around in ships ranging from the civilian to heavily armed warships.
Great amount of factions instead of just Britain, Spain, Netherlands and France. There are 8 at this time.
Combat is heavily based on three things. Which is good. Speed, skill and teamwork. ( a group of small ships working in unison can literally sink a 3rd rate warship.)
The Dev team have clearly done their research by reflecting the fact that the amount of guns didn't always win.
A trade system which works on supply and demand much like Port Royale franchise. It is hard however as prices don't stay the same as players and wars affect both.

Cons: there is no marker on the map to show your position in relation to mission markers. (I had a mission near Jamaica but I found that I was next to Bermuda)
There is no way points to help with navigation which both these points can cause huge stress when trying to get to your mission. Especially when you get storms around you.
There is no way to test drive ships to see if they are for you and you how they are played.
Base resources are too expensive and experience gain from battles is low. It takes 20 missions to get 1000 experience points.
You should be able to ring the ships bell any time with each button press to ring it. ( make use of morse code)
There should be a progression table to show what you gain from promotions.

It is highly function and extremely thrilling with combat and sailing physics and cannon and projectile physics too. It is worth as an early alpha £25-£35 due to its currently working and huge amount if features alongside a already vast community and friendly and dedicated Dev team.

Don't ram a ship bigger than yours. You'll be shoved over with leaks in you're boat.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a lot of promise, if you like sailing ships then this might be the game for you, however this is early access, there is quite a few problems and bugs as you should expect from an early access game.
However, the devs do try their best to help. Eg, I got stuck because the game spawned me in shallow water, within 10 mins of me posting on the forums, a dev had responded and sorted the problem for me.

Pros:
-Good Graphics and sounds
-Realistic ship/combat mechanics
-Nearly everything in game can be crafted
-Runs pretty well on low end computers
-Alot of different ships, from small cutters up to 1st Rates ship of the lines
-Different ways to play. PvP, PvE, trading or crafting.
-Great dev support.

Cons:
-Can take hours to get somewhere
-Alot of grinding to get the better ships
-Gankers (when I first started I kept getting attacked by someone in a vastly superior ship, had to quit and go with a more      powerful nation)
-No ingame tutorial

Community (from British point of view)
-Big clans control nearly everything, they tend to give ports to allies without informing the lower players who use those ports. I understand we needed to give our allies the ports, but there is no way ingame to notify the players who use that port unless you log in everyday.
-Players control too much, For example, USA is getting owned atm by the pirates (who for some reason are classed as a nation) and Sweden nearly got wiped out by the french and danes.
-Most player will try to come to your defense if you're attacked (if you're close enough)
-Teamwork is needed to survive

If you want a game where you can just jump on for an hour or so and shoot people with massive warships, this is not the game for you, it will take days to get to the bigger ships.

If you want a game where you have to work hard, be part of a large community, help defend your nation against all her enemies, then this might be the game for you.

8/10

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

I have put in the hours so can give a accurate account of the game as it currently stands.

It is a beautifully impressive game, ship models are perfectly recreated right down to the flaking paint, the sea and weather is some of the best I have seen in game, and the battles , well you have to fight the urge not to literally duck under your computer desk when huge balls of iron come directly at you.

Unfortunatley, there is little more than just that, sailing which takes a long time, battles which take a long time, buying resources to craft new ships which take a long time, ranking up to crew those ships which takes, you guessed it, a long time.

Promise of more content now appears to be a pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. This leaves fighting AI ships which can do things that you will never be able to do such as almost turn on the spot with no regard to wind and fire rapid single shots as fast as an Uzi. Or you can join a clan and go PvP. From my time playing this is an experience of being bossed about a lot and players b*tching and moaning, then there is the fact of very few other players to fight so battles are always unfairly balanced. You are stuck to one server, if you move you only move your xp, no ships, no gold. On the server I originally chose the player count fell from 1200 in January to 150 when I last played in April. In fact they are now in the process of closing that server down rather than looking at the cause of player desertion.

When I first thought of this game I was told the community was good and helpful and in game I will say whole heartedly that is the case. Whereas the forum is rather a dictatorship where if you post anything unliked by the developers or moderators they will either lock the post or erase it.

I have stopped playing this game now, purley as since a recent update the battles are too hard. I am not a navy warfare mastermind or a particularly skillfull games player and without that the game has nothing. Everytime when I log into Steam I hope to see a content download for this game but it has been almost a month now and nothing has happened. Saying all this, I am glad I bought the game because I did manage to get  a beautiful screenshot of a ship bursting through heavy waves and I use this as my desktop wallpaper.

As it stands I have to give this a reluctant no, too high price for too little content

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've purchased this game quite recently at the time of posting this review, and the negative reviews posted right before did make me waiver. I'd like to go over why I am so happy that I decided to try the game for those that waiver as I do.

I've played Sid Meier's Pirates for well over 1k hours before it was added to steam, this game sort of comes across as a much more in depth MMO version of that. Choose a nation, participate in PvE missions (small and large scale), capture ports of Pirates or other nations for your nation, fight people or capture traders/player ships in the open world, participate in a player driven economy. All of these aspects of the game accompanied by fantastic feeling combat and a true sense of accomplishment along the way, something I've found missing in a lot of games.

It's true that you don't show up as an X on the map, and must use your compass as well as landmarks to get around. I have yet to get lost (perhaps other than a couple minutes of questioning my exact location), and honestly navigation feels great and after a day of playing I could find missions far off of land easily.

There are several nations as well as pirates, and each one feels like a unique community. As you play throughout the day you see server wide messages of port battles, cities being conquered, you see in global chat people mentioning huge expensive ships being captured by pirates. The world feels alive, actions seem to matter and when you see a first rate ship sail by or you see people taking part in these huge battles with huge perma-loss risks and rewards, it excites a new player to want to continue.

I already feel part of a national effort, I already feel a sense of accomplishment after getting a new ship and crafting enough to make a lot of gold. The combat feels fantastic, and though 10+ minutes may feel slow to a lot of people for missions, it never feels artificially slow. Each mission is still fun to me, fleet missions feel rewarding and sailing back to port with the risk of pirates jumping me and taking all of my rewards is honestly fun to me. (though very rare, but the possibility is there)

I'm very happy that I'm playing this game, though it seemed hard at first it very quickly became a fluid and fun experience. Though people said missions were super slow, nothing has felt anything but natural and entertaining. This is a game that feels rewarding, the faction system makes me feel like I'm a contributing member and honestly this is the pirate game I've been wanting for years. I hope the development keeps going strong and adding more, but either way I've already gotten more out of this than a lot of games and plan on continuing for quite a while.

Currently as of writing this, the best advice I was given before playing was to pick EU PvP 1, even as a North American player. There is no noticeable ping in game, especially with the slower pace, and the national politics and action make for a great playing experience.  A definite recommend in its current state, May 20th*, subject to change of course.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Originally, I gave this game a huge thumbs up and highly recommended it to all who would listen. What was an amazing game with a lot of potential is turning into a lame duck.

Combat is taking a serious turn for the worse as they are trying to move toward a more 'historic' approach to naval battle which seriously reduces the amount of damage done to enemies. No longer can you do damage at 200 meters or further from ships. Group pvp is now more of solo-within-group pvp as you can only have so many people within 200 yards of enemy ships with an angle to penetrate. Battles which were once exciting and skill-based are turning into hours-long snoozefests where you literally have to be almost on top of another ship to damage them.

While they may tweak this to (I'm sure they will?) reflect the desire of the player base as a whole, it is indicative of the attitude of the developers. It is obvious that they are making the game that they want to make, regardless of the appeal to the larger gaming community in general or in regard to the opinion of those who they allowed to PAY to test and give feedback.

Boarding combat is extremely uninteresting and detracts from the game. It is basically a PC version of rock/paper/scissors. All the suspense of childrens game with the graphics to match. The ship cannon combat graphics are awesome, but the boarding graphics don't even have crew representations, it is literally a text screen/overlay that pops up and reports the results of the 'hidden' boarding battle.  Some ships have a numerical crew (listed in your HUD) of up to 1200+, but when you board it shows an empty deck while the battle 'rages' in text.

Since the steam release the in-port UI screen has literally been a blue screen with absolutely no graphics. It is about as close to a MUDD based game as you can get and has been that way for the last 3 1/2 months. Instead of taking the time to remedy such an obvious blemish to the game that they are charging $40 for, they are more interested in breaking things that are already working well, such as the combat system.

Finally, the game is a serious time sink that doesn't allow you to just log on for 30 or 45 minutes and accomplish something. You literally need to commit to 2 or 3 hours to really have an opportunity to enjoy yourself. Out of those 2 or 3 hours half of that time will be you sailing around waiting for the fun to happen. Speaking of mind-numbing, the time it takes to sail in between ports is fantastically slow. I have watched butter melt that was more interesting. For someone with ADD/ADHD, this game could possibly be used as a torture device. Handcuff them to a computer desk and make them 'explore' in a 'historical' sense.

The developers are choosing to ignore testers (who paid to help test their game) for voicing opinions in an attempt (most of the time) to help shape this game. Well, I was a believer and advocate for this game, not so anymore. They seem to only want to listen to those individuals who give them the answers they are looking for, essentially the 'yes men.'

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Difficult but rewarding. You don't need to know a bunch about sailing to get good at this game, but it certainly won't hurt you to know either.

The statement that it's some kind of professional simulator is a bit silly, but it's got some nice physics and mechanics for combat.

Manual aiming of guns and option to command a broadside or fire each cannon in sequence. The details they put into the models even though it's in Alpha/Early Access is impressive.

The game is visually pleasing in my opinion. Though I imagine they'll improve it as time goes on.

The devs put out a lot of content regularly and try to communicate with the players. Does not seem like they'll just leave once they get tired of listening to us complain.

Only downside that I can see is that it takes a long time to do some simple stuff. Some folks would rather see some more immediate action, but it's not impossible (or uncommon for that matter) to go for a 30 minute span looking for a fight but finding none.

PvE is the majority of my experience because I'm on a PvE server, but you get to keep your experience you earn (just not the equipment/gold/crafting levels/ships) when you swap to the PvP server.

Navigation requires you to understand how to use a compass and map in concert. There is NO map marker to tell you where you are and there is not indicator besides a general marker on the map for where your mission will be taking place.

Overall I recommend this game because it's very fun and somewhat addictive. Leveling is a chore, but frankly I like that because it's better than everyone being in high end ships all the time. The sense of achievement is good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My first game review, though I own many games on steam.
The reason for this is Naval warfare in the age of sail is close to my heart.

Firstly, like many others have said, the graphics are very pretty, which nice on its own, does also lend a sense of immersion.
So I hope graphically it continues to to be the way it is so far.

There is a few choices of nations, to start, which cant be a bad thing, some reportedly are underplayed, but there is time im sure to balance that out, though some will always be the underdogs in a way, as they might of been historcially, due to various influences.

I have seen people knock the game so far for not having a tutorial, well, there are many video's on youtube and also in my opinion, there isn't a lot of complex mechanics going on in the game at present. As for the complexity and realism of sailing an age of sail warship and gunnery, there is information all over the internet. The game doesn't hold your hand in many respects and I personally like that, for instance, you dont see where you are on the sea, you have to work it out yourself. But I hope they can introduce somehow realistic mechanics, maybe a sextant, the sun, stars, or similar to add to realism, for navigation.

The game map covers the caribbean, whilst large it's not something you can get lost in for days, but I have heard it takes  several hours real time to sail it's width, wind dependant I assume.

The interface currently is really basic, hopefully that will improve and be polished.

You can dock in ports, which is represented in port by an interface, no avatar combat or walking around port. You can buy and sell in other ports and I think there is organised warfare between nations on some scale.

Naval Action, has the beginning of possibly a great niche game, one that I think many people may want to play, it looks beatiful, the sailing and gunnery seem realistic. It remains to be seen how the game develops in a broader sense, with trading, crafting, warfare and the meta game, but the nuts and bolts of the game seem well established.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is early access, let's start there.  There are bugs.  There will be changes.

I have participated in this game since the Sea Trials a year or two back.  The combat has continuously gotten more detailed, and new features have been added.  The economy, for now, seems to closely mirror that of Pirates of the Burning Sea.  The combat focuses on realism wherever possible.

The map is huge.  It takes hours to sail from one end of the Caribbean to the other.  The conquest mechanics are in development still, but the foundations are there, and seem to work well.  Each nation seeks to localize and then dominate their area, with forays out into other territory.  All is driven by control and commerce.

If your inspiration comes from the likes of Patrick O'Brian or C.S. Forester, this game is for you.  If you want to zip around and rehash Pirates of the Caribbean, it probably isn't.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is released as an alpha access, and it shows. On top of that, they peddle it for 39.99. The game is said to be a beautiful realistic experience, but most of it is portrayed in spreadsheet type layouts. The layouts spill over the sides of my moniter when set in its native resolution so that I can't read costs correctly, the UI is very wonky and seems to have little organization involved.

Having said these things, the combat, once you learn how to do it, is quite realistic and a bit fun. The combat is definitely what this game has going for it.

Overall the game didn't meet the expectations it sets, and the only thing justifying the purchase at the 40$ price tag is promise of the game costing more in the future for content which might be developed in the future.

I sent in a refund request and hope it gets fulfilled because I could spend 10$ on Sid Meier's Pirates! and get a much more exciting, immersive, fun game set in the 'most beautiful period of naval history - when sailing ships ruled the seas.'

I wanted this game to be good, but it's just not there, and it's not worth 40$ as is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Have had the game during early days when it was available only as a paypal bought option at the Sea Trials stage. I did mess around with the open world starting points when those came out. But, was a bit more difficult at the time due to mass packs of enemy AI running around. Currently, I'd say the devs have some work ahead of them.
Nothing insurmountable or even that difficult that I would say they have to do. I have yet to really see anything that could be a bug or even be considered game breaking. Damage modeling is exceptional, and doing targeted shots can be very useful.
. Not a run and gun shooter or action game. Combat involves ensuring position prior to going into a fight, and using strategy, tactics, proper formation use, and pure skill at manuevering a ship. If you want something that is a slight challenge, with sandbox attributes, and a good solid community then this is one of those games. I would rank the community as being close to if not on par with the great community EvE has built over it's many years.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really wait .. the devs are looking for a handout on an unfinished game.   The GUI is all blocks.  The game has this durability factor that you lose a ship and you lose the ability to play it.  The commerce is not working well.  You fight a ship for 30 minutes and some guy just pops in boards your almost demasted enemy ship and steals the booty.   Really the game will probably never be finished.   When Devs like this steal in to Steam to get early release it is because their funding has run out the investors pulled out... Steam has become the entitlement depot for half finished games!!!

Early access or not this game is asking you to pay $29 USD for a game that is only about a small instance combat mode.  Well done possibly but they are not trying to layers together a game on top of that effort that is not functioning.   If all you want to do is shoot cannons with a deck view against AI ships then go ahead and pay for it.  If all you want to do is shoot cannons at another player in a small room then go ahead and pay for it.  If you interested in an immersive game that captivates your overall ambition to be a master of a vessel and dominate with your freinds other players in a small room with out an objective then the game is finished for you.

The other layers of this game commerce is somewhat functioning if you can find a safe spot.  Otherwise you have to spend hours waiting for the wind to change to get into port safely.

Your best bet is to kill AI ships and steal their cargo to build that big ship and fight in the small room instance.  Hope you dont get caught trying to go to port to sell the loot.

Attacking cities happens way too easily.  Maybe 5 or 6 fall in less than an hour.  I am sure there wil be changes to this.  It is often boring with nobody but one side attacking.  Getting to the defense of a city you are not already right next too in this game is next to impossible.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of my first reviews because this game deserves it

Firstly the developers have obviously put a lot of thought in to this game and continue to add fixes and patches, really great work on their part. I was scepticle with this game at first I've tried games alike to this in the past and although they were good there was nothing that made them gripping, this game seriously has it all.The graphics are actually amazing for this game, they also keep adding little tweaks which make them more intense as the patches come out. The clans are great use and you are part of nations opposing every other nation, get in the right clan and its 24/7 game play.

You can play this game in several ways depending on what you want to achieve. You can play as a trader and make your money, you can also combine that and be a crafter making ships for others to buy from you. The crafting aspect is actually very good, one being that you don't just get automatic rights to craft anything you like, it creates more thinking and a tech tree to follow, one part makes this part and you only get a certain amount of labour you can use per hour which means people can't gain silly amounts of advantage. Also you have to craft certain types of ships with just a small % of a chance you'll get the blue prints to other ships meaning it takes time and tactic to be able to craft different ships.

Now if you go for the battle side this is a very broad game play. We have port battles, PvP or just plain old hunt the AI. I must admit alot of thought has gone into this; you need to be able to think, control and watch. The devs keep patching this area and adding or smoothing out the tweaks and doing an amazing job for it. When sailing in battle you have to think which direction you are going, where your sails are pointing how much sail you have, how many people on guns, how many people on plugging leaks. It really is in depth as a game gets for this area you quite literally can control everything.

Overall I would extremely recommend this game and urge anyone thinking to get this. The price tag is worth it!!! Constant patches and planned improvements that are set this game to be one you won't get bored on. I've clocked so many hours and the worst part is I never saw those hours go by, its truly addictive when you join the right clan community; my main tip is to join a clan to maximise every aspect of this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Have had the game during early days when it was available only as a paypal bought option at the Sea Trials stage. I did mess around with the open world starting points when those came out. But, was a bit more difficult at the time due to mass packs of enemy AI running around. Currently, I'd say the devs have some work ahead of them.
Nothing insurmountable or even that difficult that I would say they have to do. I have yet to really see anything that could be a bug or even be considered game breaking. Damage modeling is exceptional, and doing targeted shots can be very useful.
. Not a run and gun shooter or action game. Combat involves ensuring position prior to going into a fight, and using strategy, tactics, proper formation use, and pure skill at manuevering a ship. If you want something that is a slight challenge, with sandbox attributes, and a good solid community then this is one of those games. I would rank the community as being close to if not on par with the great community EvE has built over it's many years.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really wait .. the devs are looking for a handout on an unfinished game.   The GUI is all blocks.  The game has this durability factor that you lose a ship and you lose the ability to play it.  The commerce is not working well.  You fight a ship for 30 minutes and some guy just pops in boards your almost demasted enemy ship and steals the booty.   Really the game will probably never be finished.   When Devs like this steal in to Steam to get early release it is because their funding has run out the investors pulled out... Steam has become the entitlement depot for half finished games!!!

Early access or not this game is asking you to pay $29 USD for a game that is only about a small instance combat mode.  Well done possibly but they are not trying to layers together a game on top of that effort that is not functioning.   If all you want to do is shoot cannons with a deck view against AI ships then go ahead and pay for it.  If all you want to do is shoot cannons at another player in a small room then go ahead and pay for it.  If you interested in an immersive game that captivates your overall ambition to be a master of a vessel and dominate with your freinds other players in a small room with out an objective then the game is finished for you.

The other layers of this game commerce is somewhat functioning if you can find a safe spot.  Otherwise you have to spend hours waiting for the wind to change to get into port safely.

Your best bet is to kill AI ships and steal their cargo to build that big ship and fight in the small room instance.  Hope you dont get caught trying to go to port to sell the loot.

Attacking cities happens way too easily.  Maybe 5 or 6 fall in less than an hour.  I am sure there wil be changes to this.  It is often boring with nobody but one side attacking.  Getting to the defense of a city you are not already right next too in this game is next to impossible.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I started playing this game a few weeks ago. And it's all I was looking for.
Gameplay is interesting as you start with one small ship and have to choose a Nation to be part of.

You can trade, fight and craft, or buy (with ingame money earned by trading or fighting) new ship to use for when you are moving up in ranks.

The game can be time consuming in a good way. It's a multiplayer game with a good community.
I highly recommend this game if you like historical based games.

The developers and the community are very involved in the evolution of the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

11/10

For a game thats still in Alpha its superb.  Has very playable content with VERY few bugs.  Its immersing and fun, but most importantly its CHALLENGING!  Some people argue that its empty in terms of content and a 'grindy' game which is true  (hello?  Still in alpha!) but personally I don't mind the grind at all as every battle there is a good chance you will sink if fighting a bigger ship or even 2v1!  You can group up with friends or randoms and battle against large AI fleets that cruise the waters and have epic scale fights, or have a chill and do some trading and crafting.

Not for the type of gamers who want to blow everything up and own at battles within 15 mins.  Takes a long time to master the mechanics or sailing and aiming effectively and each time you advance in rank and get a new ship you have to re-adjust your skills to fit the new speed/turn/gun placements.  The detail they have put into combat is fantastic, and you have to pay attention to a lot of factors to stay ahead of the enemy to win.  and for such an early game combat looks fab!

If you liked cids pirates and such you'll love this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In some ways acting as a successor to Pirates of the Burning sea, Naval action is a far more realistic voyage into naval combat. The game has a large focus on trade, and the major nations must struggle for control over all of the major trading ports in their attempt to acheive naval superiority. Large scale naval battles are acheived in a grand fashion, with beautifully rendered oceans, and ships. Smoke billows off of freshly fired cannons, and drifts away slowly with the breeze.

Battles in Naval action require a bit of practice, and an understanding of basic seamanship will help asspiring captains greatly. The action here is slower than many games, and requires a bit of tactical positioning; it is critical that players learn to use the wind to their advantage if wishing to avoid destruction.

Naval action is still in early access and has a number of issues at the moment.
While the game is lovely, this graphical fidelity comes at a performance cost; further optimizations will hopefully reduce the strain on mid-range systems such as my own, but with my rig the game is perfectly playable. The UI leaves much to be desired as well, as the developers have opted to use a placeholder GUI while they work on core mechanics. This issue should easily be resolved in the coming months.

CPU:i5-3750k 2.6ghz - OC 4.0ghz
Nvidia Geforce 660ti
16gb ddr3 ram

While It might not be for everyone, I personally rate Naval Action at ~ 9/10.
Technical issues keep me from giving it a perfect score, but I fully expect those to be resolved at a steady pace.
