reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having aspirations to become a naval officer and chagrined I will likely never have the chance to captain a warship under independent command (given my country's pitifully small navy), I took great interest in Naval Action. While rather pricey for a game still in an open alpha, the game itself is quite fun – with new content being added regularly.

While still a game in active development with quite a few flaws and the sometimes painfully repetitious grinding for higher ranks/manpower/resources to make components to construct ships, the freedom afforded in the game is outstanding. Learning optimal angles to sail in the wind, manoeuvring to ripple off broadside after broadside at foes with great plumes of gunsmoke obscuring your vessel, your battleline - and ominously, that of the enemy. The ability to board an enemy vessel to take a grand prize for yourself and the crew. This game exudes the spirit of the Napoleonic era.

More than that, nothing quite beats the exhilaration of participating in a PVP fleet action in a wee 7th rate cutter against 4th and 5th rate enemy ships.  The stark terror of the sea about your small ship awash from a 25-gun broadside of 18 pound shot, with a mere six-gun broadside of 6-pounder shot to reply with.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA steadily improving attempt at historically accurate naval warfare simulation, set in a beautiful open-world carribean. It has a long way to go before it's worth the $54 CAD (as of this writing) price tag, but if you're a fan of the period or with naval combat in general, I recommend picking this one up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow! So for early access this game would be great as if they did nothing else! Very suprised at the game mechanics, graphics, MMO fluidity, and trading system.

So what for some of the positives:

1) Easy Chat for Nation, global or learning.
2) Smooth Battle sequences and transition into them.
3) something fo reveryone - if trade is your thing, trade. Craft - craft. Fighting - well you have to learn to sail and battle on the high seas, if not you losse your neck to the enemy or pirates!
4) Graphics are amazing.
5) The world is vast and based in some of the natural history (although many liberties taken). If you want to sail all over, make new warehouse and dock at ports, expect to have the realism and time invested in doing so. At first I didnt like this aspect, but now after playing hours upon hours I respect it.
6) Potential. Even though this game is great as is - it has great potential to go in many directions.
7) Action. There is down time in the game - but if you want action it can be found almost anywhere on the seas.

Some negative points:

1) Hard learning curve at first. If your not dedicated, I could see where you would easily give up. It would be nice to have a tutorial or two for the new gamer coming into the world. So often on the chat I see, So what do I do - Im new?"
2) Action will get old - and so will crafting  at a certain point. Although the ship production line is quite extensive

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fans of economic PVP games or Caribbean pirates alike will both get their kicks in this game.  Bear in mind it is still in early access, but if you're a fan of EVE Online or Pirates of the Burning Sea, you should get excited about the potential.  The combat simulation is deep enough to keep you coming back for more, with PVP being about more than mashing skills but also, positioning relative to target and wind, and proper target ranging.

Economic elements of the game include building and stocking your storehouse with resources to build your fleet, with the higher tiered ships being guild-wide undertakings that must be protected at risk of losing days/weeks of hard work if it is destroyed, (yes ships can be perma-destroyed).

Starting price tag may seem steep for an EA game i'll agree, but if you're the niche player of the target audience, its money well spent for a good time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great game, and can only get better from here. The combat is very well done, and detailed. The open world if VAST and interesting if a bit sparse at the moment. The pvp fights for conquests are interesting and the game does little in the way of holding your hand.

The game is best played with a group of people out hunting down missions or other players, as well as working together to bettter the nation you play on. You can join a PVE server if pvp is not your thing, but you also don't entirely need to participate in pvp if you don't wish to on the pvp server itself either if you stay away from the front lines.

All in all, I feel like the game needs a little more time in the development cooker but as far as early access is concerned this is a game that has already sucked out over 174 hours of my time as of writing this.

If you would like to see what combat is like in the game please check out my youtube channel at Drakedge2000

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor those interested in a deep, methodical, and strategic Naval Combat & Trading game, this is the cream of the crop. Even while in early access, I have found immense pleasure in sailing the Caribbean, using only a compass and landmarks to navigate, and engaging enemy vessels with a number of beautiful ships. The combat is comprehensive, utilizing demasting, chain shots against sails, wind, and positional damage--shoot below the waterline to start sinking a vessel, or use grapeshot on their weather deck to kill crew before boarding! This game is certainly not for everyone; it is NOT an arcade game, and if you do not have the patience to truly explore and learn the skills needed, you may not find that you enjoy this game. But, for those of you with a hardy constitution and a love of the sea, you'll find no better game to capture the sense and feel of Napoleonic Naval Warfare.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, yes, it is yet another unfinished (for now) early access game. Many things are missing (dear lord, at least add scale ratio to the map!), game explains absolutely nothing (it couldn't be more unhelpfull to new players even if they tried) and UI is a times really awfull. Oh, and for early access game it is pretty expensive.

But even so, it is a lot of fun. There aren't many games in this genre and for many players the naval combat from the age of sails just strikes a soft spot. After some 20+ hours of playing (and googling a lot or watching YT videos, because the game really explains nothing) I really like what I got, even in the current unfinished state.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Been playing on and off since the damage model alpha (deathmatches to balance damage model). The game is great, the combat sailing is simple, but has a high skill cap so skilled players can manually manipulate sails for more unique and/or efficient maneuvering.

Ship combat can take getting used to because the waves affect the ships, and there is some randomness to shot placement (These are not modern cannon). You need to learn where your cannons are placed on your ship, how your sails are setup, and what that means with regards to elevation and firing angles (ie. are the waves too high, or are the sails too full and canting the ship too much).


This is an early access game, but it has been fleshed out quite well since the open world was first introduced to early backers. The devs listen and interact with the community as well, so use the official forums to give suggestions and use the bug report feature to help make the game even better.

Despite it still being Early access, I love this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Create a character, pick a nation to work with (or ye Pirates), then start learning the art of naval combat.  Once you learn a little you will gain XP and gold to be used to purchase larger ships.  Bigger ships brings more intense battles as well as higher XP and gold rewards.

Or if you prefer to be a merchant you can travel the Caribbean searching for the best markets to purchase base materials like logs and metal ore.  Then transport it back to your base of operations and craft ships and materials that you can sell for a profit.  If you get good at it there is a huge markup on high-end ships.

For an Early Access" game it feels fairly polished.  The only exception is the port/crafting/shopping interface which is expected to get a makeover.
"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLoving the game so far!  My laptop struggles a bit (plus a slow internet connection), but I look forward to trying it on my desktop with better internet.  Exploring the Open World is great, combat is fun, and the other players are friendly and helpful.  There is some uncertainty about etiquette for entering battles vs the AI that other players are already engaged in.  Some people welcome the help and others feel like you're stealing their xp.  Hopefully some sort of optional lock-out system will be implemented (or already exists and I just don't know about it).  All-in-all a great game, worth the $40 even in Early Release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is actually pretty damn awesome, even with it being nothing like I expected it to be (I was expecting vast open world battles that greatly focused on realism).  While the game is more realistic than the others that are currently on the market, there are still some things that throw it off.

Battles are initiated, which are followed by a loading screen.  Anyone in the area joins the battle when its initiated, and others are able to join while its in session by going to that location and joining.

The game is pretty slow, yet feels very fast paced.  Most battles tend to last about 30+ minutes, but every second of those 30 minutes is a great experiance.

Probably one of those games that over the next couple months I'll put a couple hundred hours into; and will more than likely return to afterwards.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fan of an age of sail?
They you can't get any better than Naval Action! It really is a no-brainer!
The seer amount of love and effort put by the dev's in this game is visible and felt
in the first battle you set off!
Ships are beautiful, sounds and atmosphere fantastic!

Gameplay wise, is skill based! There is no RNG, or TAB targeting, or any of that nonsense in NA!
The more skill and knowledge you have the better you will fare on the high seas!

Game itself is a nice blend of arcade and realistic gameplay. You can't really have a full realistic as battle's would last
half a day, but it's still far from arcade and does require from a player to be aware of his vessel and its position, strengths and weaknesses , wind direction, sail management, cannon ammo type, etc.

At this stage game is a pure sandbox. You are put into the world and off you go. You can choose any from a high number of nations or go neutral or pirate.

For now, game is full of placeholders, and it's pretty basic. Do not expect a full product! It really is an early access"!
But consider that i bought the game a year ago and still had my money's worth out of it at the time where it only had some kind of a team deathmatch in it. Now it has an open world set in the Caribbean with ports that can be attacked and conquered. It supports some basic trading and crafting. (YES
date:
you can get ganked while sailing around but is gives the game a fun factor)

There are no official tutorials in the game and you will have to learn on your own. There are very good you tube tutorial videos that will give you a good explanation of game mechanics. One i will recommend is RamJB. Forum is also a good place to seek information.

Playerbase for the most part is mature and very helpful. Will we see a downgrade with the steam release only time will tell.

I could ramble on but in short
recommended: this is a great game in the making. If you are a fan of the age
hoursPlayed: if you like immersive roleplaying games then this is your station! If on the other hand you are a player that is into instant gratification then i will advise you avoid this game as it will not give you any. THIS IS NOT world of warships with sails!\n\nSo support the making of the greatest naval game ever attempted and join us all in the high seas!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since the sea trials I have been part of this game and it's great that we finnally reached this stage, so to all the new players out there, here is my opinion on the game.

Open development:
The Devs are really open to new ideas and listen to the players on the forums, they are really active with fixing bugs and making things better.

Community:
The community in the open world pre-EA was really great, everybody helped eachother and it was just one big friendly mess, with already lots of clans and roleplay, I hope this will continue in the EA.

Game:
The Game itself is, apart from the bad UI, really beautifull and realistic (even the waves are calculated on the server) and really fun to play, and with still lots of new features to come, I would really recommend this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first started playing this game is was disapointed. I didn't really know what to expect.
I felt like it was just like Elite but with ships. And it kinda is and it kinda isn't.

Naval Action is a truly unique game.

You join a faction at the start of the game (You can make several characters with different nations) and based on that you are placed somewhere in the HUGE world of this game which takes place in the carribbean, of course. Not all locations are based on real places however. But that's good Imo because it offers more places to explore.

This is an early access game but it doesn't feel at all like it's in beta or anything. I haven't come across a single bug. Only thing I noticed was that I could buy iron and sell it for a higher price than I bought it for, in the same port, it fixed itself after I've sold only a few iron ingots, so I didn't get rich. (sadface)
The one thing they could do better is the UI. It's perfectly functional but it's not very good looking.
And more ships...But I'm sure we'll get that.

The only real nagative thing I can say about this game is the HUGE initial grind you have to go through to get your first ship. This was almost fixed when they added the Pickle (but it's so hard to get that it's almost impossible). But I personally had to play for about 15 hours before I got my first new ship. You could do it faster but I had to do things in between mission so I wouldn't get bored. Good thing is that the devs have said there will be no more exp wipes which means you get to keep your level which is the most important thing really. Gold isn't as big of a deal. Not too hard to come by. So once you get passed that inital grind you're free forever. (Unless you make a new character).

The combat is slowish depending on the size of the battle. In most missions you will only face one enemy which is slow indeed, but not nessesarily boring. The larger battles are faster, and awesome to behold.

People keep saying the game is very complex. Which I didn't reallt feel. No it's not just a game you can just in to and know exactly what you're doing in 5 minutes. But Give it an hour or so and you'll start to get the hang of it. People are really helpful so if you've got a question you ask in chat and you'll get help. No question is too stupid. (Except how to turn on your engine...)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA rare type of MMO - one designed for players that enjoy tougher MMOs. No icon on the map to display your position, localized banking, PVP almost anywhere (on the PVP servers), etc. This is a very solid foundation and could potentially turn into one of the best MMOs out there. In my opinon, your enjoyment of the game will come down to how much you enjoy the combat system. If you like how it looks, buy the game immediately.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Create a character, pick a nation to work with (or ye Pirates), then start learning the art of naval combat.  Once you learn a little you will gain XP and gold to be used to purchase larger ships.  Bigger ships brings more intense battles as well as higher XP and gold rewards.

Or if you prefer to be a merchant you can travel the Caribbean searching for the best markets to purchase base materials like logs and metal ore.  Then transport it back to your base of operations and craft ships and materials that you can sell for a profit.  If you get good at it there is a huge markup on high-end ships.

For an Early Access" game it feels fairly polished.  The only exception is the port/crafting/shopping interface which is expected to get a makeover.
"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLoving the game so far!  My laptop struggles a bit (plus a slow internet connection), but I look forward to trying it on my desktop with better internet.  Exploring the Open World is great, combat is fun, and the other players are friendly and helpful.  There is some uncertainty about etiquette for entering battles vs the AI that other players are already engaged in.  Some people welcome the help and others feel like you're stealing their xp.  Hopefully some sort of optional lock-out system will be implemented (or already exists and I just don't know about it).  All-in-all a great game, worth the $40 even in Early Release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is actually pretty damn awesome, even with it being nothing like I expected it to be (I was expecting vast open world battles that greatly focused on realism).  While the game is more realistic than the others that are currently on the market, there are still some things that throw it off.

Battles are initiated, which are followed by a loading screen.  Anyone in the area joins the battle when its initiated, and others are able to join while its in session by going to that location and joining.

The game is pretty slow, yet feels very fast paced.  Most battles tend to last about 30+ minutes, but every second of those 30 minutes is a great experiance.

Probably one of those games that over the next couple months I'll put a couple hundred hours into; and will more than likely return to afterwards.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fans of economic PVP games or Caribbean pirates alike will both get their kicks in this game.  Bear in mind it is still in early access, but if you're a fan of EVE Online or Pirates of the Burning Sea, you should get excited about the potential.  The combat simulation is deep enough to keep you coming back for more, with PVP being about more than mashing skills but also, positioning relative to target and wind, and proper target ranging.

Economic elements of the game include building and stocking your storehouse with resources to build your fleet, with the higher tiered ships being guild-wide undertakings that must be protected at risk of losing days/weeks of hard work if it is destroyed, (yes ships can be perma-destroyed).

Starting price tag may seem steep for an EA game i'll agree, but if you're the niche player of the target audience, its money well spent for a good time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game, I have put about 40 hours into it now and I got hooked to it the day I bought it. Naval Action is a open world ship sailing MMO simulator. It is very similar to Eve if anyone knows about it, but it isn't as overwhelming as Eve. There is several different nations you can choose from, from the major players back in the 1700s like Great Britian and Spain, to the smaller nations like Sweden, Dutch, and even the Pirates. There is trading, crafting, and conquering territory with other people in the nation that you choose. There are PVE and PVP servers, both in US and EU.
The map is the entire Carribean, with the entire coast line from half way up the Eastern US, all the way down to the Northern coastline of Brazil. There are a huge amount of ports you can travel to and see what they produce and in what quantities as you plan out trade routes to make money or to craft ships, items, upgrades, etc. As you level up, you can sail bigger ships more proficiently as you are able to command more crew to sail these larger ships.

Surprisingly, I have yet to see bugs besides a small graphical glitch when sailing around. One thing thing that can be a pro or a con is that traveling to different places takes time while in the open world part of the game. You can simply alt-tab or watch a video on another monitor, if you have one, to pass the time. When you are in the open world sailing around, the wind matters a lot in how you travel around, so you must plan accordingly or it will take forever to get to the place you want to go, and wind defintely matters in battles you get into. When you get into a battle, you and the other party will be put into an instance and other people from the two nations can join the battle while it is going on, but they have five minutes to do so before the battle is locked to the players or AI within the battle. In battle, you can sink other ships, board them and capture their ship, or run away if you feel the battle isn't going into your favor, but the enemy can stop you from running away if they can hit you at least once every one minute and 30 seconds.

It is still far from finished and the devs seem pretty decent as they listen to the feedback the community gives. Also, they have plenty of ships being added into the game as the game moves through early access, along with UI changes and other features added to the game.

I just have to say I am addicted and can't wait to play more of this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great. I will mention that it is Alpha right now and its basically down to either fighting or trading/crafting. The best part about this game is you can decide what you want to do, adapt your own strategies against ships, and the overall freedom of a large map at your disposal. The community is mature and seems to be helpful. Being able to take ports from other nations, and having it affect the economy and politics of the map is great.

There have already been alliances made between nations and clans within the game. Player driven economy and conquest really makes this game great.

I truly hope the devs stick to this game because the potential for a good naval action game is already in place. Great start!
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For die hard sailing ship fans this could be the game for you.

For a very early alpha game it shows great potential, plus the devs are constantly updating and fixing bugs, damage, more acurate ships etc. All though there is no set campain missions (Yet) there still is fun in sinking other ships and trading. Upon Joining the Americans (PvE) I was greated by a warm welcome of other players who asisted me in trading and fleet missions to get me a better ship. All thoguh I'm still out classed by their massive ships we still raid the Spanish coast togehter.

Pros

Like i said, constant updatng don't expect for the glitch or bug you find to last long. Friendly players who are happy to join in your vendetas and help in your crafting or battles. Large amount of ships and ship classes to choose from. Even two of the same ship can have major changes. Either diferent thickness or being faster. easy grinding, most missions give 5000+ coins and different amounts of XP, depending on the mission you chose. Absolutly beautiful world down to the waves lapping against your boat. So even when your not filling a ship at port side full of holes you can still sail around and enjoy the scenery. Trading although a good mechanic still a little sketchy and chalengeing to properly do, best stick to sinking ships to start off.

Cons
Still in alpha so major bugs and what not everywhere. Sink mechanic kind of boring they just go straight down. You can get lucky and set the oposing ship afire but still, would be niffty seeing a ship rolling to one side or the other or even completly over and then sink. No set tutorial, just drops you in the middle of the ocean and thats that. Find your own way. Best to look up how to videos or consult your local players. Navigation is simple. Map and compass. To simple... map could use gridlines at least. Finding your missions out in the open water. No waypoint no tracker nothing. You just gauge off your map and hope you get close enough to actually see it. There is fast travel but you can't fast travel with loaded goods and when you do theres a set time limit before you can again. (usually 3 hours) To be expected for an MMO but needs work. Sailing is actual time and requires a tone of time. Even sailing the full American controled coast from top to bottom might take close to half an hour. If  the wind plays nice. Port menu kinda boring but I won't complain about that to much. It is just a menu. Still a bit pricey for an early game full of errors. But has huge potential if you dont mind waiting. Still best to wait for it to go on sale. Massive ship battles are long at least an hour. But the payout is great.

Just a few of the pros and cons. But I recomend it for all pirate or privateer fans. Saill across the 7 seas,  hoist your nations colors and fight for survival amoungest players, enemy nation ships, and pirates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While the game is still in development, and the dev team are interested in feedback from the players, their obstinate refusal to offer anything close to realism in the way of maritime navigation is the deal-breaker for me. No matter how pretty you make the sunsets, no matter how detailed the ships, no matter the accuracy of the eye-candy for the period, having to rely on landmarks for navigation is possibly the stupidest game mechanic decision they have made. They give you a compass and what amounts to a speedometer, and tell you to navigate by sight. No concession to anything realistic about sailing is made. The world map is lovely, yet worthless in regard to getting from A to B. Yes, you can see the port you just departed from, and yes, you can see the port you may be attempting to reach. You can even see the crossed sabers indicating the position of the ship(s) you are instructed to sink, etc. What you are not given, and what you will be never given (unless the dev team comes down off their high horse) is any indication of where the hell you are on that same map.

I played Pirates of the Burning Sea at launch, and then again 2 yrs ago. While Naval Action is in the simulation" category
hoursPlayed: PotBS was a better game. It had character and style. NA has plenty of screenshot-worthy moments
voteText: but the ludicrous and intentional lack of navigation realism cannot but render this game to me anything beyond a mobile Geoff Hunt painting. If you want to sail a pretty ship around scanning the horizon for a landmark to fix your position
helpfulPercent: then buy the game.  I think I'll uninstall for now and come back when the game is finished. Maybe
votesHelpful: by then
votesTotal: the devs will realize that their desire for players to experience being "lost at sea" because navigation tools like an octant or a sextant would make it too easy is a cop-out.\n\nI have not
votesFunny: and will not say anything about the lack of tutorial
commentsCount: etc. because it IS an Early Access game.\n\nIf you have a couple of spare $20 bills lying around
column16: buy the game. If you would rather see your money put to better use
column17: send it to me and help me pay off my student loans."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I like this game a lot; but I can't recommend it.  Designed to, as accurately as possible, portray the Age of Sail in the Carribean and Gulf of Mexico, the game does that very well.  The devs are working very hard to tweak it, add balance, etc.

But authenticity comes at a price.  Unfortunately, the main cost is real time. This is a huge problem for the long term success of a game.  Just going on a simple PvP mission can take an hour or more.  By the time you sail to sea (crap - it's against the wind), get to your marker, conduct the fight, then sail back (crap - against the wind AGAIN), you have just spent 30-60 minuites (or more) in the game.  Seek out a larger PvE battle and the time goes even higher.  PvP battles can be even worse.

Any battle can last up to 90 minutes.  That means if you have 60 minutes to play before you go to work, before your next class starts, etc you can't play because you may still be stuck in a battle by the time you must leave.  And even if you get out of the PvP battles, you may well find friends of the enemy waiting for you as you leave - sucking you back into another up to 90 minute battle - sometimes 2-3+ times in a row.

For someone with no time constraints, that is fine.  For the majority of players with class, jobs, family, etc, the time cost is too high.

Yes, if you can only play a short time you can pursue your crafting skills.  But, it literally takes only 10-15 minutes tops to use up all the labor points you have for the day, so crafting can't fill the short time void very often.  You can also make trade runs, but smart players build their outposts so trade runs are rarely needed; why risk losing one's cargo when one can ship in complete safety using the automated delivery system that entails 0 risk to ship or cargo - and again can be setup in 10-15 minute tops?

And that really, is all you can do.  Fight.  Trade. Craft.

Even with the most well thought placement of your outposts, getting to an enemy port to raid or try to seige takes a long period of real time - followed by that up to 90 minute fight - or multiple fights back to back.

Not only can most players not afford the IRL time sink, many others can't handle the long periods of inaction.

You can select Small or Large fleet battles in port and skip the sail out anf back.  This helps a little but the battle can still go on for 90 minutes.

I'm not sure what the devs can do to lessen the time drain.  The overall concept of the game is outstanding.  Battles, especially between groups of frigates are great fun.   But the average gamer is going to acknowledge the game's potetntial then move on to other games that offer more fast paced action.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Neg:  Battles seem to be random, as you can shoot your enemy to oblivion and somehow it still manages to sail faster than you can.  Half of the battle is spend chasing your enemy instead of actually fighting.  The damage models are way off, and the chances to hit are taken straight out of a casino.


The open world is a farce, battles are instanced and everybody plays the same factions.
Missions are boring as hell, seeing there's hardly any variaty.  Port battles are a joke as well because they're identical to regular battles.

And to top that, it takes an horrible grind to unlock new ships that are hardly any improvement over the old one.

Cons:

Graphics are okay and that's the only good thing i can mention about this game.
The interface is straight out of the 90ies. (i liked the 90ies)

I feel ripped off, this game should be 10 euro/dollars at best.

IF you liked Total War: Empire sea battles, and look for something similar, this is not the product to buy.
However if you like dreadful slow mmo's with average combat, a bad trading system and no variaty this is your game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI enjoy the game.  I joined a clan, help new people in general chat with questions about gameplay and do a lot a trading/crafting.  I play PVE b/c PVP is not well balanced yet.  Fleet actions with friends are a lot of fun.  The graphics are beautiful and the ships have individual characteristicss.  They caan be customizable with add-on mods too.  When on long sails I play sea-chanties and period music and stuff from the Master and Commander soundtrack.  Lots of friendly folks (at least as Britain in PVE).  I recommend it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you love the age of sail or a slowwer paced game this is great. A few things bug me about this game mainly being that 1st rates are what win wars, if your nation can't bring 25 1st rates to a port battle you may as well not go, I know the devs are working on a fix for this problem though. The grind isn't as bad as it used to be and the AI have been fixed aswell. The devs have said they will support and add content to this game as long as there are players playing it which I hope will be for a long time. All in all I give Naval action a 8 out of 10 and that will go up as more things are added to the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Basically it's a nice game, and I want to play it for a longer time... but....

Once I'm logged into it I already feel bored and immediately log out.

Why ? ...   Let me tell you some things you might need to know before purchasing it:



Pros:

+ pretty neat interface while being on the ship, easy to understand

+ the first thing you'll notice are the waves. the water is so realistic to watch.. and even more realistic during battles, where u'll have more details

+ steering a ship is fun too, there are a great variety of ships you can purchase during the game with many upgrades and different looks

+ mixing a ship simulator with an mmo is a cool idea too

+ you can be dutch, danish, sverige, american, british, french, spanish or join the pirates, which is the only faction who can attack eachother.

+ day/night cyclus



Cons:

- the waves could be much bigger at the sea

- as nice as the UI is while outside on the sea, once you are in a Harbour/Port/Outpost the UI is big and confusing.

- You gain 50 ish xp for a successfull mission in Level 1, and not more. You need 1000xp to Level 2 = Pure Mission Grinding!

- There ain't alternatives to grinding missions, but to attack players of other countries, which you shouldn't do in early levels anyway, cause you have no effin chance
So if you don't have mates to help you out in those missions wich are 1vs1 battles against AI Ships and 50% of them will destroy you in the beginning, you have a problem

- one of those missions ( 1vs1 battles ) will last for 30minutes or longer until finally a ship is destroyed and will sink, whether its yours or the AI ship.

- there are only 3 things to do in this game: missions ( which are always the same procedure ), pvp battles ( will be interesting in higher levels / you can attack Harbours too ) or you can just farm Gold by buying and selling goods in different Ports, but you cant gain xp from that and there ain't trading quests yet.
If you decide to farm Gold first, you might be able to puchase bigger ships, but bigger ships need a bigger crew, and the amount of crewmember will increase with your rank/level only! so don't even think about joining a battle with a ship that needs 150+ crew and you only got your 40 member in level 1. Cannon reloadtimers will increase drastically, your turning and steering will be horrible, and you can't even manage to repair it either.

So.. if you're already a fan of ships , especially old ones and don't care about the difficulties during the game, get it and travel the carribean sea!

Otherwise, give it a couple more months and check if they added more content.

Also feel free to check out my screenshots if you're interested.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At this point and time I can in no way recommend this seemingly nice game. Here is why:
First of all, the UI is absolutely horrible, and in addition, from what I gather through forum posts and the like, the devs do not intent to enhance it, or at least make it half way decent, in any way shape or form in the near future.

Secondly the graphics. Played on ultra, with everything turned up, the game is still rough around the edges. For example, ropes on the ship are being formed in lines, even with AA turned to max, the contact of the ship with the water is in no way smooth, the vegetation on the islands contains very rough models, and suffers from similar AA problems, and the lighting/shading, is not remarkable either. Combine that with the fact that all you 'll be looking at in this game, are the above mentioned ship, islands and sea, the game is certainly no eye-candy at this point, for me at least. Whether the developers intend to enhance the graphics remains to be seen.

Thirdly immersion. Having to go through loading screen after loading screen, even to engage enemy ships at sea, just totaly breaks immersion. I can understand, and forgive, a loading screen here and there, maybe when you enter major ports, but not when they litteraly precede every enemy encounter. Further more, when not engaged in combat, the ship seemingly runs itself, with not crew on deck, as if it was a ghost ship. Not only that, but even when you do get to see the crew, which is only in enemy engagements, the crew is poorly animated, and they do not even engage in activities around the ship, either following your orders, or passivly. They have only 1 animation ,which is to inspect the cannon, and even that is terribly done. This lack of the human factor is also present at ports, that look abandoned as a direct result of this. I really hope the developers do try and amend these issues someday.

Moving on, perhaps the most awful thing about the game at this point, and something that I am afraid will not be changing, ever, is the grind. Going by reports in forums, and videos, along as with what little I could gather from struggling to understand the menu, the grind is horrendously long, even to match that of free-to-play MMOs. Difference is, I can understand why F2P MMOs need the grind, which is to generate income from people skipping said grind. But in a game you pay 40 dollars for, such a long grind is to my eyes completely unacceptable. Sure, im all for not giving everything away at once, but the system going at this point is just off the charts.On a positive note, If the game has one redeeming vertue even at this point, it is that of the combat system. That is truly enjoyable, and the battles are truly engaging. It is however too, quite slow, which I personaly do not mind, however this might be a nuisance to some people.

All in all, the game feels too rough, and too early in development right now, which is not inherently a bad thing, but when the developers are asking a whooping 40 dollar fee, for this unfinished alpha, that you are going to be testing for them for free to boot, I can not, sanely recommend it. If the game gets patched up in the future, or if the developers realize they are asking too much for a game miles from being complete, and change the price, then I might come to recommend it. Until then, stear clear from this one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

alright, in the beginning i was really drawn to this game, time period, the gun powder all that, that is why i bought it when it released.

first of all, this game is NOT WORTH 37 euros, i can buy a triple A game for that money, so i EXPECT a good quality game with many features/ near finished. if its was like 10 to 15 euro range, i might gave it a thumbs up.


Graphics 7/10

the ships looks stunning. but the boat that you start out with, not so much. the big boates look amazing.
i also loved it when you are sailing and in the far distance you see towers of a city sticking out so you know you are almost home.
islands itself are quite dull, and low res.

in battle, the ocean is beatifully done. the ships movement, are very well done

dont get me started about the ui, its bland, boring and not user friendly, but hey its alpha right?

gameplay 5/10
the only thing i liked was the 'naval action' for the rest it was boring as ♥♥♥♥. this aspect of the game is not for most people.(so not for me.) you go out in the ocean looking for fights, or get a contract to battle a ship 1vs1. buddies with you could help with this grindfest.

Then in the ports you can select small boat battles, and big boat battles. this is where everyone is. and because everyone is in the ports money/xp farming, there is almost no one in the open seas. developers need to get rid of that, or lower the rewards for the pvp battles.

Technical 9/10
this games runs very well on my system, gtx970, intel core i7.
frames are always at 60fps+
only minor thing i have is the daily maintance, this is the first game i see that has this. and if you are immersed you have to port, and log out for this maintence, or else you could lose progress.

Final 4/10
its just below average for me. but if you REALLY like boat battles from this time piriod and have patience with grinding 10 hours for a bigger ship, then by all means buy it. but for 37 euros, i can buy a triple A game that is finished and gives me more gameplay and enjoyment.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDue to the return policy on Steam I had to ditch this game before I could really experience anything except for a little bit of sailing and a pair of battles. Naval Action is an open world game in alpha stages of development (at time of writing). To be worth $40, a game should grab me very quickly with something, anything and Naval Action simply failed me in that regard. The primary pull at this time, naval combat, is novel but you could probably have just as much fun playing Patrician III or World of Warships. Take your forty bucks elsewhere for now and wishlist this game. For a piece like this it would be better to spend sixty dollars on a fleshed out product than forty dollars on what amounts to a whole lot of not much.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I picked this game up to play a little bit with my bro who seemed to enjoy it quite a lot. Having played everything from Sea Dogs to Age of Pirates 2 Gentlemen of Fortune mod, I found the setting to be an excellent take on a familiar formula, and a worthwhile update to the previous titles.

Unfortunately it's lacking a lot right now, and is not worth $40 at this stage in its development. First off the graphics in the pictures and movies make it look stunning, but actually in-game I found that your basic ship design isn't much better than Age of Pirates 2, even the deck crew look bad, you can fire your guns from your ship and the cannon fire looks lovely, unfortunately the big billows of smoke will pretty much obscure your shots making aiming in this way difficult.

Also, the UI is as barebones rudimentary as it gets, and doesn't nothing for the immersion factor, in fact it felt like I was playing a government simulator of wooden ship combat, the ui elements are just that sterile and impersonal. I'm sure that this will change in time, but who knows what quality they'll implement in this feature at this time.

The other complaint I have is that there's no landing, you can't go ashore, you can't lead a boarding party onto an enemy ship, you can't duel with the captain after slicing through half the crew. I understand that they probably want to keep things more focused on the sailing aspect, but it was a feature in a lot of games like this and it seems like the sort of thing that should be continually developed in a title such as this instead of scrapped completely. To me it feels like a step back instead of a step forward.

The game isn't open world so much as an open ocean where your sailing mechanics are sped-up and highly unrealistic until you happen upon a generic crossed swords icon indicating a combat instance is available to join. Usually you find yourself joining a battle between a player and an NPC pirate that is underway, you may help out and before this fight ends 2 sometimes 3 other people have also joined. The outcome of the fight is pretty much a foregone conclusion at this point, and the idea that other players can essentially take over your battle didn't resonate well with me.  At present this appears to be how you slowly grind your way up from a crappy sloop to higher level ships and that's pretty much it, please someone throw some ice water on this raging fire storm of smoldering game play *snooze*

Ultimately I refunded this purchase because as it stands now, the game isn't worth what I paid for it, maybe in the future after more features are implemented. Being that this game is being released as early access with a slew of features missing or incomplete, should that not be reflected in the price?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't believe the pretty pictures and videos.  Besides being FAR from finished, this game also misrepresents what it really offers.

All the beautiful videos are shot in the battle instances, where your ship behaves like it should, where graphics are turned all the way up, etc, etc. When you are in the open world, you are sailing a simplified, lower-poly model of your ship that clips through waves, sails straight into the wind with square sails up (and inverted!) and can turn on a dime. When you see another ship in the open world, you can clip straight through it. In open world, your ship doesn't even fly a flag. You can be in the middle of a storm and your ship barely rocks, you see waves clipping through the deck and sides and your gun ports are wide open (meaning, in the real world your ship would have flooded and sunk).

Devs are too lazy to code small fidelity improvements, like gun ports closing or square sails being lowered instead of being inverted by the wind (which would cause the ship to stop or even go backwards).

The interface is not finished (it's super-primitive right now, like something out of 1980s). The  map is useless (you don't get a you are here" GPS blip
date: and neither do you have historical instruments to tell you where you are). You sail by "best guess".\n\nIn general

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The good:
Fantastic combat model (although somewhat flawed - see below)

The bad:
Grind, grind, grind (done to enable their pay2win plans)

What do I mean by grind?  I've got 80 hours into the game, and I'm still sailing the starter ship.  Sure, I could be sailing the first square rigger (I just bought a snow), but why should I?  I'm almost broke, the starter ship is free, and I need to save for the next tier ship.  The system is broken.  XP is too slow (by about 4x) and gold is far too scarce.  People will say you can do it faster (and yes you can), but add in the reroll (because I picked France, and no one speaks English in chat), the failed try at trading (which is grindy), the aborted crafting try (which is grindy), and a days worth of exploring, and you are right at about 80 hours.

80 hours (probably closer to 70 due to idling).

Still in the starter ship.

Now, you will get many saying this isn't going to be pay to win.  Call it what you want, pay to play, play to win, pay to skip the grind - it's all semantics.  The people in denial are just trying to set up an MMO with an elite class of players (the ones willing to put tons and tons of time into repetitive missions), while the rest of us sit back and wish we were part of that elite class.

Repetitive missions you say?  There's only ONE mission.  Sail out for 5 mins, kill the pirate (or pirates), sail back.  20  to 25 minutes total (if you know exactly what you are doing).  A resonable pace is 2 missions per hour.  At first, longer, and you will fail frequently.  You'll get about 90xp per mission (on your way to 1000xp for teir 2 - tier 3 another 1000, teir 4 another 3750).  You will need to get to tier 3 for your first significant ship upgrade, but you had better not been spending any gold.  You'll need every cent to buy and equip that next ship  (and after that, you won't want to sail it, because you wont want to lose it).  I like the difficulty - no complaints there.  Only problem - the grind. Rinse, repeat until you are numb.  Grind even more. Oh you can go after that unarmed trader instead for 40xp- what great excitement!  You could also play PvP for xp, which is much more interesting, but your xp rate/hour goes way down - and worst of all you will sink more often.  With anything but the free ship, sinking is expensive - so no more PvP for you!  Great design, huh?

No thanks.  Save your money.  They make excuses  (it's an alpha!), well $40 sets a pretty high bar, unfinished or not.

I should add, they will tell you that the Premium ships will only be cosmetic, but they are being dishonest. The Premium ships cannot be lost (but can be captured) (see source link below).The non-paying customers (I mean  the ones who refuse to pay more than the initial $40) get 5 sinkings per ship, then they are right back into the grind of paying for a new (expensive in terms of time) ship. That's the reason it's pay2win (or whatever you want to call it - semantics). The starter ship is free, so have fun with that, otherwise get your wallet out if you don't have hours and hours to play.

A few more things...  Although the combat model is great, the AI cheats.  It has uncanny accuracy.  Devs say they won't tone it down because players eventually get good.  Well, this just punishes the new players.  And people don't actually get good at naval tactics.  They get good at learning to deal with a computer AI.  The technique of turning your bow or stern into an enemy to soak damage is almost laughable, and so unrealistic.  Oh, and the cannons are FAR too accurate.  Players are actually aiming for specific parts of the ships (trying to hit the masts, for example, or sneak a shot into the hull below the waterline).  For Pete's sake, these were smooth bore cannons on a very unstable platform!  Imagine you are on a real rocking ship, trying to time your shot with the rocking - you certainly aren't going to be aiming at the mast.  But in this game, no problem.  Shoot that mast clean off the ship if your aim is good enough (there's effectively a gyro stabilizer better than an M1 tank's in this game).  So if you are looking for realism, you won't find it here.


For anyone considering this game, look at all those thumbs down.  This is an accurate review.  Those thumbs down show you the fan boys you'll be playing with - trying to dishonestly bury these facts.

Dishonesty seems to be a theme with Naval Action.  Shame, shame, shame.

*source of infinite durability (almost - ships cant be lost, but can be captured) - don't let anyone else say otherwise unless they give you a link
http://forum.game-labs.net/index.php?/topic/4668-open-world-prototype-rules-of-engagement-ship-loss-and-spawning/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't waste your time.

Naval Action is not ready for early access. Instead of adding much needed basic features to the game - such as a UI - they instead ruined what was once the most enjoyable aspect of the game: trading.

In Naval Action, you are able to craft and sail the few ships that are available in game. A player had formerly been incentivized to explore and capture ports to find resources, make deals with other players, and steal ships to rob them of their parts. I suspect that this challenge was removed because the developers theorized that the playerbase is leaving due to the lack of progress that players experience. However, the game is not fun in the absense of a challenge and players like myself are leaving due to the game's volatility and nonsensical changes.

There are only three things you can do in Naval Action:
1) Stare at a featureless port UI screen
2) Wander around a not-to-scale open world ocean (feels like you're sailing a remote-controlled toy)
3) Fight in instanced battles, usually against AI

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PRO's

Amazing graphics.
Complex damage mechanics, every individual part has a purpose on your ship (Not accurate but complex).
Fun detailed battles (when fairly matched).
A true to life economy (A little too true for my innocent heart).

CONS

1) The game has not got the right balance of simulation/fun. This subject is very long, but it’s too realistic in certain departments whilst neglecting departments that matter, and they ALL conflict with fun. This game is not a sim OR Arcade... it trys both.

2) Low level Single/Solo players having a bad turn will lose all help from the built in starting mechanics (Missions and Freebies) and will eventually go broke and struggle without help. Game is designed purely for groups and almost punishes lone ships. If you spend hours looking for a balanced opponent, it’s ok but if you do ANY missions (which is only the level based port missions, which is also the main source of starting wage/currency/experience, as only ship battles give XP), It will always pare you up a level and not your current ships rate, so for example you lost a previous good ship and have downgraded due to cost... Those missions become impossible solo in a crap ship. Just entering the missions to check will cost you as you will have to repair your ships trying to run away. If you fight, you’re up against X2 vessels higher than your ranks corresponding ship. This at first was not much of problem, but with the improved AI its impossible now without help or a better ship. You gain little as your repairing and it takes allot of time and money to buy or rank up without exploiting the market. Capturing a ship is near impossible whilst solo in missions as you will sink either by the shear time or by the other ship. If you lose a ship you go down a massive jump. If you’re not good you will eventually resort to a starter ship and have no missions to help you. You will have to earn from random encounters with very low ships (few of). If you go after a ship correctly tiered in the vast ocean (up to 3 hours looking), it will take a good hour in real time to capture her), whilst realistic... not at all fun for any casual player that does not want to play the game for 10 hours straight every day whilst doing nothing the majority of the time.

3) Economy has been owned By a large group of people, Basically they dictate all ship prices and put out other starting traders, devs have been made aware of this obvious event but have done nothing (You come on the early hours you can see them talking in chat and sailing in trade ships). The shop generated ships will be bought by them and relisted at stupid prices (1000% above the reccomended level price). So you can forget about your appropriate priced replacement ships unless you spend hours crossing the ocean with no guarantee of finding anything. So a good feature for those just wanting to exploit money, a bad feature for ANY casual player or anyone here wanting to focus on the ocean battles rather than the economy. Low level players having a bad turn will lose all help from the starting mechanics and will eventually go broke and struggle without help. When they introduce paid for content (They have announced paid DLC)... no doubt the market exploiters will gain real money in some way (Selling gold IRL etc).

4) Weird and basic bugs with questionable help from Admin". Chat
date: friends list and text sometimes disappeared and when I reported it with various other issuesI was told "Well no one else is experiencing it" with their admin reading and replying to my posts in a demeaning and unbeliavble manor. Next day it seemed to "fix itself" for everyone in my TeamSpeak. It happened a couple of times later and is mentioned in a much later update... Good acceptance of an error report right? Also the bad exploited economy
recommended: AI ships performing 100% whilst only having 5/160 crew
hoursPlayed: bad provided help mechanics for solo's
voteText: bad MM and the newest bug is being teleported to the other side of the map (ALOT... of sailing time back) and without my stored equipment
helpfulPercent: no ships and no docks (So can’t stay there and cant have any fun).\n\nOn all
votesHelpful: my personal opinion is it’s not worth the cash as its all eye candy unless you want to start exploiting mechanics for gain. I bought the game in its private kickstarter and realy liked the introduced features back then... but now its all different and not all good. The game is not a Sim nor Arcade game (I like both type of games)... but its simulator aspects hamper the fun
votesTotal: even though it could do it right
votesFunny: by putting in restrictions for certain actions and tweak AI
commentsCount: they seem to desire either corruption or a game that a small population will desire. There is just too little features in this game. Lots of people out there have joined the exploitation of the economy and will defend this game visciously purely because of that trait. Others will just like the realistic feeling in the ocean and the awe left from a battle. But most will eventually succumb to the lack of content at the present or experience the Bankruptcy/Little progression.\n\nThis review is open for adjustment as the game goes on

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is no longer worth the time or money it costs to play it, in fact, it is overpriced garbage. It is advertised as an MMO with many different features to keep you interested, and at this point I dare say it is falsely advertised.

In the early days of EA resources were scarce and crafting was a challenge. You had to compete with other players for limited resources and not everyone could craft a ship every day. This also gave incentives for your nation to expand and take the ports of others in order to give your nation access to more resources. I enjoyed the competition and enjoyed nice ships being a rarity. The developers have since catered to care bears who only want an easy mode game, and as a result there isn’t really anything left to do. Resources are now in infinite supply. There is no point to capturing the ports of other nations for their resources. You will find everything you will ever need in an infinite supply in the ports right next to your capital.

The developers plan on wiping many aspects of player accounts due to the influx of cheaters. They have said they will soft wipe the servers, which means players will lose all of their gold, ships, and resources. They do not plan on wiping XP or crafting level. This won’t slow down a cheater who by definition isn’t playing by the rules; instead it will punish the average player. Sounds fun doesn’t it?

The one thing this game does decently is the combat. There is some fun to be had in pvp. This alone may keep you interested for a couple of days but it too will become monotonous and boring quite fast. When I started playing there were enough players to be spread around 2 to 3 different servers. At the time of this review there is only enough players left to fill half of one server, and it's easy to see why players are leaving this game in droves.

I give this game a 3/10 and would say its worth about $10.00.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is more MMO than say a World of Warships and it's not play to win in any way.  All good right?

No it has no end game besides faction battle on the PvP servers between factions, none on the PvE side at all.  Crafting in game is the same formula used 20 years ago.  So what you have is an MOBA  pretending to be an MMO with limited arena battles, all battle are instanced.  Gets dull after about 100 hours of play.

On PvP it's already devolved into a few Mega clans that work together mostly doing PvE battle vs NPC cities.

The game is one of the best looking Unity engine games to date but, it's never going to blow your mind and like all Unity games it makes your GPU work harder than it should for what you get.

If that is enough to buy it, you will be happy otherwise move on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Technically this game reminds me of Flight simulator X on sea. You have depth and possibilities of gameplay and it's not easy to get into, but if you perservere with it (which I have not) I believe there are rewardings to be found here. However at it's current state, the game has a steep curve to get into, very basic graphics and in general everything happens in slow motion. However the slowness is due to the simulation aspect of the game and does not differ from fsx in that respect. I mean your'e supposed to sail the sea, not fast travel it. I feel this will be a game for the experienced players and niche market, which as with fsx or other sims, is not bad thing at all. It's still getting patches and releases so the devs are at least doing something with this. I sure hope it will see a finished day someday and then I'm happy to take another look at it.

There are severe annoyances that the community has been griping about for ages so lets hope the devs pick up on that one, such as the possibility for newbie players wait for experienced players to battle to death and then at last minute a newbie joins in and loots the shipwreck right before the winners noses or similar. Takes the wind off from playing competetively, and right now that's basically the playerbase this game has at the moment. Only curious and hardcore are willing to put up with this game's raw state of development. For these reasons I would advise to wait before getting this game, unless of course your'e that type of person.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you have ever wanted to feel like the captain of an Age of Sail ship this game is your chance.
You can command any vessel starting from small cutters and yachts up to huge Ships of the Line. You can trade, sail the seas, fight enemy ships and conquer enemy towns for the benefit of you nation and your own.
Here is a short list of my most favorite features of the game:
- Extremely realistic sail mechanics.
- A map on which you have to find out yourself where you are (no GPS).
- Beautyful sea, weather and world. Just sail and admire the sunsets.
- Advanced damage model with leaks, demasting, fires and explosions.
- Trading goods between towns and crafting ships.
- Huge naval battles with up to 25 versus 25 players in beautyful ships.

If you do remember Pirates and liked it, this is the perfect game for you.

If you want to see some more you can stop by at www.twitch.tv/PlakRocks or www.youtube.com/c/PlakRocks to watch some move videos of this great game.

Early Access Review

Amazing game all around. I will be sailing around in the open world and just look around me and I see the beautiful scenery that the devs have put so much work into. I go into a battle and I truly feel like the captain of a ship, just as I did in my youth. I sail about, seeking adventure, wealth, and most of all, filthy pirates.

From a technical standpoint, the game is indeed an alpha, but it's quite well polished, and bugs are rare. The developers are amazing from all that I have seen, and are very receptive to the community's thoughts. There are features that need tweaking and some that have yet to be added, but I am confident in gamelabs.

The loading screen quotes are also very witty and fun, just to mention that.

Overall, if you have any interest in the age of sail and becoming a captain, this game is certainly for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very pretty game that is currently missing key features that define a 17th-18th Century naval game in the Carribean such as:
- Exploration of any kind
- A meaningful and detailed trading system and economy ( The thing that defines this era )
- Trading Vessels ( Currently, 3 converted, reskinned warships are the only options available )
- A useful open world navigation UI ( You sail blind most of the time, you get a crude map of the world though with no markers )
- Dedicated areas for new players to avoid being ganked and griefed
- A meaningful progression system geared towards those that like either combat, trading, or exploring. ( Currently, you just shoot ships. It gets pretty mundane really fast )

What you will get if you pick this up:
- Highly detailed warships
- A gorgeous open world with very well done weather effects and ocean effects that actually effect you
- PVP or Missions or a super simple trading system geared towards warship construction
- Long sail times between ports

I am not recommending this at this time due to the fact that the devs seem to be unsure of what to turn this game into or maybe they just don't want to share their roadmap and the current lack of content for the era it takes place in just makes it feel very empty. If you like shooting things alot and sailing for long periods of time and seeing very detailed warships, then you might like it at this moment.

At $40, I recommend you give this game some time to sink or swim.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Does sailing around on a high quality naval vessel appeal to you? Engaging in port battles, trade runs and ship to ship combat against both NPCs and other players (on PvP designated realms)? Then this could have been the game for you!

Unfortunately a number of features let it down such as the world map scaling with the ships so a trip to Honduras from Jamaica takes the same amount of time it would take a ship travelling at the same speed in the real world.

This is further hampered by storms with zero visibility (sailing past obscured ports at 100m is common) and that there is no marker on the map for either your position or that of your group members. Travel is done by zig-zagging between ports based on compass bearings and combat navigation is done in degrees from north.

Due to recent changes, resource acquision is now entirely player based in a world where 90% of the 300 population server is in the capital and most of the other 100 destinations have no resources to trade. Combat harks from AC Black Flag with crew management detracting from the combat experience (try choosing between sails, gunnery and boarding while in combat)

Overall this game is no longer worth the $40 price tag. If you're still interested wait for the full release and keep an eye on the reviews at launch

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A beautiful sailing game, based on the unity engine.

I've played this game in the closed early access for some time now, and it's finally out on Steam.

What you can expect from this game? A realistic sailing simulator, with pretty ships during the age of sail, tons of fun playing multiplayer. It's really exciting to be in a big naval battle, line formation, giving the ships of the line their name, just  firing upon the other fleet, watching the smoke build up more and more as the battle goes on. The sounds of the cannons echoing over the ocean, and then the cracking and splintering of wood as the cannons impact the hull of the ship, with little pieces flying all over and landing in the water.

Apart from that, there is also the open world, which allows trading, exploring, sinking pirates, the usual stuff one would expect from a naval open world game. The time is sped up in the open world, but the travelling time is somewhat realistic, with the carribean area being very detailed in terms of islands and nations.


Would I recommend this game? Definitely, it's not finished yet, early access and all,  there are still a lot of missing features, especially in regards to the open world, but the game already brought me so much delight, that I definitely got my money's worth.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

its a great game and is very addicting, but there are issues and yes its an alpha but these need to be addressed now before its a full game.

1.) the aiming- the aiming is terrible, i cant find out where to aim with it, its a thin red or white line when i aim at the enemy ship, the cannons fly right over the ship when i aim at the water it shoots to low. its just very annoying and needs to be fixed and updated.

2.) the map- the map is very little help as all it does show the land masses and how big the map is, BUT THERE IS NO INDICATOR OF WHERE YOU ARE AT, NO ARROW OR DOT OR LINES OF TRAVEL. now its realistic but i think for players sanity of finding out where to go needs to be updated.

3.) now if you like it hardcore then skip this if you do. you pay alot for your ships then they sink 5 times thats it, its gone, you can of course buy repair kits for nearly 3000 gold for each on a 5th rate, i get it but the price of ships need to be lower abit for that (FYI there are 7 rates and a 5th rate can cost up to 150000 gold and there are limited numbers of ships that can be bought in the port so you might not see the ship you want avalible).

NOW that is out of the way the goods. its a very realitic game though the ai is stupid but i wish you could walk on your ship but I cant deny i put hours into this game. the level up is a bit weird but you will understand it later and for an very new alpha it has alot of potental to be one of the best games ever. big open world sailing on your own vessal the size of the HMS VICTORY is pretty cool i think. and there are plenty of nations to choose to be, even a pirate. plenty of varity of ships as well so i still recommend it and support this amazing game just a few errors but its new i'll cut it some slack.

NOW THEN YA LANDLUBBERS, SEE YA AT SEA.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

10/10

Booted up game.
Joined friend in a glorius first time skirmish.
Got mounted by another boat.
The mounting boat capsized.
Preceded to get broadsided by a frigate.
Somehow survived the engagement.

Long spiel:

The game mechanics are quite solid for an early access alpha game, ship battles are fun, and the graphics are quite amazing. I did not expect the amount of features present in the current alpha state of the game, I was expecting basic ship combat, and open world sailing. Many complain about the place holder UI as of 2/24/2016, however the UI is actually quite responsive and ergonomic as far as playing the game goes, so ignore those nerf herders. The game is a bit pricey but considering the game being an MMO, that is much better than paying a monthly installment fee. The only qualm ill have is if the devs decide to implement a monthly fee. Other than that I believe this game is quite solid, seems like the updates from the devs are prompt and quite consistant from a time perspective.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

=== More Complete Than A Lot of Recent AAA's === Does Combat for the Era Justice ===


Even for an Early Access review, I can definitely recommend this game. It does naval battles very well, but it also does an open, real time world very well too. The game has plenty of content in terms of both progression and exploration. The world is huge. It sort of simulates a live economy of goods and services. There's also almost a dozen factions/countries with a pretty decent community so far.

The game plays well and looks good. There are a ton of 'Pros'. The only two 'Cons' is that it's a massive time Vampire and there are a couple of bugs that are super annoying right now. I imagine the later will get fixed, but the first is going to be up to you.

It's all multiplayer and getting together with friends is easy, fun, and fairly balanced. I wouldn't say it's dependant on playing with friends, too; it's got plenty of content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty good for an early access game, although it has been in alpha 1 year prior to this early access release.
Nonetheless, pretty amazing for an open world game. The grinding has been all over though, the UI is pretty ♥♥♥♥ but the gameplay is where it stands at its best. You could actually feel the quality over quantity on the ship battles, because numerous times I have had for example 5 more basic cutters (first ship) than the other team, but gets destroyed by a 3rd rate. That just tells you how powerful the expensive and big ships really are, it's quite scary to face one of these in small or large battles.

This game has port battles which I haven't come through yet because of me ranking incredibly slowly in 80 hours. You'd probably not spend as much time to get up in rank, but for me it's been a pain in the ♥♥♥♥.

So in conclusion, if you have a lot of spare time you could try play this game, especially if you are interested in naval warfare. I am saying this again, the grinding is a pain in the ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Outstanding game so far. Naval Action captures the difficulty, chaos, and terror of naval combat unlike any other game since Silent Hunter III. Its open world is influenced heavily by EVE Online and Mount & Blade, and while systems are rudimentary, they are all in tact and functioning. The size of the world is truly impressive -- the entire Caribbean, modelled precisely. It takes about 3 real-life hours to cross the map, if you have the wind... The political system is very intriguing and already shaky alliances have formed between certain nations.

Gameplay is remarkably tight for an early access title -- I have encountered literally no bugs, glitches, freezes, etc. The combat is difficult but accessible for new players, and the graphic fidelity in the battles is basically AAA quality -- think a cross between Wargame: Airland Battle and World of Warships at max settings but with MUCH better ocean, sound and smoke effects. Ships are modelled in much more clarity and detail than WoWS and waves and storms can dramatically influence battles.

This game needs more press and exposure. I've played every major war game, sim, etc., and Naval Action is the most promising I've played in a long time.

Is it worth $40? Absolutely. The test UI is clunky and certain features need iteration, but the game is pretty much there and without the glitchy nonsense that afflicts most Early Access titles. This is 100% more polished than Day Z SA.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Easily the best Age of Sail game I've ever played. It has an amazingly realistic combat system and a beautiful open world, although the content is currently a little shallow (pun intended) besides generic missions, but that is to be expected from a game in Alpha development.

Please note that if you buy this game, you're buying a game in ALPHA, which means you're not entilted to a perfect game and have no right to complain if it doesn't satisfy you. I can't tell you how many people I've met that acted as if they've been ripped off by purchasing this because they don't seem to realise the whole point of Alpha testing is to smooth out the game. If you're looking for a perfect, smooth, polished game, I suggest you wait until full release, or at least later in development.

For an alpha game being developed by a 10 man team, I'm extremely impressed so far and look forward to further developments.

9.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naval Action is an immersive, physics-driven MMO set in the age of sail that is fun, challenging but is at an early access stage that while stable, lacks the depth needed to be a really great game.

Disclaimer -- At the time this review was written, there are four servers.  3 PVP and a PVE server where much of the PVP content such as attacking other players and seizing ports  is disabled.  I played on the PVE server first to get a feel of the game  so I will not address PVP, but instead talk about the mechanics and PVE features.

The game is set mostly in the Carribean, where the player can be a member of one of eight factions of varrying historical appropriateness (Spain, Great Britain, Denmark/Norway, the United States, the Pirates, France, the Netherlands and Sweden).

The game map extends from Deleware to the north coast of South America, east to the Lesser Antilles and west to the east coast of Mexico and the Yucatan.   I haven't counted the number of cities and towns on the map, but it looks to be over 100.  The cities are divided between the various factions and also 'neutral' and Free" cities.  Players can dock in any city owned by their faction or sometimes neutral cities

voteText: or build) bigger

votesFunny: there is a handy 'teleport me to my capital' button that can be used every few hours if you are truly desparate.\n\nSailing is also more difficult than most typical age of sail games.  For example

column21: judge the fall of your shot

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have bought this game when it was in very early Alpha access and only the combat testing, called Sea Trials was available. I am involved in the development process of this game for more than a year now.

From the start, I was very impressed by what the Developers want to create here. And that with a quite small team of developers.
Sure,there are some bugs and the game still isnt completely finished (for example there is close to no GUI for the Harbors), but you can see the effort which is put into developing the game. And the progress is also visible. This is no game, which might end up not getting developed further. For more than a year I could follow the development progress and see first hand, that tester suggestions are taken seriously and often even get implemented into the game.
The game has absolutly great sailing and gunnery physics and its a blast to sail around in the caribbean with some friends, searching for enemy fleets to destroy. Or prepare and execute a port assault together to get access to additional ressources for your faction.
So if you are at all interested into the Age of Sail, this game is YOUR game. Buy it!

in short:

Great:
Ship sailing
Gunnery
Models of the ships
really big Open world
Battles for control over the various ports

Good:
Rank progression
choice of ships

not so good:
Missions (there are missions, but they are repetitive and kinda meh)
GUI ( the GUI for the harbors for example is not yet really implemented, but they are working on it)
Trading (work in progress)
Crafting (work in progress)

bad:
no tutorial at all


I could write much more about this great game, but I think this is enough to get a first impression about wether this game might be something for you. I#ll update this review in case something major changes.
