reviewText:
Early Access Review

So it's time to change my review since I'm now 800+ hours into this game.

I have pretty much experienced all the game has to offer, and I have to say Naval Action is my game. It's my Star Wars Galaxies, my Eve Online, and every other game I've played over the years that has sucked me in to become an obsession.

Let me be blunt. Naval Action falls into the marmite category in that you will either love it or hate it depending on what you look for in a PC MMO.  It is NOT a game for people who want instant fast paced action. It's not a game for kids, and it's not a game for those who don't have even a slight interest in 18th century naval warfare.

It IS a game for the more mature gamer who enjoys a PVP game that has moments of inactivity (sailing) with burst of exciting naval combat with opposing players. The ships are beautiful and combat is very realistic.

I've read all the recent negative reviews about this game having no end game content. Frankly I find this absurd. The end game 'content' quite simply is PVP. These guys have rushed to get in the biggest ships then wonder why people run from their 1st rate fleet. Their ego limits their ability to get out of their first rates and into something more PVP focused. In addition, they forgotten that this is an ALPHA game with much of the content still in development.

The other comments I read are about chat bans. As a 41 year old gamer, I've seen it all. Many MMO's have such a toxic community, it can be enough to put you off playing the game. NA on the other hand have a low tolerance attitude towards toxic idiots who have gotten it into their heads that due to the anonymity of the internet, can say and do what they like without fear of consequence. In naval action, such idiots are quickly dealt with leaving the rest of us rational and respectful players to get on with the game without having to deal with the drama queens.  Seriously folks, if you've been turned off a game because of its community, you'll find the NA community to be one of the most helpful and friendliest out there.

So as a potential purchaser of Naval action, let me tell you about what you can expect.

Once you get through the early stages of the game and get into a ship that has a role in combat, you will want to join a clan. NA is a social game and really it's all about the clan. Do your research, find a good one and I can promise you, you'll have a great time.  Once you are sailing with your clan, your world of possibilities opens up, and you'll spend a lot of your time going out and either defending your own waters against enemy players who try to harass your countrymen, or you'll go to their waters and try to harass theirs.  PVP is usually never hard to find.

For the PVE'ers, there is content for you here too, but I can imagine without PVP, it will become repetitive fast. PVP is were it's at!

Like EVE online, NA has it's interesting politics. You'll no doubt find a nemesis, that guy you are determined to catch and sink.  There's lots of personalities out there, and you could be one too. Being 'famous' is all part of the attraction of NA, just like the real sea captains of the time.  For me, it's these clashes of personalities ad egos that makes this game so much fun.

At £29.99, in terms of fun per investment, I can tell you with my 800+ hours in this game, It's given me approximately 790 more hours of fun than AAA The Division at almost double the price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I could sit here and write a 3 page story about how good this game is... or I could leave you with a few facts, and let you decide for yourself:

1. I play TONS of video games, from many different companies ranging from AAA titles, down to little-known indie games.
2. This is in my top 5 games that I've played in my entire life. I'm 26 and have been gaming since I could reach a keyboard.
3. Hands down one of the best development teams I've ever seen. I could write an entire story about this topic alone, but simply put- they're amazing. They do what they're supposed to do, and do it with excellence, and on time.
4. If you're a fan of Naval Combat, Open World Adventuring, Trading/Economy, Collecting Stuff (a hoarder like me), or simply are a fan of beautiful graphics topped with a superb physics engine... BUY THIS GAME. WHY ARE YOU WAITING? STOP READING THIS AND BUY IT!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game!  I looked and studied and pondered for a couple of weeks before I bought it.  I've had it for 36 hours and have logged 13 hours in game.  Not having a manual makes for some interesting oopses on my part, but I'm getting the hang of it, and it's a lot more satisfying to learn things the hard way.  So far, I've only played on the PVE server, but when I level up, I'll give PVP a try.

Don't wait, buy it NOW.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If your looking for something different, then this could be it.

PRO's
Stunningly beautiful graphics, when in battle.
Large open world
Seems to attract more mature players. (Maybe not enough instant gratification for younger players)
Lots of helpful players available online during the game
Many different aspects to the game, sailing, trading, crafting, building ships, upgrades and of course brilliant battles.
Great deal of hard work from the developers with lots of regular updates and improvements to game play
Rewards skill and effort
No obvious hacking or cheats in the game that I have seen or heard of, though there have been some exploits that have been taken advantage of.

CONS
No manual. Very confusing for beginners, initially.
A lot of the online info is wrong / out of date due to game changes by the developers
Requires considerable player effort to understand and enjoy - but this will be a positive factor for many
UI crude but works well enough, even if its a bit vague and confusing at the moment. This is due to be updated.

SUMMERY
This is an Early Access game, but far more developed and playable than most. It has  (FEB 2016) strong support from the team. This has the potential, to be something very special. Nothing like the satisfaction of out maneuvering and out shooting an enemy. And nothing quite as humiliating as sinking after a heavy defeat, or seeing your crew decimated prior to being boarded. A recent update from the developers said they feel the mechanics are near right now and they will concentrate on added improvements to game content. Guess this means the UI in particular and general polishing.
But if your considering buying the game, do be prepared for some serious searching for info in the early stages!

Would sink again. 8/10 at the moment. Potential 10/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In a nutshell: The game is currently building its already solid foundation in Alpha testing.

Ships traverse an overworld with sped up movement, similar to mount and blade. Combat occurs when a ship chooses to attack you (and attempts to keep you within a certain radius of his ship in a circular ring), or when you choose to enter an instanced event/mission/battle area.

Combat involves sailing around and attempting to blast your enemy to bits before he blasts you. Ships have somewhat realistic damage models and can take hits on different sides. Leaks, fires, loss of crew will all act to the detriment of the ship. You manage crew and can select what tasks you want them to focus on. At the moment this is the most complete aspect of the game.

Ships and assets can be crafted, but ships may also be captured via boarding (where you manage crew in a rock paper scissors type minigame and attempt to reduce enemy crewcount or morale to 0). Ships sunk will lose a count of durability. Crafted ships will have up to 5 lives
date:
captured ships or the more powerful first rate ships will only have one.

Servers are PvE or PvP (other players may attack you in the overworld). The most active server is PVP1 for the EU.

You may also attempt to capture ports in special port battles, and secure a port for use by your own nation. Ports have hard hitting artillery fortifications. You will need a group to attack and defend ports.

Progression is centered on the aquisition of experience, money, and assets. You can obtain money and assets through trade, crafting, or combat solo or in a group, and xp through combat.

Nations are entities which can take and hold ports. You select a nation at character creation, and nations will act hostile to all but themselves (player driven diplomacy is currentlg the only diplomacy in game). Pirates function like a nation, but can attack other pirates as well.

PvE exists as NPC ships in missions, events, or fleets in the overworld.

The UI is barebones and there is little to no official documentation or tutorial to the game.

Don't forget that its early access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Already a heap load of fun, this game has bags of potential and will only get better and better.

It IS early access, but well worth the money in my opinion. The developers are working hard and patches/hotfixes are frequent.

Currently the UI is placeholder and well below standard, but it's functional at least. The game itself, the ships and the scenery are looking lovely though and it really captures the feeling of being in a sea battle.

The community tends to be very mature. Use of voice comms is frequent and large clans are organising for massive fleet battles on a daily basis but it's still very possible for you to solo if you are that way inclined. Some work needs to be done to balance the gold income here and there but that'll come in time.

There is currently next to no help ingame, but there is an unofficial wiki and a help chat channel in which people are more than pleased to provide answers.

On the whole, I'd wholeheartedly recommend this game as long as people understand that they really are buying a game that is (heavily) in development. I have no doubt that this game will see full release, the developers are excellent and the communication with the community is top notch.

Finally a game that is going to give Early Access a good name.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the first time I have written a review on Steam for any game so hopefully that will give you some indication how impressed I have been with Naval Action during beta testing and before the Early-Access release.

Although there is still much to be added to the game, there is already enough present to give you what feels like a complete experience, much superior to other games of it's ilk that have been released fully.

The focus is very much on simulation and the game is initially quite daunting and challenging. For example, you have to navigate properly between locations using just a compass and without your position shown on the map, whilst you have to manually aim your guns in battle (rather than letting the computer do the aiming for you as in other games). You have to learn to read the wind and sail properly (different for each ship) and the difference between a good sailor and a bad one (me!) is significant.

Although the game isn't easy at first (and there are no tutorials yet), this brings me onto one of the best facets of the game; the community. I have played more MMOs than I can remember but this is by far the friendliest and most helpful playerbase I have ever seen. Shout out for help or advice and players will quickly reply with what you need to know or sail to help you. I have had players capturing ships and giving them to me and the general chat is fun and interesting. It is common for fleets of players to group-up for hours, conquering ports etc and these times have been genuinely memorable for me.

Once you have got used to the game, it's simulation nature gives it more depth, more skill and a greater sense of achievement when you get it just right.

Graphics are top-notch: ships are beautifully and accurately modelled whilst the sea and weather effects are stunning. Sound also is good with the whistling of orders given on ships particularly immersive.

As mentioned before, there are no tutorials in-game (yet), whilst the ui (especially in port) is pretty bare at present. Plenty of features are still being worked on whilst the mechanics of port-battles, boarding and much else are still being developed. Nevertheless, there is already so much good quality content present that I have no hesitation in recommending Naval Action even in early access - you won't be disappointed.

So, if you have any interest at all in the Age of Sail or warship combat generally, this is an absolutely must-buy game even at this relatively early stage.
